[21:49:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the static versions of the author view of the HTML5 spec now have toc.js and dfn.js enabled 

[21:49:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/

[21:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec-author-view/spec.html

[21:50:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so each page of the multipage version now has an on-page TOC

[21:51:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and if you click on terms on bold that are <dfn> instances, it'll show you backreference to all the hyperlinks to that term

[19:03:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[19:04:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
oops

[19:04:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://qa-dev.w3.org:8888/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fdev.w3.org%2Fhtml5%2Ftests%2Fvalidation%2Ffull%2Finvalid%2Fmissing-attributes%2Flink-missing-href.html

[19:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
oh so dfn.js doesn't actually work cross-file?

[19:04:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: well, no

[19:04:04.0000] <Hixie>
oh ok

[19:04:05.0000] <Hixie>
nevermind then

[19:04:06.0000] <MikeSmith>
no magic -- only works within the 

[19:04:07.0000] <MikeSmith>
same file

[19:04:08.0000] <Hixie>
i disabled it on the whatwg copy because it wasn't particularly useful without that

[19:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
/me looks at the file

[19:05:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, it may be that I should disable it in the multipage author view too

[19:05:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
see the attributes list in the error message

[19:05:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
the "(required)" stuff

[19:06:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I added that by patching the copy of the HTML5 spec that v.nu uses

[19:06:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
10-line change

[19:06:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://pastebin.ca/1734693

[19:07:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so.. I wanted to as if you could consider making that change to your source 

[19:07:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
or something similar

[19:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
html5 used to have those, i took them out because very few attributes really are required vs optional, most have complicated rules about whether to have them in or not

[19:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
so i figured it would be misleading to say "required" or not

[19:08:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
well, for the v.nu case, I think it's useful

[19:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. title="" is required on <link>... if rel="stylesheet alternate"

[19:08:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
right

[19:08:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
but v.nu catches those cases and reports them

[19:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah but the spec would be misleading if it said "required" for href="" but not title=""

[19:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
because title="" isn't optional in all cases

[19:09:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah, I see your point

[19:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so, OK, it may be that this is really only useful for the v.nu messages

[19:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
i agree that it's useful in validators, though maybe it should explicitly say what is missing, since i was a bit confused when first looking at the error message

[19:10:02.0000] <Hixie>
gotta go, bbiab

[19:10:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
OK

[19:11:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but yeah, that's the core problem -- the relaxng/jing backend doesn't give useful error messages about missing attributes

[19:11:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the backend doesn't report which attributes are missing

[01:44:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:46:00.0000] <Lachy>
it's interesting how in step 2 he claims that "The one true way of naming things on the Web is with a URI." and then step 3 identifies the problem with that, but instead of fixing the problem in step 2, a layer of abstraction is added instead.

[01:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:48:01.0000] <Lachy>

[01:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:51:00.0000] <Hixie>

[08:27:00.0000] <cardona507>
so localStorage is tied to my entire domain? meaning that if I have a page in directory A that has something stored in localStorage, that stuff will show up in directory B's localStorage? That is what appears to be happening to me. If so, how would we host multiple apps on a domain without them polluting each other?

[08:31:00.0000] <annevk>
use a prefix

[08:38:00.0000] <cardona507>
thanks annevk - what do you mean? 

[08:40:00.0000] <cardona507>
like www2.foo.com?

[08:40:01.0000] <cardona507>
or foo.bar.com?

[08:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
cardona507: Use a prefix in the keys that you use when accessing localStorage

[08:45:01.0000] <cardona507>
thank Philip` - And happy new year everyone

[08:45:02.0000] <Philip`>
localStorage.a_whatever = 1; localStorage.b_whatever = 2; // no conflicts

[08:46:00.0000] <cardona507>
nice to know

[09:18:00.0000] <foolip>

[09:19:00.0000] <foolip>
obviously yes to step one and two, but the last?

[09:42:00.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: It has an HTML5 serializer, which should do what you want

[09:42:01.0000] <Philip`>
and it has various configuration options depending on what you consider pretty

[09:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
(though it never does anything DOM-altering like inserting whitespace to make the output prettier)

[09:44:00.0000] <foolip>
hmm, guess I'll have to try then

[09:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
The multipage spec splitter uses html5lib to parser and modify and print pages, which sounds like what you want

[09:45:01.0000] <Philip`>
s/parser/parse/

[09:45:02.0000] <Philip`>
(Oh, actually it uses lxml to parse because html5lib is painfully slow)

[09:46:00.0000] <Philip`>
(http://code.google.com/p/html5/source/browse/trunk/spec-splitter/spec-splitter.py)

[09:53:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[16:06:00.0000] <brandon>
I am guessing this is several days late, but I ran into a limitation I wasn't expecting (assumed it was in the spec). The problem I am having is placing a background of rgba(0,0,0,.2) OVER a background image... but background colors are only allowed to be declared last (after all other images)... The only other solution (without adding more markup or changing the image itself) is to set a...

[16:06:01.0000] <brandon>

[17:14:00.0000] <Lachy>

[17:30:00.0000] <Lachy>

[17:36:00.0000] <bfrohs>

[17:43:00.0000] <Lachy>

[17:45:00.0000] <Lachy>
or, maybe not. one sec...

[17:46:00.0000] <Lachy>
bfrohs, set z-index: -1; and specify the background image on on ::before, and then specify the colour on the element. That will give you the correct layering of text, bg colour, bg image

[17:55:00.0000] <bfrohs>

[06:56:02.0000] <mikekelly>
hi fans

[06:58:00.0000] <mikekelly>
been trying to figure out why there's no @rel attribute for form elements

[06:59:00.0000] <mikekelly>
anyone got any idea why that might be the case?

[06:59:01.0000] <cardona507>
what exactly is HTML5lib?

[07:02:00.0000] <jgraham>
cardona507: Is that a deep philosopical question or do you want a simple answer like "a set of implementations of the html5 parsing algorithm for various languages (principally python, also PHP, formerly ruby), and some associated utilities for working with HTML trees"

[07:03:00.0000] <cardona507>
jgraham - :) - not it isn't a philiosophical question - I actually am interested in what it is - thanks for the answer

[07:03:01.0000] <mikekelly>
is a form not considered a type of hyperlink?

[07:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
mikekelly: No - <a href> and <area href> and some <link href>s are the only hyperlinks

[07:06:01.0000] <Philip`>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/links.html#hyperlink-elements

[07:08:00.0000] <mikekelly>
Philip`: Ok - I was wondering more about the reason that distinction is held

[07:09:00.0000] <mikekelly>
i.e. a form links the UA to another URL .. seems like a hyperlink to me

[07:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'd guess it's because those are the only things that directly provide a URL for users to visit

[07:10:01.0000] <Philip`>
whereas form URLs aren't useful by themselves, since they require form data to be passed too

[07:10:02.0000] <Philip`>
(and lots of other URL attributes (<img src> etc) aren't followed by users)

[07:11:00.0000] <mikekelly>
so rel='search-result' wouldn't be an appropriate link relation for the google search box?

[07:11:01.0000] <mikekelly>
the link is variable

[07:11:02.0000] <mikekelly>
but it's constrained

[07:11:03.0000] <Philip`>
How would any consumer make use of that rel information?

[07:12:00.0000] <mikekelly>
the variable parts of a GET action are all search parts

[07:12:01.0000] <Philip`>
If the search form had rel="next" then what should happen in a UA which provides a 'next page' button in its UI based on rel=next links?

[07:12:02.0000] <mikekelly>
Philip`: a machine would be able to insert data into that form and understand the semantics of the resulting requesdt

[07:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
That wouldn't work on e.g. Google's search box because the semantics of the response depend on the parameters, e.g. if you click "I'm Feeling Lucky" then it sends different parameters and the result is a redirection to a result page instead of a list of results

[07:15:00.0000] <mikekelly>
what is the difference between those two submit buttons?

[07:15:01.0000] <mikekelly>
is that html?

[07:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
<form action=...><input type=submit name=btnG value=Search><input type=submit name=btnI value=Lucky></form>

[07:18:01.0000] <Philip`>
Oh dear

[07:18:02.0000] <Philip`>
If I click "I'm Feeling Lucky" with no text in the search box, it looks like an old Geocities page with fireworks everywhere :-(

[07:19:00.0000] <mikekelly>
er.. right

[07:19:01.0000] <mikekelly>
and that would be perfectly valid HTTP response

[07:19:02.0000] <mikekelly>
the redirect is a 'search-result'

[07:19:03.0000] <mikekelly>
a search result that redirects you..

[10:36:00.0000] <zcorpan>
"Content inside a blockquote must be quoted from another source" says the spec

[10:37:00.0000] <zcorpan>
so presumably <blockquote>All the world's a stage</blockquote><p>-Shakespeare</p>

[10:39:00.0000] <jwalden>
that would seem to treat -Shakespeare as semantically at the same level with any surrounding paragraphs of information, which doesn't seem right

[10:43:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[10:46:00.0000] <Philip`>

[21:12:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[21:12:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the upstream limit at validator.nu is 4096KB

[21:12:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
and the spec is around 4300KB or so now

[23:11:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I wonder if the spec is going to grow like gmail storage space

[23:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
the sum of specs that define the web will, certainly

[23:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
whether we have that in one document or a great many or something in between is an editorial issue

[23:13:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[23:14:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[23:23:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:23:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
it's not conforming in the current spec

[23:23:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
in the ABNF for the contents of the style element

[23:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: the spec shouldn't have grown... it was working fine before the holidays for me, and i validate the complete version of the spec before preprocessing (i.e. about 13 specs at once)

[23:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
maybe the preprocessor overhead is more than i realised

[23:25:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
it was hitting the v.nu size limit well before the holidays

[23:25:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[23:33:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:33:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:36:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:38:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:38:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://qa-dev.w3.org:8888/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fdev.w3.org%2Fhtml5%2Ftests%2Fvalidation%2Ffull%2Finvalid%2Fmissing-attributes%2Flink-missing-href.html

[23:39:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[23:40:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: added all required-attributes to Assertions.java and have the build make copies of the meta.rnc, embed.rnc, media.rnc, and microdata.rnc files with the required attributes made optional in the schema

[23:41:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the copies are, e.g, meta-vnu.rnc

[23:41:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and are generated, so not in version control

[23:41:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[23:41:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:23:00.0000] <workmad3>

[01:24:00.0000] <workmad3>

[01:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[01:24:02.0000] <workmad3>
couple that with the fact that multiple <link> tags already works and multiple type attributes on a <link> tag will break older browsers...

[01:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[01:26:00.0000] <workmad3>

[01:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[01:26:02.0000] <workmad3>
as opposed to it being hidden behind some web service call that is :)

[01:27:00.0000] <workmad3>

[01:29:00.0000] <workmad3>

[01:32:00.0000] <workmad3>

[03:04:02.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, if we keep the spec as is, then having autobuffer omitted must then mean no buffering. But that doesn't allow for browsers to provide sensible heuristic based approaches

[03:05:00.0000] <othermaciej>
what Lachy said - I think there needs to be a way to specifically hint "don't buffer" that's distinct from giving no hint at all

[03:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
what's the use case for that?

[03:06:00.0000] <jgraham>
"authors really want to conserve bandwidth"

[03:06:01.0000] <Lachy>
the main use case mentioned on the list has been a blog that includes a video as part of one of the entires, but the author doesn't think all users will want to watch the video just because the article still happens to be on the front page

[03:06:02.0000] <Hixie>
wouldn't that be all authors who don't want buffering?

[03:06:03.0000] <jgraham>
Hixie: ?

[03:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
what's the distinction between the author who doesn't want buffering (and so doesn't set autobuffer) and the author who wants no buffering (and so sets nobuffer)?

[03:07:01.0000] <zcorpan_>
MikeSmithX: <style><!--> opens an escape in opera

[03:08:00.0000] <jgraham>
Hixie: The author that doesn't set autobuffer may still get buffering if the browser so choses

[03:08:01.0000] <Lachy>
the difference is that the omitted attribute doesn't give a clear indication of author preference, and so browsers should be allowed to optimise for the best user experience

[03:09:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: authors who don't think about the issue likely won't include any particular attribute, thus the browser might choose to guess whether buffering would be good based on things like number of videos on the page, their prominence and relative size, etc

[03:10:00.0000] <Lachy>
e.g. If I'm on a high speed connection with no bandwidth limits, as I am here in Norway, then I wouldn't mind having my browser autobuffer for me automatically on most sites. However, if I'm stuck in Australia on a slow, usage-capped connection then I'd prefer not to unless I really wanted to watch the video

[03:10:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: except that you can't distinguish "no opinion" from "specifically don't want buffering"

[03:10:02.0000] <othermaciej>
with the current spec design

[03:10:03.0000] <doublec>
how would the browser know you're on a usage capped connection?

[03:10:04.0000] <Hixie>

[03:10:05.0000] <Lachy>

[03:48:00.0000] <annevk>

[03:48:01.0000] <workmad3>

[03:48:02.0000] <workmad3>

[03:48:03.0000] <annevk>

[03:48:04.0000] <hsivonen>

[03:48:05.0000] <annevk>

[03:48:06.0000] <hsivonen>

[03:51:00.0000] <annevk>

[03:51:01.0000] <annevk>

[03:51:02.0000] <annevk>

[03:51:03.0000] <Lachy>

[03:52:00.0000] <Lachy>

[03:52:01.0000] <annevk>

[03:53:00.0000] <annevk>

[03:56:00.0000] <jgraham>

[03:56:01.0000] <jgraham>

[04:30:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[04:31:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[04:39:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[04:41:00.0000] <jgraham>

[04:42:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[04:42:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[04:43:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[09:13:00.0000] <abernier>
html5 introduces new elements like <header>, <footer>, <nav>, ... is it a good idea for html4 authoring to replace them by <div class="(header|footer|nav)" ?

[09:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
abernier, doesn't really matter, unless it will make transition easier or something.

[09:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
abernier, the point of the new elements is to add standardized semantics, you don't get those in HTML4 for these elements either way.

[09:33:00.0000] <abernier>
AryehGregor: yes, and adding semantics through class attributes is a quite common concept, no?

[09:42:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
abernier, but they aren't standardized semantics.  Nothing other than your own page is going to treat <div class="header"> any differently from <div class="snafflefloozer">.  For all any third-party semantics-inferring tool knows, you prefer to call your headers snafflefloozers and vice versa.  So there's no reason to use one over the other except personal preference/legibility/etc.

[09:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I know users underestimate how much effort development takes, but this is still a pretty impressive statement: ". . . I want everything perfect and without any flaws. Is that to much to ask ?"  http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=16482

[10:07:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:11:00.0000] <Hixie>

[16:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: because i have the feeling that some of these bugs that i'm marking "Rejected" due to unclear requests are going to just be raised as issues, and will waste a lot of the WG's time, where if the request had just been made clear in the bug, I maybe would have been fine with making the change

[16:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:52:00.0000] <hsivonen>
hmm. so is pageshow supposed to fire on initial page load, too, and not only when navigating back to a page in the back-forward cache?

[02:53:00.0000] <hsivonen>
apparently yes

[02:53:01.0000] <hsivonen>
and Gecko and WebKit either differ in handler support or in event firing

[02:53:02.0000] <zcorpan>
does pageshow use the Event interface?

[02:53:03.0000] <hsivonen>
dunno

[02:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't like how pageshow is defined

[02:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it makes it needlessly awkward to have code that *only* runs when restoring from b/f cache

[02:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if only one of "load" or "pageshow" fired, you could easily put code in one handler or both depending on whether it's one-time, every-time or restore-only initialization

[02:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
not only that but "load" has to do complete initialization anyway, to support browsers that don't have "pageshow"

[02:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I believe I gave this complaint to the folks who first implemented these events for Gecko but they were unconvinced

[03:00:00.0000] <zcorpan>
not too late to change it

[03:00:01.0000] <hsivonen>
hasn't Gecko had a b/f cache for years already?

[03:10:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yes it has

[03:10:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I discussed it with the engineers working on it before it shipped, years ago

[03:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'd suspect at this point a new event ("pagerestore"?) would be required

[03:11:01.0000] <othermaciej>
although I think it's hard to depend on "pageshow" always firing, and yet still be compatible with browsers that never fire it at all

[05:50:01.0000] <Lachy>
re the autobuffer thread, I'm not entirely convinced that making autobuffer itself a tri-state attribute (on/off, or absent) is impossible, despite it being boolean in Firefox 3.5

[05:51:00.0000] <jgraham>
But I'm not really sure that it was baiting (I'm not sure what the point would be)

[05:52:00.0000] <jgraham>
Lachy: Agreed but I don't really see the value in taking the risk

[05:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Firefox has pretty high uptake on updates

[05:52:02.0000] <Lachy>
since autobuffer is, I believe, currently only implemented in Firefox, and its omission currently has the same effect as autobuffer=off should have, then authors can simply omit the attribute for the relatively short transition from FF 3.5 to 3.6

[05:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there are advantages and disadvantages to reusing autobuffer vs. minting a new buffer attribute

[05:53:01.0000] <Lachy>
so, if 3.6 supported autobuffer as tri-state, then the issue would not have serious long term consequnces

[05:53:02.0000] <othermaciej>
a new buffer attribute could be more clear and would have less risk of legacy conflict, but at the same time it might leave us stuck with two attributes

[05:53:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm planning to list both options when I file the bug

[05:53:04.0000] <jgraham>
I think we could obsolete autobuffer at this stage

[05:54:00.0000] <Lachy>
of course, using buffer="..." as tri-state, and obsoleting autobuffer would also be acceptable to me

[05:55:00.0000] <Lachy>
I don't think there is significant content out there relying on autobuffer for it to be impossible to remove once buffer="" is more widely supported

[05:55:01.0000] <annevk>
autobuffer can easily be removed

[05:55:02.0000] <annevk>
that was never the concern

[05:55:03.0000] <annevk>
afaict

[05:56:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: Gecko 1.9.2 is in RC in mobile. changes to the engine feature set are highly theoretical at this point

[05:57:00.0000] <Lachy>
also, I'm slighly less convinced about the need for tri-state buffering, until I've seen more evidence about what sort of heuristics browsers can realistically apply when the attribute is absent to make it significantly different from the no-buffering case.

[00:00:02.0000] <Hixie>
when someone refers to http://example.com/#foo, where http://example.com/ has no script and no element with id=foo, clearly something is wrong

[00:00:03.0000] <Hixie>
but if there's a script, #foo could be an argument to that script representing state

[00:00:04.0000] <Hixie>

[03:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
wait this is already clear

[03:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
there's one bitmap according to the spec

[03:04:00.0000] <hsivonen>
/me doubts treating canvas as one bitmap for both the WebGL and 2D contexts is going to fly

[03:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
There's some currently-active discussion on the WebGL list about the context stuff

[03:07:00.0000] <annevk>
aah, let Philip` coordinate!

[03:08:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hixie: Implementors don't want to share a bitmap between 2D and WebGL contexts, because it forces performance penalties in current hardware/APIs

[03:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
Philip`: ok, please file a bug when you can tell me precisely what the spec should say :-)

[03:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
so the HTML spec itself is clear but it's incompatible with what the WebGL spec requires

[03:09:01.0000] <hsivonen>
how does WebGL handle page zooming?

[03:09:02.0000] <Philip`>
/me is kind of hoping the WebGL people will work out what to do

[03:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: As far as I'm aware (which isn't far since I've never tested it at all), they'd render into a width*height-attribute sized buffer and then stretch it to match CSS and zoom etc

[03:11:01.0000] <Philip`>
since I don't see what else they could reasonably do

[03:12:00.0000] <Lachy>
jgraham, is your system clock set to the wrong day? This e-mail of yours was sent yesterday, but dated today. http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jan/0123.html

[03:13:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: can OpenGL ES read back the buffer at the time of zooming, or will everything be kept in a buffer in case the user zooms later?

[03:14:00.0000] <hsivonen>
anyway, for both 2D and 3D, it seems super-sad to me that Canvas is concuptually a bitmap instead of being a one-way resolution-independent drawing pipeline

[03:14:01.0000] <hsivonen>
/me often runs with non-1:1 zoom

[03:14:02.0000] <hsivonen>
/me doesn't want jaggies

[03:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
i tried my best to make it the latter

[03:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: It's defined in terms of writing to a fixed-size drawing buffer, and glReadPixels reads back from that buffer, and the buffer is passed to "the HTML page compositor immediately before a compositing operation" (where it might be transformed and drawn on top of, etc)

[03:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me likes the ability to read pixels back from canvases, because otherwise it'd be impossible to do pretty much everything he's ever done with it

[03:20:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: does glReadPixels kill perf?

[03:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: Its existence doesn't hurt the performance of any other drawing operations

[03:21:01.0000] <Philip`>
but it's a bit slow if you call it

[03:21:02.0000] <hsivonen>
/me has no idea how GL context virtualization in Quartz Compositor and the like works

[03:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me neither

[03:22:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: doesn't a readback always stall the GPU pipeline for the duration of the readback?

[03:22:02.0000] <Philip`>
(though I don't even know what it is)

[03:22:03.0000] <hsivonen>
or is a readback async?

[03:23:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's synchronous at the OpenGL API level

[03:23:01.0000] <Philip`>
so the drivers/hardware would have to flush all current drawing calls and then read all the pixels before carrying on, I presume

[03:23:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: as I understand it, Quartz window compositing is done on top of GL, but you can pretend the GL context inside your window is the whole GL world

[03:23:03.0000] <hsivonen>
or something like that

[03:24:00.0000] <hsivonen>
without really knowing much about this, it seems that a one-way operation for transferring the pixels onto a texture within the GPU would be a useful operation

[03:25:00.0000] <hsivonen>
assuming you could queue subsequent ops with the texture into the pipeline right away

[03:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
You can select a texture as the framebuffer object, so that things are rendered directly onto that texture

[03:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://www.khronos.org/opengles/sdk/docs/man/glFramebufferTexture2D.xml

[03:27:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: does using that result in the same black-box-testable effects as reading back the pixels? 

[03:28:00.0000] <hsivonen>
(assuming your CSS compositor allows a gl texture on a layer)

[03:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
You mean rendering onto the default framebuffer, then reading the pixels from the GPU back to the CPU, then doing the compositing on the CPU; vs rendering onto a new framebuffer that's bound to a texture, keeping it on the GPU, and doing the compositing on the GPU (assuming your GPU compositor is equivalent to the CPU-based one)?

[03:30:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: right

[03:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
Those should be equivalent as far as I'm aware, as long as your framebuffers are the same size and type in each case

[03:31:01.0000] <hsivonen>
/me hasn't used an GL features that weren't available way back when on an SGI O2

[03:31:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: ok

[03:31:03.0000] <hsivonen>
s/an/any/

[03:31:04.0000] <hsivonen>
/me also hasn't used all features that were available back then

[03:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
It seems the problem with 2D/WebGL contexts is that browsers don't have a GPU-based compositor today, and they do 2D canvas on the CPU, but they want to support WebGL today, and they don't want to require a GPU/CPU synchronisation performance penalty

[03:33:01.0000] <Philip`>
It shouldn't be a problem in the future but they need a solution now

[03:33:02.0000] <hsivonen>
/me thought Safari on Snow Leopard had a GPU-based compositor

[03:33:03.0000] <Philip`>
(and preferably one that doesn't prevent a better solution in the future)

[10:36:00.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
can one use <section> instead of <div> now?  

[10:36:01.0000] <Philip`>
Not in all cases, since they have different semantics

[10:37:00.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
so section is more of a broad element?

[10:37:01.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
div more specific?

[10:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think (but could be wrong) that <section> should be used for a block that has a heading and that should appear in an outline of the document

[10:39:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me looks at the spec

[10:39:01.0000] <Philip`>
"Note: The section element is not a generic container element. When an element is needed for styling purposes or as a convenience for scripting, authors are encouraged to use the div element instead. A general rule is that the section element is appropriate only if the element's contents would be listed explicitly in the document's outline."

[10:39:02.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
oh ok so a page could have <header></header><section></section><footer></footer>

[10:40:00.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
oh ok so put the divs inside so those would serve the purpose of a layout

[10:40:01.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
and <aside> too i imagine

[10:40:02.0000] <Philip`>
It could, although in that case I think you could just do <header>header</header>content<footer>footer</footer> and there's no need for <section> (though there would be a need if the content consisted of multiple sections)

[10:41:00.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
oh ok so i have one time or a few times had the need to have multiple pages

[10:41:01.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
like but have it vertical

[10:41:02.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>
so a section could serve as a page

[10:41:03.0000] <Philip`>
If you're using <section>/etc then you should style those directly, rather than writing <section><div>... and styling the div

[10:41:04.0000] <Philip`>
but if you don't need the semantics of <section> then you should just use <div> by itself (or any more appropriate element)

[10:42:00.0000] <Philip`>
You might want <article> if the 'pages' are self-contained components

[10:43:00.0000] <smq-monstros1ty>

[16:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[16:13:02.0000] <annevk>
though they fixed some of it in 3.0 it seems

[16:15:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'm interpreting "accreted" as meaning the same as "evolved", and languages like Python and Java accreted with the guidance of some language design principles and a desire for self-consistency

[16:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
(The first versions were very different to the current versions - nobody sat down and wrote a complete spec for the current version before implementing any of it)

[03:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: how should i handle bugs that are just questions, e.g. http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=8661 ? (I mean, other than answering the question, which I will do, obviously.)

[03:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
reject? partial accept? "i don't understand"?

[03:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: not really sure

[03:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: this one has an implied spec change based on a faulty premise in addition to the question

[03:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>
i.e. it says there is a contradiction which actually there is not

[03:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
so I'd handle this one on that basis (in addition to answering the question)

[03:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if a bug really just asked a question without any report of a problem or request for a change (even implied), then I would consider that INVALID, same as garbage text or a completely off-topic comment

[03:43:01.0000] <othermaciej>
or maybe NEEDSINFO if it seemed like the person was getting at something but failed to express themselves

k

[12:08:00.0000] <Lachy>
so I would assume the split will only affect the W3C copy

[12:37:00.0000] <Lachy>
in this case, (a) and (b) are mostly identical, except for the header (basically everything above the TOC) and the recent introduction of the device element.

[12:37:01.0000] <Philip`>

[12:48:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me wonders how the crieria used to spilt out microdata apply to other parts of the specification

[12:48:01.0000] <cardona507>
what is a shadow dom?

[12:48:02.0000] <jgraham>
In particular "maturity" and "market success"

[12:49:00.0000] <jgraham>
cardona507: In what contex? XBL defines an officil meaning but it has been used in a different sense to talk about <canvas> accessibility

[12:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm not sure precisely how the <canvas> folks are using the term, but when you hear it in reference to XBL2, it means a special transformed DOM that is only accessible to CSS.

[12:50:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Javascript still sees the original, untransformed DOM.

[12:50:02.0000] <cardona507>
I was just reading a canvas accessibility email from HTMLwg and I am unclear by "shadow dom" - tabatkins - only accessible to css? what are the benefits?

[12:51:00.0000] <jgraham>
cardona507: http://www.w3.org/TR/xbl/#shadow is what xbl means

[12:51:01.0000] <cardona507>
cool - thanks jgraham

[12:51:02.0000] <Philip`>
In the canvas accessibility discussion, it just means the DOM subtree of the <canvas> element (which doesn't get rendered in graphical browsers), as far as I'm aware

[12:51:03.0000] <jgraham>
in the <canvas> case they just mean "desendants of the canvas element" as I understand it

[12:51:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
cardona507: The benefit is that it allows you to do transformations that don't actually make sense from a content perspective, but are necessary for styling.  Like, say, wrapping a box in multiple <div>s so that you can style each one.

[12:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
in the case of <canvas> it's just the descendants of canvas which are not rendered, but are exposed to accessibility tools, per the spec

[12:52:01.0000] <cardona507>
ahhh - I see - thanks othermaciej

[12:52:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
The fact that your styling happens to be easier to apply when you have a structure like <div><div><div><div>foo</div></div></div></div> shouldn't have any effect on your actual content, which just uses <div>foo</div>.

[12:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: most of the individual criteria were not enough to decide the matter by themselves, and it's not clear if any other part of the spec is precisely in the somewhat unusual position that Microdata is in

[12:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
What precisely *is* the unusual position Microdata is in?

[12:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: plus, we're not going to rule on splitting anything that no one actually objects to

[12:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
read the long review of arguments

[12:54:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
othermaciej: That still leaves you with, iirc, something like half a dozen requests to remove things.  ^_^

[12:54:04.0000] <Philip`>
Isn't the XBL thing going to be a nightmare for debugging and for understanding what tree structure your document represents?

[12:54:05.0000] <othermaciej>
and see if you think those same arguments all apply equally to any other part of the spec

[12:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Philip: I don't think so.  The kind of reorganizing you can do is relatively limited.

[12:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway, I am interested in moving on to the next issue on deck which is the dt/dd/details/figure thing

[12:55:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I hope someone else writes an alternate proposal for that because I am not really keen on <fltcap>

[12:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I might have to write one myself, or more than one

[12:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I still have *no* clue what fltcap is supposed to stand for.  I see that "cap" part is for "caption", but what is "flt"?

[12:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it's supposed to stand for "floating caption"

[12:56:03.0000] <jgraham>
Oh I forot about that issue

[12:56:04.0000] <Lachy>
the right way to deal with that is, since Hixie won't introduce new elements, is to drop both figure and details from the spec and reintroduce them with <legend> in the future when the parsing issues are resolved with it.

[12:56:05.0000] <Lachy>
ah, rending issues.

[12:56:06.0000] <jgraham>
Yeah there needs to be another chage proposal at least

[12:56:07.0000] <Lachy>
*rendering

[12:57:00.0000] <Lachy>
ok, someone should write down what I just said as a change proposal

[12:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
as far as I am aware, that is not an ordinary term of art for the caption for a figure, let alone the label of a disclosure control

[12:57:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I am considering writing Change Proposals for one or more of the following:

[12:57:03.0000] <othermaciej>
1) Use <caption> for <figure> and <label> for <details>, with a slight tweak to parsing so that <caption> inside <figure> does not break tables

[12:58:00.0000] <Lachy>
that would be nice if you think the legacy issues with <caption> aren't insurmountable

[12:58:01.0000] <othermaciej>
2) Introduce new elements <fcaption> and <dlabel> because it's totally a standard design pattern for HTML elements with compound structure to have specialized helper elements that exist only for purposes of their structure

[12:59:00.0000] <Lachy>
I like <c> as an element name, which I've suggested before

[12:59:01.0000] <othermaciej>
despite Hixie's distaste for the idea, we have tbody, thead, tfoot, tr, td and caption which are (currently) only used for tables, li only for lists, dt/dd previously only for dl, param only for object

[12:59:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
The issues with <caption> only arise when you put a <figure> inside of a <table> anyway.  If you can avoid that you're golden.

[12:59:03.0000] <Lachy>
I think I've also suggested <description>

[13:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: and parsing can be changed in the future to make it not a problem in the long run, so I think it's better than <legend>, since both are fixable and in the short term <caption> only affects <figure> in <table>

[13:00:01.0000] <othermaciej>
3) Suggest using <h1> (or some other <hn> element) for figure captions and the label of <details>

[13:00:02.0000] <Lachy>
TabAtkins, given how many legacy pages there are using layout tables around the whole page, I don't think it's unrealistic for a <figure> to end up being added to an old template like that

[13:00:03.0000] <jgraham>
I think my general opinion is that a) parsing issues should not be underestimated and b) adding more elements is not a problem

[13:00:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Then they just wait for parsing changes before doing so, Lachy.

[13:01:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I asked Hixie what the problem with <h1> would be and he said it might interfere with the content model of <figure>

[13:01:01.0000] <jgraham>
Seriously people "just wait for parsing changes" is a really bad strategy

[13:01:02.0000] <Lachy>
I don't like the idea of reusing heading elements, since a caption is not a heading. It's a very different concept, and I think the default styling of h1 will make it very unappealing to authors

[13:01:03.0000] <jgraham>
If we can't do something that can be deployed in legacy browsers we should wait for the next version of HTML

[13:01:04.0000] <othermaciej>
my reaction is that this is not a problem for <details>, and in the case of <figure> in the unusual case where you need headers inside the figure content, you can wrap it in a <div> or <section>

[13:02:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If the parsing changes are required to use it at *all*, like <legend>, it's a problem.  If they are more minor, it's less of a problem.

[13:02:01.0000] <jgraham>
"Needed to use it in a table based layout" is a serious problem

[13:02:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think <details><label> can be deployed in legacy browsers with essentially no problem, and <figure><caption> with problems only for figures in tables, but making it usable everywhere else

[13:02:03.0000] <Lachy>
also, reusing h1 to h6 for this will make stylesheets overly complicated, since authors wanting to apply styles to headings will have to do some magic with their CSS to undo the styles for figure>h1

[13:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: I agree with you in general that adding new elements is not a problem; Hixie seems to be almost alone in very strongly opposing new elements

[13:03:01.0000] <othermaciej>
out of my 3 proposals I most prefer <fcaption>+<dlabel>

[13:03:02.0000] <Lachy>
I think Hixie's stance on new elements is not supported by sound rationale

[13:03:03.0000] <othermaciej>
because, like I said, specialized child elements for structured containers are totally normal

[13:04:00.0000] <cardona507>

[05:19:00.0000] <Lachy>
hsivonen, firmware updates that remove leaked DRM keys are, IIRC, somewhat forced upon users when they insert discs produced and bought after the blacklisting.

[05:20:00.0000] <Lachy>
so if a disc says the device's key isn't valid, it won't be able to play the disc without a firmware upgrade

[05:20:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: ah. I don't really know how this works.

[05:20:02.0000] <Lachy>
ok, here's a brief summary:

[05:21:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: I was thinking of HDCP over HDMI stopping to support a picture source

[05:21:01.0000] <hsivonen>
it would suck pretty badly if one's video card stopped interoperating with a TV because the TV downloaded a blacklist with the GPU on it

[05:22:00.0000] <hsivonen>
due to the GPU having gotten cracked elsewhere 

[05:22:01.0000] <hsivonen>
or something like that

[05:22:02.0000] <Lachy>
Hardware vendors for blu-ray players are issued device keys that are stored somewhere in the firmware, usually in a way that's difficult for end users to access.

[05:22:03.0000] <hsivonen>
I don't even know what the threat scenarios are here

[05:23:00.0000] <Lachy>
The blu-ray discs have information on them pertaining to the set of keys that are valid. (This isn't just a simple list, it uses some complicated mathematics that I won't even try to explain)

[05:23:01.0000] <Lachy>
The AACS have a way to blacklist device keys by altering that information on future discs

[05:24:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: does this affect the HDCP hop in any way?

[05:24:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: does the TV and the Blu-Ray player need to be updated in sync or something like that?

[05:24:02.0000] <Lachy>
I don't believe so. If the player is able to decode and play the disc, the HDCP is a separate encryption step

[05:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
but I'm not an expert on this and my summary was an overly simplified summary

[05:26:00.0000] <hsivonen>
anyway, this DRM stuff isn't a good background for motivating users to approve the installation of browser or Flash updates to their TVs

[05:28:00.0000] <Lachy>
I've never had a TV that could accept firmware updates, and until it was mentioned a few minutes ago, it didn't occur to me that anyone would do it.

[05:29:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I have one that could accept updates, but the TV works now as a display for a Mac Mini, so I haven't taken any chances with updates

[05:30:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I've never tried the built-in networking or the widget engine on the TV

[05:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me vaguely remembers an explanation that the complicated mathematics is kind of like there's a binary tree with device keys as leafs, and the disc can contain a set of keys corresponding to nodes in the tree, where each node key can be combined with a device key in a subtree of that node, in order to decode the disc

[05:30:02.0000] <hsivonen>
in fact, I've never even connected it to a TV antenna cord

[05:30:03.0000] <Philip`>
and so the first discs just need a key at the root node, and later you can blacklist any arbitrary device key by only giving node keys at the nodes that aren't its ancestors (i.e. by giving O(depth of tree) keys)

[05:30:04.0000] <Philip`>
which seems like a clever approach

[05:31:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me has never had a TV that required updates but does have a Wii that does (and sometimes has mandatory updates)

[05:32:00.0000] <jgraham>
(and a Wii and a TV are about the same level of consuer hardware as far as I'm concerned)

[05:32:01.0000] <jgraham>
*consumer

[05:39:00.0000] <hsivonen>
does XML make it possible to introduce carriage returns in PI data?

[05:40:00.0000] <Lachy>
I don't see how that would be possible

[05:40:01.0000] <gsnedders>
"To simplify the tasks of applications, the XML processor MUST behave as if it normalized all line breaks in external parsed entities (including the document entity) on input, before parsing, by translating both the two-character sequence #xD #xA and any #xD that is not followed by #xA to a single #xA character."

[05:40:02.0000] <gsnedders>
I can't see any way past that

[05:41:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[12:04:00.0000] <navap>
Is there a difference between the whatwg and w3c specs for html5?

[12:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
the "whatwg html" spec is a superset of the w3c html5 spec -- it has features that aren't yet in the w3c copy, like <device>, and it puts everything in one document instead of several

[12:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
(the whatwg currently also has an "html5" spec that's identical to the w3c "core and vocabulary" one, but i think that's just causing confusion so i might just drop it)

[12:06:01.0000] <navap>
So which is this one? http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/

[12:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
that's the "whatwg html" spec, which is the "latest version" of html, with more features than html5.

[12:07:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Plural?

[12:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
<device> and <details>, currently

[12:10:00.0000] <navap>
Okay so http://whatwg.org/html and http://whatwg.org/html5 both point to the same document which is the HTML+HTML5 spec, and then there is also http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/html5/ which is just the HTML5 spec?

[12:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[12:10:02.0000] <Hixie>
i think i'll drop the latter one though

[12:10:03.0000] <Hixie>
as it is just causing confusion

[12:23:00.0000] <navap>
Shouldn't the examples given here have their p elements closed at the end of each line? http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/commands.html#conversations

[12:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
</p> is optional in HTML

[12:24:00.0000] <navap>
Whereas in XHTML it isn't?

[12:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
XHTML requires all start and end tags to be explicit

[12:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
whereas HTML has special cases so some tags can be omitted

[12:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
also Web SQL Database isn't deprecated

[07:17:00.0000] <mikekelly>

[07:18:00.0000] <mikekelly>
what's the barrier to standardizing a javascript API for setting/flushing Authorization header (per domain) ?

[07:19:00.0000] <mikekelly>
obviously this is outside of HTML or HTTP - this is more just a general question aimed at browser people =)

[07:19:01.0000] <Philip`>
Why should it be a JS API?

[07:19:02.0000] <mikekelly>
why is XHR js?

[07:19:03.0000] <mikekelly>
:/

[07:19:04.0000] <Philip`>
Because the purpose of XHR is to let JS make HTTP requests, so it has to be JS

[07:20:00.0000] <mikekelly>
well this is to let JS set the Authorization header..

[07:20:01.0000] <Philip`>
Authorization seems to be a purely HTTP thing

[07:20:02.0000] <mikekelly>
what?

[07:20:03.0000] <Philip`>
(currently)

[07:20:04.0000] <mikekelly>
what does that even mean

[07:20:05.0000] <mikekelly>
:/

[07:21:00.0000] <mikekelly>
so you can't understand what one might want to set Authorization header for a browser session?

[07:21:01.0000] <mikekelly>
with js

[07:21:02.0000] <Philip`>
I just mean there isn't currently a JS interface to any part of it, as far as I'm aware

[07:21:03.0000] <mikekelly>
right - I'm asking what the barrier is to that kind of API

[07:21:04.0000] <mikekelly>
where access is simply set/flush the header

[07:22:00.0000] <mikekelly>
and browser persists this per domain the same way it does for HTTP Basic right now..

[07:22:01.0000] <mikekelly>
but also exposes flush so we can actually implement logout..

[07:22:02.0000] <Philip`>
Probably the main problem is to convince people that a JS interface is better than any other ways of making authorization more useful (e.g. allowing custom HTML login forms, adding something to HTTP for logout pages, etc)

[07:22:03.0000] <mikekelly>
that's not how HTTP Authorization works

[07:23:00.0000] <mikekelly>
Logging In is a client-side state change

[07:23:01.0000] <mikekelly>
it's outside the scope of HTTP

[07:23:02.0000] <mikekelly>
whether the client is required to resubmit the Auth credentials for every request.. or they are persisted.. is down to the client

[07:23:03.0000] <mikekelly>
HTTP is completely agnostic to that

[07:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me sees a site that does <div class="FloatLeft VerdanaText Bold Font-Size-12 Margin-Top-4 Margin-Left-5 AlignCenter"  style="width: 190px; height: 15px;" >

[07:24:01.0000] <mikekelly>
if browser provided a JS API for set/flush the header per domain this functionality could be controlled via HTML+js 

[07:24:02.0000] <Philip`>
Hooray for separation of presentation and content

[07:25:00.0000] <mikekelly>
?

[07:25:01.0000] <mikekelly>
=/

[07:28:00.0000] <mikekelly>
isn't this outside of HTML?

[07:29:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:29:01.0000] <Philip`>

[09:09:02.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:11:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:11:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:12:01.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:12:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:12:03.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:14:00.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:14:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:14:02.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:15:00.0000] <webben>

[09:15:01.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:16:00.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:16:01.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:16:02.0000] <mikekelly>
does it's magic

[09:16:03.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:17:01.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:17:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:17:03.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:17:04.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:17:05.0000] <mikekelly>

[09:17:06.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:18:00.0000] <mikekelly>
no it doesn't..

[09:18:01.0000] <othermaciej>
"The Digest scheme challenges

[09:18:02.0000] <othermaciej>
   using a nonce value. A valid response contains a checksum (by default, the MD5 checksum) of the username, the password, the given

[09:18:03.0000] <othermaciej>
   nonce value, the HTTP method, and the requested URI."

[09:18:04.0000] <othermaciej>
from the RFC

[09:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's a challenge-response protocol

[09:19:01.0000] <othermaciej>
you can't set a valid response before seeing the chalenge

[09:19:02.0000] <othermaciej>
many other strong auth methods (NTLM, Kerberos) also work on a challenge/response basis

[09:20:00.0000] <mikekelly>
right - but the client credentials don't change..

[09:20:01.0000] <othermaciej>
the username and password don't change

[09:21:00.0000] <othermaciej>
so you could let JS tell those to the browser

[09:21:01.0000] <mikekelly>
with the auth echeme

[09:21:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but the *header* that you send

[09:21:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that does change

[09:21:04.0000] <mikekelly>
a decent point

[09:21:05.0000] <mikekelly>

[10:00:00.0000] <mikekelly>

[10:00:01.0000] <webben>
It doesn't elimate the putative benefit; it means the benefit/cost ratio of one action is higher than the other action.

[10:01:00.0000] <webben>
So rational actors are more likely to take the former action - because time/resource/money is limited.

[10:01:01.0000] <webben>

[16:06:00.0000] <webben>
/me is left wondering whether using a bug tracker where everyone on the wg is subscribed by default, but where you could desubscribe from tickets you don't care about, might work better.

[16:07:00.0000] <webben>

[16:08:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[16:08:01.0000] <webben>

[16:09:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[16:09:01.0000] <webben>

[16:09:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[16:11:00.0000] <webben>

[16:11:01.0000] <webben>

[16:12:00.0000] <webben>

[17:49:00.0000] <Lachy>
This whole spec splitting debacle has just gone to show that there are clear flaws in the way the process was set up, yet instead of people complaining about the broken process, they're blaming Hixie for somehow not following it.

[17:52:00.0000] <cardona507>
what are some of the flaws in the process that you see?

[17:54:00.0000] <Lachy>
The process allows bugs for non-trivial issues to be filed in bugzilla, where they clearly don't get as much attention as a proper WG discussion, but the process allows the editor to review the arguments in the bug and make an initial assessment and make relevant changes

[17:54:01.0000] <Lachy>
for trvial bugs, that process is not a problem. Hixie does it all the time.

[17:55:00.0000] <Lachy>
But with a major issue, like requesting the removal of a section, there are two choices. Either Hixie rejects the idea, and someone can choose to escalate it (which ends up giving it the attention it deserved in the first place)

[17:56:00.0000] <Lachy>
Or Hixie can accept the proposal and make the change, but then suffer serious blow back from the rest of the WG as most were not involved in the bugzilla discussion, due to the difficulty of following those bugs compared with the mailing list.

[17:57:00.0000] <Lachy>
My e-mail on the issue basically said, major and potentiall controversial issues should at least have a first round of discussion on the mailing list, optionally opening a bug in parallel for tracking purposes, but where at least initial significant discussion takes place on the list

[17:58:00.0000] <Lachy>
that allows us to get a rough idea of how the group feels about the issue

[18:00:00.0000] <Lachy>
of course, public-html would be a lot healthier if it wasn't so buried in process discussions all the time, which is effecitly the cause of us having to set up bugzilla to keep real technical issues separate from the nonsense

[18:00:01.0000] <cardona507>
I guess an argument might be "but what if the bug didn't get opened in parallel? and then the conversation petered out but there was not bug to force action"

[18:00:02.0000] <cardona507>
*not a bug

[18:01:00.0000] <Lachy>
then someone can open a bug, and cite the major technical arguments for/against and include an initial change proposal. That allows the editor to review the bug and past discussion and make an initial decision

[18:01:01.0000] <Lachy>
and then follow the rest of the process as normal from that point onwards

[18:02:00.0000] <cardona507>
so you are basically saying that you would like it if people could just discuss such major issues before soley relying on bugzilla?

[18:02:01.0000] <webben>
Keeping all technical discussion under bugs might reduce the amount of process discussion, since it would basically be OT for a bug.

[18:03:00.0000] <Lachy>
webben, it doesn't help to reduce it on the list, and so real technical discussion which is harder for people to follow in bugzilla gets lost, while everyone still gets flooded with process discussions

[18:04:00.0000] <webben>
I think that bugzilla is making technical discussion hard to follow is a consequence of the tracker software and how it's being used, not an intrinsic problem with bug-oriented discussion

[18:04:01.0000] <Lachy>
this is they the WHATWG model was so much healthier for years before the W3C got involved. It's just gone downhill from there.

[18:04:02.0000] <webben>
I think the WHATWG model worked reasonably well for people involved throughout the process.

[18:05:00.0000] <webben>
It worked less well for newcomers and people intermittently involved the longer the process went on, since it became harder to follow why decisions had been taken/what relevant information had already been presented.

[18:05:01.0000] <webben>
The mailing list search was never very user-friendly.

[18:06:00.0000] <Lachy>
anyway, I'm in pain from my elbow injury  and I'm going to bed.  good night

[18:06:01.0000] <webben>
I don't from a pure process perspective the W3C-WHATWG partnership has improved the situation though.

[18:07:00.0000] <webben>
Lachy: Good night! Hope that heals soon!

[18:07:01.0000] <cardona507>
night Lachy

[05:40:00.0000] <Utkarsh>
I had a question. If I need to group several <article> with a parent element, should I use <section>?

[05:54:00.0000] <webben>
Utkarsh: Depends.

[05:55:00.0000] <webben>
Utkarsh: What is the relationship between the articles?

[05:59:00.0000] <Utkarsh>
well, I'm laying out the frontpage of a blog. I saw one site enclosing all the <article> in a section. I had earlier used a div#container for this.

[06:29:00.0000] <webben>
Utkarsh: I think "div" remains most appropriate for that.

[06:29:01.0000] <webben>
Utkarsh: "A general rule is that the section element is appropriate only if the element's contents would be listed explicitly in the document's outline."

[06:30:00.0000] <webben>
Utkarsh: the grouping of articles on the frontpage of the blog doesn't seem like it would normally get a distinct entry in the document's outline.

[06:31:00.0000] <webben>
Utkarsh: See also the example for the 'nav' element: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/sections.html#the-nav-element

[06:32:00.0000] <_Utkarsh>
webben: ah, I think using a div would be more appropriate then, they've used that in the example too

[11:20:00.0000] <karlcow>

[11:30:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[03:06:00.0000] <Hixie>

[03:08:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I think the answer to that should be that they don't assert that they're valid HTML4

[03:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
these were examples where there was first the source, then the example literally in the spec so you could see what it looked like

[03:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
i just removed the second part and left the source

[03:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. search for "gross margin table"

[03:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
that <table> uses the HTML5-suggested "<tfoot>-comes-last" markup style

[03:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
so i left the markup but hid the actual table

[03:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah tfoot

[03:10:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[07:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: "invalid" and "no effect" are orthogonal - you'd have to say both if you mean both

[07:53:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
kk

[07:53:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the spec normally says "MUST NOT" rather than "invalid" but people will get what you mean

[07:53:03.0000] <gsnedders>
Right, yeah. Great.

[07:54:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[07:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[07:56:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[09:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:37:00.0000] <daedb>
<figurecaption> is too long imo. I'd prefer <fcaption> over <figcaption> for length reasons too, but I could live with both.

[13:37:01.0000] <jgraham>

[13:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[13:52:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Then again, if I go suggest in a while the idea Hixie and I were discussing, I could just write ::wrap(dlabel+*), and get a pseudoelement wrapping everything below the dlabel.

[13:52:02.0000] <Lachy>
oh, that's a nice idea

[13:53:00.0000] <Lachy>
would it wrap all groups of consecutive elements that match the selector?

[13:53:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(The idea is that you could specify one or two selectors, detailing the first and after-the-last element.)

[13:53:02.0000] <daedb>
::wrap(dlabel~*)?

[13:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, frex, to get a section pseudo (when using implicit sectioning), ::wrap(h1,h1) would do it.  Similarly ::wrap(h2,:matches(h1,h2)) for the lower ones.  Though that should probably be a built-in pseudo anyway.

[13:56:00.0000] <Lachy>
TabAtkins, that wouldn't quite work if you described it properly, since the second h1 would be wrapped by the pseudo-section, where as you likely want the wrap to stop before it

[13:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, the second selector picks the after-the-end element.

[13:56:02.0000] <Lachy>
also, you'd end up with weird overlapping wraps

[13:56:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
So it would, indeed, stop just before the next h1.

[13:56:04.0000] <Lachy>
oh. I misunderstand what you meant by after-the-end

[13:56:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
Np.  I'll be more precise when I actually suggest it.

[13:57:00.0000] <Lachy>
I though you meant the wrap would begin at the start element and then continue until the end element, inclusive

[13:57:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's what I thought at first, but it's overly hard to specify the end properly in a lot of common cases.

[13:58:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
While with this, you can either specify after-the-end, or if you have an easy way to refer to the last element that should be in the group, just give "elem + *" as the second selector.

[13:59:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
And, obviously, specifying only one selector like I did for the dlabel bit means that it should envelop all following siblings of the selected element.

[14:01:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
There's just some oddities with being able to specify overlapping ::wrap()s that I need to resolve, probably in whatever way we decide to resolve overlapping ::text()s.

[14:53:01.0000] <Lachy>

[14:53:02.0000] <Lachy>

[14:54:00.0000] <Lachy>

[15:09:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, your selector would tend to misnest.  I don't see any way you could sensibly define things like padding in general if you have <table><th><h1>...</h1>...</table><p>...<h1>...</h1> and you try to wrap everything between the h1's.

[15:09:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, foo + * won't work if foo is the last child of its parent.

[15:09:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm confused by your first statement, Aryeh.

[15:09:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
And yes it will - at most, it will wrap to the end of its parent.

[15:10:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Oh, wait, now I see what you mean.

[15:10:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, take my HTML snippet.  What does ::wrap(h1, h1) { padding: 1em } do?  What box gets the padding?  Your ::wrap includes some children of one block, then a sibling of that block.

[15:10:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Nah, it explicitly doesn't jump between generation boundaries.  (I didn't state that before, but it's part of the proposal in my head.)

[15:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So in this case it would do nothing.

[15:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Because we have <th><h1>...</h1></th>.

[15:11:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It would just select the h1.

[15:11:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes, it would wrap the <h1> only there.

[15:11:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
And foo + * just won't match anything if foo has no next sibling, as a normal selector.

[15:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I assume ::wrap(squozzle, fooble) wraps nothing if there's no fooble element in the document.

[15:12:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
But if you had <h1>foo</h1><table><th><h1>bar</h1></table><h1>baz</h1>, it would generate two wrapping pseudos at the top level, and one inside the th

[15:12:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
That sounds unexpected.

[15:12:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
The foo+* where foo has no next sibling works as expected - if the second selector is missing or matches nothing, it just wraps to the end of the first selector's parent box.

[15:12:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me has thought about this problem a bit for MediaWiki, from the perspective of auto-adding divs around sections, but it's pretty hairy if there's any nesting

[15:12:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Ah, I see.

[15:12:06.0000] <TabAtkins>
And yes, ::wrap(sqozzle, fooble) wouldn't do anything.

[15:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The first selector has to match something for it to work at all.

[15:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Wait, wouldn't ::wrap(squozzle, fooble) wrap around each squozzle element and all its subsequent siblings, if there's no fooble element?

[15:13:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[15:13:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I think I get it now, then.

[15:13:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
kk

[15:13:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
It will break horribly if you have any kind of nesting, but oh well.

[15:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It won't break.  It just won't generate pseudos like you expect.

[15:15:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The main problem is this:  <b>foo</b> <i>bar</i> <b>baz</b> <i>qux</i>, ::wrap(b,b) {} ::wrap(i,i) {}

[15:15:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That'll attempt to create overlapping wrapping pseudos, which is no good.

[15:15:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's a much bigger problem, yes.

[15:15:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
But I believe that we can resolve this with whatever we decide is appropriate for the same situation in the ::text() pseudo.

[15:15:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
I got the impression ::text() wasn't going anywhere.

[15:16:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Nah, I'll be revisiting it in a bit.  I'm pretty attached to the functionality.

[15:16:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And the two authors of the group (me and Brad) both feel very strongly about it, so as long as we can get the implementors to grudgingly accept it, we should be golden.

[15:16:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That just involves resolving all the ambiguities, and ensuring that it's not too expensive to match.

[15:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
"just"

[15:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I think the point that it ties together style and content too tightly is pretty compelling.

[15:19:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think the argument that simple page transformations are unreasonably useful is pretty compelling.  ^_^

[15:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
::text does indeed tie to content pretty tightly, but the current solution, where you wrap the content in <span>s according to the styling you want, is just as bad, it's just putting the problem in the HTML rather than the CSS.

[15:20:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
::wrap wouldn't be as tightly tied, since at least it just selects on the same things as normal CSS.

[15:23:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The fact is, there simply isn't a generic declarative solution for complex prettifying of arbitrary content short of AI, and I think we're still pretty far from "page-style: make-it-pretty;".

[15:23:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So style is fated to intertwine with content at least somewhat in some situations, just as behavior twines with content and style in js.

[15:24:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Heh, page-visual-template: url(foo.pdf);

[15:28:00.0000] <Lachy>
TabAtkins, what's this page-visual-template property?

[15:28:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
A pretend property implemented by AI, which takes a pdf and styles the page accordingly.

[15:38:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[15:38:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[15:39:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[05:47:00.0000] <zcorpan__>

[05:50:00.0000] <Philip`>

[05:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
but you'd have to use lots of triangles

[07:13:00.0000] <Lachy>
text/sandboxed-html doesn't seem to have very nice graceful degradation.

[07:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess you could retrieve that, retrieve the wikitext, and slice out the bytes given.  If you want it to be HTML, you can then feed that back to the parser.  Of course, that will give weird results if any tags straddle sections.

[07:14:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The person to ask in RoanKattouw, he's the API guy, but he seems not to be on IRC right now.

[07:15:00.0000] <Lachy>
I assume that's probably considered a feature that current UAs won't accidentally interpret the HTML, but Firefox popping up a save dialog to users isn't very nice.

[07:15:01.0000] <Lachy>
Safari seems to have the best fallback, which is to treat it as text/plain

[07:16:00.0000] <Philip`>
If your site wants to work in legacy browsers without exposing those users to XSS attacks, the site will have to sanitise the HTML anyway before it can be used in <iframe sandbox>

[07:17:00.0000] <Philip`>
in which case serving the same content as standalone text/html to legacy browsers wouldn't introduce any new dangers

[07:17:01.0000] <Philip`>
It only makes a difference for sandbox-supporting browsers, where the sandbox layer of defence would be lost if the content was accessed outside of its iframe

[07:17:02.0000] <Lachy>
yeah, I realise that. I'm just concerned that this will limit adoption among sites, since they usually need to maintain compat with older browsers for a few years after they've been made obsolete

[07:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
So I guess something like text/html;sandbox=1 would be better because it will work in legacy browsers without introducing new vulnerabilities, and will allow sandbox-supporting browsers to apply extra defences to it

[07:18:01.0000] <Lachy>
and I don't know any site that would want users to inadvertently save the file and then possibly open it wondering what it is

[07:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
(But, on the other hand, people will add ;sandbox=1 to all their pages before anyone's released a sandbox-supporting browser, and therefore prevent it ever being supported)

[07:20:00.0000] <Lachy>
Perhaps sites will resort to some sort of browser sniffing to determine whether or not text/sandboxed-html is supported

[00:30:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[00:31:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[00:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:36:00.0000] <tantekc>

[00:36:01.0000] <Hixie>

[00:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:37:01.0000] <tantekc>

[00:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i was refering more to someone saying "i think we should do a, not b, because z" one day and "i think we should do c, not d, because not-z" the next

[00:38:01.0000] <tantekc>
othermaciej - yes, argument from authority is perhaps a weak/indirect form of evidence ("experience" or "expertise") but is both better than nothing / novice opinion, and certainly better than ad hominem or other logically flawed attacks.

[00:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: though "i don't have to defend my position, but i will object to the hilt your suggestion that i may be wrong, and i think your arguments are irrelevant" is equally abusive, imho

[00:39:01.0000] <othermaciej>
however saying something like "I don't have to answer your reasoned arguments because I am the top expert in the field" would be a bad form of argument from authority

[00:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: since it precludes compromises from being derived

[00:40:01.0000] <Hixie>

[00:40:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:40:03.0000] <zcorpan__>

[00:41:03.0000] <Hixie>

[00:42:00.0000] <Hixie>

[00:42:01.0000] <Hixie>

[00:46:01.0000] <hsivonen>
the main problem with not compromising is that under a "can you live with it" regime, other people who normally would compromise have to also adopt an uncompromising line, because otherwise those who don't budge get their way over and over again

[00:46:02.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: i'm not talking about compromising really but about finding solutions that are equally good for you, but also good for others

[00:46:03.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: I don't entirely buy into "can you live with it" as the standard for anything but truly bikeshed-type issues

[00:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: e.g. if someone wants a rail bridge and someone else wants a car ferry, it may be that a car/rail bridge would equally please both camps -- depends on their reasons

[00:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: or it could be that a tunnel would be a solution

[00:47:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: depends if the reasons are "has to carry cars" or "has to not be ugly" or "has to support freight" or "has to support tourist passenger rail cars"

[00:48:01.0000] <othermaciej>
in fact the W3C process specifically says you can't halt progress just by saying you cannot live with a decision

[01:03:00.0000] <roc>

[01:03:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it sucks that it fires on initial load because:

[01:03:02.0000] <Philip`>
tantek: It wasn't effective since it didn't cause error messages in browsers

[01:03:03.0000] <jgraham>
I think my primary objection to <div> is that it does nothing for readability. It seems like a shame to design in a patern where a <div> will likely be used more often than not

[01:03:04.0000] <zcorpan__>
othermaciej: it's not impossible to change if changing it doesn't break sites

[01:04:00.0000] <tantek>
only effective in making a point about the ridiculousness of draconianism

[01:04:01.0000] <othermaciej>
a) it makes it awkward to do reinitialization that should only be done when restoring from page cache; you have to record manually whether it fired once before

[01:04:02.0000] <othermaciej>
b) you can't use pageshow as your sole event even for first-time init anyway; you have to use load for browsers that don't (yet) have pageshow

[01:04:03.0000] <Hixie>
jgraham: if that becomes the case we can always add a different kind of <div> later

[01:04:04.0000] <Hixie>
jgraham: as we did with <Section>

[01:04:05.0000] <Philip`>
tantek: I think the point is more about the problems of output validation being stricter than input validation

[01:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's okay if they're both equally strict

[01:05:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and if first-time init and restore share some but not all code, it's much easier to call one function from two event handlers than to make one event handler behave differently depending on if it has been invoked before

[01:05:02.0000] <Philip`>
but XML is stricter than everybody's input validation

[01:05:03.0000] <othermaciej>
zcorpan__: sites use it - I don't know how much they depend on the Gecko semantic

[01:05:04.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:05:06.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:05:07.0000] <tantek>

[05:58:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Does XBL2 require the binding files to be loaded synchronously?

[06:10:00.0000] <Lachy>
hsivonen, from memory, I don't believe so.

[06:10:01.0000] <Lachy>
oh, wait. Maybe it does.

[06:10:02.0000] <hsivonen>
XBL1 seems to be implemented with a synchronous load, which seems undesirable

[06:11:00.0000] <Lachy>
if it wasn't syncronous, then that would make it difficult to bind events like load and pageshow to iframes using it, since you couldn't depend on the XBL being loaded before those events fired

[06:12:00.0000] <zcorpan>
maybe you could have an event fired when bindings are applied

[06:12:01.0000] <zcorpan>
or maybe xbl should delay the load event

[06:12:02.0000] <zcorpan>
or both

[06:35:00.0000] <Lachy>
the other problem with async techniques is that since load time is often faster in local testing environments, authors may depend on bindings being loaded before something else in the page, even though that may not turn out to be the case in real world conditions.

[06:35:01.0000] <Lachy>
this issue occurred with stylesheets, where authors have scripts depending on element styles being set by stylesheets earlier in the page

[06:37:00.0000] <Lachy>
althogh, syncronous processing sucks for incremental loading. Maybe the best solution would be to delay events until after bindings have been loaded

[06:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: Like how the load event gets delayed by things, so everyone uses domcontentloaded or runs directly from a <script> at the end of a document to avoid the delay?

[06:54:00.0000] <Lachy>
yeah

[08:16:03.0000] <tantek>
Philip`, TabAtkins - "detractor performant" means the person is a detractor (disagrees with a technology, which in itself isn't necessarily a bad thing, if they're constructive), and is a performant (is "acting out", trying to gain attention, etc.) - both of which specific types of trolls do

[08:16:04.0000] <daedb>

[08:19:01.0000] <workmad3>

[08:19:02.0000] <Philip`>
My dictionary says "A person who performs a duty, ceremony, etc., a performer."

[08:19:03.0000] <Philip`>
which is not the same as an acting kind of performer

[08:20:00.0000] <tantek>
the point is that such individuals, whether intentionally or not, are more destructive than constructive toward the development of an open community based technology, either intentionally so, or unintentionally, but likely with disregard for such, and often paired with craving more attention/recognition/ego-boosting.

[08:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Where was this strange and/or novel phrase used?

[08:20:02.0000] <tantek>
if you can recognize the pattern, and recognize that it is harmful to the development of the technology (and the community), then you can take action to prevent further damange

[08:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'd still have just used "troll".  Unintentional trolls are no less trolls.

[08:21:01.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - in my comment on Andy Clarke's blog post.

[08:22:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:22:01.0000] <karlcow>

[08:23:00.0000] <Philip`>

[08:23:01.0000] <Philip`>

[08:23:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I think the problem is that the whole Change Proposal thing is too lengthy and complicated.

[08:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Mainly because it tries to appear equitable.

[08:24:01.0000] <karlcow>
Philip`: I do not believe into that. it is an attempt at Universalism

[08:24:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:24:03.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - AFAICT, the whole Change Proposal thing is designed to slow down and discourage spec feedback filibustering

[08:24:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
If we had, say, a quick vote of a small group of actual members in the event of dispute, like I guess happens in most WGs, there would be no problem.

[08:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
tantek, it makes it harder to raise formal complaints, but also harder to address them.

[08:25:01.0000] <tantek>
it's a mechanism designed to cope with the aforementioned "trolling"

[08:25:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it prevents you from spamming the group with blockers

[08:25:03.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - agreed

[08:25:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
The problem is when they're being raised by people who seem to have unlimited time to pursue their agenda, and addressed by people who have actual work to do.

[08:25:05.0000] <othermaciej>
to get something to be a blocker you have to do a bunch of work

[08:25:06.0000] <othermaciej>
then the group has to do work in response

[08:25:07.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hrm.  These google results seem likely virus-filled.  Anyone got a suggestion for a reliable swf-to-flv converter?

[08:25:08.0000] <othermaciej>
the way it is set up has enough credibility that decisions can stand and remove blockers

[08:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But the ones doing work in response are mostly people like browser developers who could more productively be, e.g., implementing the spec and providing sound feedback.

[08:26:01.0000] <tantek>
IMHO much better to admit that negative contributors exist, and kick them out per a community guidelines policy, than introduce more bureaucracy to deal with them slowly and painful with everyone else involved.

[08:26:02.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: Is that even possible?

[08:26:03.0000] <othermaciej>
it's true that voting is another potential decision mechanism that could have perceived legitimacy

[08:26:04.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:26:05.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor: "The problem is when they're being raised by people who seem to have unlimited time to pursue their agenda, and addressed by people who have actual work to do."  <---- exactly

[08:26:06.0000] <tantek>
hence, filibustering

[08:26:07.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: (I thought SWF was a lossy optimised format, so you couldn't reverse it decently in general)

[08:26:08.0000] <othermaciej>

[08:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
