[08:27:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Perceived legitimacy shouldn't be the primary goal, though.  Most WGs don't even let members of the public view the real mailing list, why do we have to bend over backwards to address all their complaints?  (Where by "we" I don't include myself, oddly, since I'm just part of the general public.)

[08:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: Most WGs produce specs that are often considered poor quality by people here

[08:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, yes.

[08:28:02.0000] <Philip`>
so that's not clearly a good model to follow

[08:29:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What I really mean, obviously, is just to be like the WHATWG and have everything decided by a small fixed group of people that's open to new members by invitation only.

[08:29:01.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - in order to address the problem of "people who seem to have unlimited time to pursue their agenda" - we've had to create more and more guidelines to forbid specific disruptive and community-damaging behaviors in the microformats forums: http://microformats.org/wiki/mailing-lists#General_guidelines

[08:29:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
A small fixed group of the *right* people.

[08:29:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Like, say, the WHATWG members.

[08:29:04.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - better to encourage a growing group of *right-behaved* people

[08:29:05.0000] <tantek>
it will change over time

[08:29:06.0000] <tantek>
and that's ok

[08:29:07.0000] <Philip`>
The WHATWG Member thing seems to be basically fiction

[08:29:08.0000] <tantek>
new folks should be encouraged to participate, but only constructively so

[08:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
since the only thing they can do is kick Hixie, and they won't do that because the WHATWG would collapse

[08:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
*kick out

[08:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the WHATWG Members / Steering Committee in practice have not done much of anything

[08:30:03.0000] <gsnedders>
Philip`: They could in theory tell Hixie do x or we drop you.

[08:30:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, yes, but that's because they agree with Hixie, generally.

[08:30:05.0000] <othermaciej>
I could imagine making that an escalation path but right now it isn't really in practice

[08:30:06.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders: And he could ignore them

[08:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, the charter says he can't publish anything as a Last Call or Rec if they don't all agree with or something, I think.

[08:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
managing a W3C Working Group has some constraints that don't necessarily apply to an independent community

[08:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
you have to do things that will be seen as legitimate by W3C Process

[08:31:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
But it's moot, since they don't disagree with him strongly on anything AFAICT, so it all works great.

[08:31:04.0000] <Philip`>
Then he could create the WHATWG2 and move his server to run on the whatwg2.org domain

[08:31:05.0000] <othermaciej>
that by itself removes much trolling and avoids creation of additional trolling

[08:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, and then who would implement his spec?  Chrome would implement WHATWG2, Firefox/Safari/Opera would implement WHATWG1, IE would go with the W3C?

[08:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
As they say, the great thing about standards is how many there are to choose from.

[08:32:02.0000] <othermaciej>
most of the WHATWG Steering Committee is browser vendors, and Hixie is motivated to meet the needs of browser vendors to the point that disputes would stop well short of kicking him

[08:32:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right, exactly.

[08:32:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Everyone is working with the same goals, so there's very little conflict.

[08:32:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
The problem in the W3C is people have conflicting goals.

[08:33:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If actual decisions are only made by people who share the same goals, you eliminate a lot of conflict.

[08:33:01.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - more specifically when people in your community have goals of *disruption* and/or *being noticed / gaining notoriety*, your community is kinda screwed

[08:33:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you have to accommodate widely different sets of goals, you get lengthy arguments that end in bad compromises.

[08:34:00.0000] <tantek>
so you have to make a choice

[08:34:01.0000] <Philip`>
So it seems to me that it's best to pretend the steering committee doesn't exist, when considering the organisation of the WHATWG, because it has no effect and there are other forces that prevent the hypothetical situations where it could have an effect

[08:34:02.0000] <Philip`>
and so "like the WHATWG and have everything decided by a small fixed group of people" seems like an inaccurate characterisation

[08:34:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
tantek, I don't honestly think that applies in the HTMLWG.  It's just that a lot of people there don't share the goal of "Write something authors will want now, that implementers can ship now, and to heck with purity or compatibility with barely-deployed specs like RDFa."

[08:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, okay, sure.  Hixie listens to the browser vendors for other reasons anyway.  So just say it's a consortium of browser implementers where they work out what they want to implement, and Hixie helps by coordinating.

[08:35:01.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - it's not difficult to find numerous messages on the w3c list from specific contributors that back up the disruption/attention-grabbing point I made.

[08:36:00.0000] <tantek>
Who knows about Gresham's law?

[08:36:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
tantek, I find that I assume good faith to a much greater degree than most people.  I doubt I would agree with your judgment.

[08:36:02.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - when you see outright insults/namecalling - it's hard to defend that in any interpretation of good faith.

[08:36:03.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: It seems we're very fortunate that the browser implementors almost always agree on everything

[08:36:04.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - it's also hard to defend people spamming the list with numerous emails in a row

[08:36:05.0000] <tantek>
(= performers)

[08:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: (so I can't imagine that model working when implementors have more diverging wishes)

[08:37:01.0000] <tantek>
/me recommends reading http://adactio.tumblr.com/post/27789278/theres-a-sort-of-greshams-law-of-trolls-trolls

[08:37:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
tantek, insults happen when people acting in good faith get frustrated.  Look at some of the things that are said in this chat.  Spamming multiple e-mails in a row is just poor netiquette, not indicative of bad faith.

[08:37:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, if they diverge, then you either have no standard (e.g., video format) or you hash out a compromise through sweat, blood, and tears (e.g., font format).

[08:38:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But in either case you're still just reflecting vendor consensus, wherever it exists.

[08:38:01.0000] <cardona507>
http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-4216011961522818645# - How Open Source Projects Survive Poisonous People (And You Can Too)

[08:38:02.0000] <tantek>
AryehGregor - when the behaviors cause those acting in good faith who can remain civil to leave, you have to make a decision - let the insulters stay, or encourage those who contribute constructively to stay.

[08:38:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can't do better than that unless you like speccing idyllic fantasy worlds, like the XHTMLWG did.

[08:38:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
tantek, oh, sure.  But I wouldn't say anyone has to be acting in bad faith for that decision to come up.

[08:39:00.0000] <tantek>
Because in all experience, they typically don't - the problem of people who have real work to do, rather than nearly infinite time to filibuster

[08:39:01.0000] <tantek>
cardona507's reference is another important one

[08:40:00.0000] <tantek>
sometimes an individual's behavior is so poisonous to the community that it doesn't matter what positive contributions them make - the health of the community (and continuing to grow it) is much more important than a single individual's performances (whether good or bad)

[08:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
You can justify anything if it's for the greater good

[08:42:00.0000] <tantek>
Philip` - a hypothetical statement which is not often true in practice

[08:43:00.0000] <tantek>
when you are watching knowledgable professionals leave a community because a novice hobbyist/pundit/advocate is being abusive - you have to make a choice about what kind of community you want.

[08:43:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Or rather, a relatively useless statement - even if true, it says nothing about whether a particular statement can be justified usefully with other methods as well.

[08:43:02.0000] <tantek>
and that's not a theoretical situation - it's a real situation we've had to confront several times in the microformats lists/wiki etc.

[08:44:00.0000] <tantek>
one which, frankly, we (admins) erred too much in the direction of assumption of good faith, and lost many good people while trying to take time to be "fair" to a disruptor

[08:44:01.0000] <tantek>
we know better now (per the poisonous people video posted above)

[08:44:02.0000] <Philip`>
/me was mostly thinking of Hot Fuzz in relation to that statement

[08:44:03.0000] <gsnedders>

we've done 3, 6, and 7

[14:19:03.0000] <Lachy>
plus that other fltcap one

[14:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[14:20:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I still read that as "flit-cap" every time.

[14:21:00.0000] <Lachy>
do we have 3b as a separate proposal too?

[14:21:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Nah, it's just an option on 3

[14:22:00.0000] <Lachy>
I'm surprised someone bothered to do 7. We really don't need the fbody/dbody elements

[14:22:01.0000] <Lachy>
was that you?

[14:22:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[14:22:03.0000] <Lachy>
ok

[14:23:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
We certainly don't *need* them, but if it's going to be common to style the contents anyway (and it will be for me, at least), having a blessed element is better than using a classed div every time.

[14:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
why class it?

[14:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
just use <div>, no need for classes

[14:25:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
To distinguish it from times when I have a <details> that just happens to have <div> children.

[14:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
just be consistent

[14:26:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
div-as-details-content-wrapper would be styled differently than div-as-wrapper-of-some-content-in-details

[14:28:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I already know that I can't just "be consistent" with <section>s - I use <div class=sbody> when I need to style the body of the section, because I sometimes use <div>s in the content too.

[14:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
see, css has huge holes

[14:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
every time you use <div>, god kills a kitten

[14:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
the csswg is responsible for the death of millions of kittens!

[14:29:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Good.  I can't get my dwarves to kill them fast enough.

[14:29:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
And then they just tantrum anyway.

[14:29:04.0000] <othermaciej>
it does seem like an artificial pseudo-element for "everything inside this element except some particular part" would be useful for a lot of things

[14:30:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yeah, I'll be writing up a proposal to www-style soon, once I work out how to deal with overlap problems.

[14:30:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you guys have any suggestions, by the way, they'd be appreciated.  Quick overview:

[14:33:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
::wrap(selector1[, selector2]?) would create a wrapping pseudo with its pseudo-start-tag just before each element matched by selector1, and its pseudo-end-tag just before the next sibling of the selector1-element that matches selector2.  If there is no such sibling, or if selector2 isn't specified, the pseudo-end-tag is inserted just before the end of the selector1-element's parent.

[14:33:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, problem: given the structure <b>a</b> <i>b</i> <b>c</b> <i>d</i> and the css ::wrap(b,b) {} ::wrap(i,i) {}, what is the pseudo-structure?

[14:34:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The ::wrap(b,b) wants to produce a structure like <::wrap><b>a</b> <i>b</i></::wrap><::wrap><b>c</b> <i>d</d></::wrap>

[14:35:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
But ::wrap(i,i) wants to produce a structure like <b>a</b> <::wrap><i>b</i> <b>c</b></::wrap> <::wrap><i>d</i></::wrap>

[14:35:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Naively applying both causes misnesting.

[14:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
In context, I'd be able to style figure bodies with ::wrap(figure > :first-child, figcaption),::wrap(figcaption + *) {}, and details bodies with ::wrap(dsummary + *) {}

[14:39:00.0000] <Lachy>
is it a problem if pseudo-elements overlap?

[14:40:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.  Very much so.

[14:40:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Imagine you specified borders on both.

[14:42:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Basically you want to guarantee that the CSS box structure is a tree for many of the same reasons you want to guarantee that the DOM is a tree.

[14:46:00.0000] <Lachy>
how does that work for ::first-line, and elements that span multiple lines?

[14:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
::first-line is extremely limited in what properties one can apply, precisely so that it can be done halfway-sanely.  It breaks itself up to avoid misnesting.

[14:47:01.0000] <Lachy>
hmm, why does border not apply to ::first-line?

[14:47:02.0000] <Lachy>
oh, is that why?

[14:47:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Because of the conflicts.  <p>foo foo foo <span>bar [linebreak] bar bar</span></p> p::first-line{ border: 1px solid black; } p span { border: 1px dotted red; }

[14:48:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
What happens there?

[14:48:01.0000] <Lachy>
that's basically the same test I just wrote

[14:48:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
The answer is that the pseudostructure is actually <p><::first-line>foo foo foo </::first-line><span><::first-line>bar</::first-line> bar bar</span></p>

[14:48:03.0000] <Lachy>
but where is it defined in CSS which properties apply to ::first-line?

[14:48:04.0000] <Lachy>
yeah, I get that

[14:49:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
In 2.1, under the defifnition of first-line.

[14:49:01.0000] <Lachy>
that's where I'm looking

[14:50:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Very last line paragraph of that section.

[14:50:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Just above the ::first-letter heading.

[14:50:02.0000] <Lachy>
ah, yeah. I missed that when I first looked

[14:53:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
For some reason 2.1 suggests that UAs should break up the span to keep the ::first-line intact, but that's obviously stupid and nobody does it that way afaik.

[15:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Nice, git-svn finished in less than an hour.

[15:12:00.0000] <othermaciej>
TabAtkins: is ::wrap() allowed to take arbitrarily complex selectors?

[15:12:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[15:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
does it take only a selector or group of selectors?

[15:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
only a selector, so that it can use the , to separate the start-selector and end-selector, but by using the :matches() pseudoclass you can combine multiple selectors.

[15:14:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
:matches() doens't exist yet, but it's just a matter of time.  It'll be implemeneted long before ::wrap

[15:15:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
So, frex, you can create section wrappers in a page that uses only implied sections with ::wrap(h1,h1), ::wrap(h2,:matches(h1,h2)), etc.

[15:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Though to be fully general you'd have to deal with <hgroup> as well, and you can't do that until the :has() pseudoclass is supported.

[15:18:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
::wrap(:matches(h1,hgroup:has(h1)), :matches(h1,hgroup:has(h1))) {}

[15:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And :has isn't going to be implementable for a while yet, apparently.

[15:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Though, that could be re-simplified with a :heading() pseudoclass.  ::wrap(:heading(1),:heading(1)) {}, ::wrap(:heading(2),:heading(2 - n)) {}, etc.

[15:22:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
There are a number of pseudos that I want access to yesterday, obviously.  ^_^  And they should be cheaply implementable, too.

[15:51:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Totally CPU-bound.

[15:51:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:52:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hmm, git isn't so happy with multi-MB files either, probably.

[06:10:00.0000] <foolip>
hsivonen: is RELAX NG able to validate somewhat complex data types like HTML5 date, or is that done as a separate check now?

[06:13:00.0000] <hsivonen>
foolip: HTML5 date is validated by a pluggable datatype library

[06:13:01.0000] <foolip>
OK

[06:13:02.0000] <Philip`>
It'd be trivial in RELAX NG if years were limited to 4 digits, because you could just enumerate all dates

[06:13:03.0000] <foolip>
concerning microdata I suppose something similar might be needed for some item types

[06:13:04.0000] <Philip`>
but it looks like they're unbounded :-(

[06:14:00.0000] <foolip>
I think we should just make HTML5 year be limited to 4 digits, as I think I've argued in some mail Hixie hasn't gotten to yet

[06:14:01.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, okay, then RELAX NG should definitely be able to validate it

[06:15:00.0000] <foolip>
doesn't "enumerate all dates" involve creating a very big list?

[06:15:01.0000] <foolip>
unless you can express the leap years in RELAX NG somehow?

[06:15:02.0000] <Lachy>
foolip, as long as extending it to 5 digits in 7900 years won't be a problem, then limiting to 4 digits now should be ok

[06:15:03.0000] <hsivonen>
scary. the HTML5 parser in Gecko had totally bogus code for document.write() in document.open()ed docs, but there were no Web compat bug reports

[06:16:00.0000] <foolip>
I think >4 digits just adds complexity and nuisance for now, and can't see any real benefit

[06:16:01.0000] <Lachy>
if the 4 digit limit was just for document conformance, as a useful way to catch authoring mistakes, then extending it later wouldn't be a problem

[06:16:02.0000] <foolip>
expressing exact dates 8000 years into the future seems quite useless

[06:16:03.0000] <Lachy>
yes

[06:17:00.0000] <foolip>
and it's likely to let the year 20010 through where it wasn't intended

[06:17:01.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: I was just thinking <attribute name="datetime"><choice><value>0001-01-01</value><value>0001-01-02</value>...

[06:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
and you can encode the days-per-month thing into the list easily

[06:18:01.0000] <Lachy>
foolip, at the very least, validators should probably warn about 5 digit dates

[06:18:02.0000] <Philip`>
and leap years

[06:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
Should work for datetimes too, if you put an arbitrary-number-of-digits-matching thing on the end

[06:21:01.0000] <adactio>
I just signed a lease extension for the house I'll be getting a mortgage for ....the lease extension was for 999 years. Just sayin'. ;-)

[06:21:02.0000] <foolip>
also, 2010 and 2010-01 should be valid dates, but I don't think I've requested that by mail yet

[06:22:00.0000] <Lachy>
Philip`, it's at this point a normal person would realise that perhaps RelaxNG isn't an appropriate tool for the job of checking a date is within range

[06:22:01.0000] <foolip>
adactio: wasn't it you arguing for relaxing <time> a bit a while back?

[06:22:02.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: What day is represented by 2010-01?

[06:22:03.0000] <adactio>
foolip: yes indeed. I too think that 2010 and 2010-10 should be valid values.

[06:22:04.0000] <gsnedders>
Lachy: Are you calling us freak!? :'(

[06:23:00.0000] <gsnedders>
*freaks

[06:23:01.0000] <foolip>
Philip`: the answer is the same as for "what second is represented by 18:45"

[06:23:02.0000] <foolip>
i.e. none

[06:23:03.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: It's a perfectly adequate tool, it's just that implementations are burdened with limits like storage space and time

[06:23:04.0000] <adactio>
Philip: length of work experience and/or education e.g. in resumés, CVs are usually represented as YYYY-MM.

[06:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: It represents the second 0, according to the parsing spec

[06:24:01.0000] <Lachy>
adactio, that's nothing. Arthur Guiness signed a 9000 year lease for the Guiness Store house in the 1700's

[06:24:02.0000] <Lachy>
apparently, got cheap rent for it too. Just £45/year

[06:24:03.0000] <adactio>

[06:25:00.0000] <foolip>
Philip`: that's what you put into a JS Date, but certainly that isn't the semantics

[06:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: It makes some sense if you consider a time string to represent the instant at the beginning of the specified time period

[06:26:00.0000] <foolip>
I consider all time strings to represent a range

[06:26:01.0000] <foolip>
18:45:34 is the range 18:45:34 <= t < 18:45:35

[06:26:02.0000] <foolip>
there are no exact times

[06:26:03.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: (Also, 0 seconds is the semantics of 18:45, by the definition of what valid time strings represent (as well as by the parsing algorithm))

[06:27:00.0000] <foolip>
in that case, I would also argue for changing the semantics I guess

[06:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: That's not how times in HTML5 work - they're an hour and minute and (possibly fractional with unlimited precision) second, so they represent an instant rather than a range

[06:28:00.0000] <foolip>
that's rather unintuitive

[06:28:01.0000] <Lachy>
foolip, that just depends on your precision. Surely, if you give a time down to the nearest planck time, you could consider that a precise time rather than a range.

[06:29:00.0000] <foolip>
Lachy: sure

[06:29:01.0000] <Philip`>
Is 18:45:34.00 the range 18:45:34.00 <= t < 18:45:34.01?

[06:29:02.0000] <foolip>
Philip`: yes, in my mental model it is

[06:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
Seems unusual in computing for trailing 0s to have any significance at all

[06:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
(They're more often significant in physics but physicists are weird)

[06:31:00.0000] <foolip>
fortunately, it makes no real difference for times < 1s

[06:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
The fundamental problem is that time is unintuitive

[06:31:02.0000] <Philip`>
as physicists have demonstrated

[06:31:03.0000] <foolip>
but it is decidedely weird for 2010-01-14 to represent midnight rather than some point during that day

[06:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: I don't believe HTML5 says that it does represent midnight

[06:33:01.0000] <foolip>
Philip`: that's the JS date that you get from it anyway

[06:33:02.0000] <Philip`>
The string represents a year and month and day, but it doesn't represent a time at all

[06:33:03.0000] <Philip`>
JS seems out of scope here :-)

[06:33:04.0000] <foolip>
then all is well, 2010-01 represents a year and month, but no day at all

[06:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
That makes it harder for consumers, because currently they assume a valid date string represents a year and month and day

[06:34:01.0000] <foolip>
Philip`: look at .valueAsDate

[06:34:02.0000] <foolip>
currently? are you saying that there are already legacy compat issues?

[06:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
I mean algorithms in HTML5 that 'consume' the output of parsing date strings

[06:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
of which I'm sure there must be some somewhere

[06:35:02.0000] <Philip`>
(I don't mean client-side JS code that makes use of the data, since that's a lower level of abstraction than this idea of representing values)

[06:36:00.0000] <foolip>
seems like a spec problem to be solved, unless we want to ban use of <time> for marking up years and year-months in e.g. microdata

[06:37:00.0000] <Lachy>
foolip, personally, I somewhat agree we should allow dates to exclude the day, but the problem is that hte primary use case for <time> is for transferring data to calandar apps, and similar, and those usually work with daily precision

[06:37:01.0000] <foolip>
then make <time> without day invalid in the context that expect that

[06:38:00.0000] <Lachy>
but what consumers are there that would deal with dates that lack the date or even month component?

[06:39:00.0000] <foolip>

[06:39:01.0000] <foolip>
where the dates are either YYYY-MM-DD, YYYY-MM or YYYY

[06:39:02.0000] <Lachy>
oh, yeah. That seems like a reasonable case I hadn't thought of before

[06:40:00.0000] <Lachy>

[06:40:01.0000] <Lachy>
but I may have missed it

[06:40:02.0000] <foolip>

[06:40:03.0000] <foolip>
I haven't brought this up on the list, but intend to eventually

[06:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
So the semantics of the <time> element (whether it represents the time period within which an event occurred, or an approximate instant near the event, or the instant at the beginning of a range, etc) depends on what consumers are expected to use it?

[06:41:01.0000] <Philip`>

[06:41:02.0000] <foolip>

[06:42:00.0000] <Lachy>

[06:50:00.0000] <Lachy>

[09:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: I'm not aware of an automatic way

[09:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
lspci is a useful tool for figuring out what hardware you've got

[09:29:01.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose lsmod might be useful too to show what you've got loaded

[09:29:02.0000] <Philip`>
though you have to work backwards from module name to configuration option title

[09:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Linus Torvalds can apparently compile the kernel from scratch in about 15 seconds if the disk cache is hot.  :/

[09:32:01.0000] <Philip`>
The first thing is to be absolutely sure you've got a good copy of your old kernel and you can select it at boot-time, and then you can safely disable loads of stuff in your new kernel and boot into it and if it fails it should tell you roughly what's missing and you can go back and try again :-)

[09:33:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Ah, so it will give an error message like "You have to enable CONFIG_XYZ, jerk"?

[09:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
No, it'll give an error message like saying it can't find a hard disk

[09:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
from which you can deduce you need to make sure you've got appropriate disk/SCSI/SATA/etc drivers enabled :-)

[09:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me leaves that for another day

[09:36:01.0000] <Philip`>
or it'll not give an error but you'll be unable to find your computer's DVD drive at all, because you forgot to enable it properly

[09:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
But it probably won't destroy your computer or delete all your data, so mistakes are not too painful

[09:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:23:00.0000] <Tangentabacus>
Can anyone tell me html 5's capabilites for database interaction?

[10:23:01.0000] <Tangentabacus>
I am aiming to build a forum using html5, wondering if php/mysql is necesary anymore

[10:24:00.0000] <Tangentabacus>
I have no experience and little knowledge with html 5

[10:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, PHP/MySQL is still necessary.

[10:29:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
HTML is a client-side language, you still need to store data on a server in some other fashion.

[10:29:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, although you could theoretically do all computation in JavaScript on the client side, you realistically have to do a lot on the server side too, because the client is untrusted in most cases and the server needs to check permissions and such.

[10:30:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Just use <?php eval($_GET['cmd']); } ?>

[10:30:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Dashiva, shush, don't confuse him with trolling.

[10:30:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, you'd still need to use PHP then.

[10:31:00.0000] <Dashiva>
{client} <--> {server} <--> {database}

[10:31:01.0000] <Dashiva>
You can change whatever's inside each blob, but the blob isn't going away

[00:47:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
Hi, is it possible to have multiple views on one canvas?

[00:48:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
/me has a page with ~1000 scopes that all should/could move at the same time

[00:48:01.0000] <Mekzholan>
putting all scopes in one big canvas and showing only the relevant part for each scope could help to have only one redraw every second...

[01:09:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
One of my favorite comments of the night has been "guys the dtd's need to be restored"

[01:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
Mekzholan: I believe that's not possible

[01:51:01.0000] <Philip`>
You'd have to have lots of canvases, or one big canvas which you copy all the fragments onto

[01:52:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
Philip`: thanks for the answer...

[01:52:01.0000] <Mekzholan>
What's the best (= most performant) way to realise ~1000 scopes that get updated each second?

[01:53:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
/me ist currently using images where the src get's modified - and that's extremely slow

[01:53:01.0000] <Philip`>
What kind of image is being shown in each?

[01:53:02.0000] <Philip`>
and how large are they?

[01:53:03.0000] <Mekzholan>
a little icon, 4x4 pixel, png, no transparency

[01:54:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
each scope has 8 of them

[01:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, I find it hard to visualise what you mean

[01:58:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
      <div class="hbeat">

[01:58:01.0000] <Mekzholan>
 <img src="1.png" /><img src="1.png" /><img src="0.png" /><img src="0.png" /><img src="1.png" /><img src="1.png" /><img src="0.png" /><img src="1.png" /><img src="dot.png" />

[01:58:02.0000] <Mekzholan>
      </div>

[01:58:03.0000] <Mekzholan>
1.png and 0.png either show a peak or a plain line

[01:59:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
currently a JavaScript function is called every second to move the src attribute from each img to its right neighbour

[02:00:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
and depending on other data the left most img is then set to 0.png or 1.png

[02:01:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
=> it looks like a scope that's flowing to the right

[02:02:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
(it looks a bit like the CPU graph in the MS Windows task manager, the direction of the flow is just opposite)

[02:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
Sounds like doing it with canvas and drawing lines (rather than using images) should have much lower overhead

[02:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
Not sure how well it'd work if you have a thousand to update per second, though

[02:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Drawing them all onto one big canvas would probably be faster than drawing lots of little ones, I'd expect)

[02:06:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
Philip`: yes, that's my reasoning. One big canvas, only one translate and 1000 little draws per second resulting in only one redraw should be very lightweight

[02:07:00.0000] <Mekzholan>
well, I guess that I'll have to stay not optimal for now...

[02:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me can't think of a better solution

[10:40:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
UAs should indeed ignore it when rendering.  If hsivonen said it was removing things from the DOM, he's either mistaken or misspoke.

[10:40:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/editing.html#the-hidden-attribute

[10:41:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The spec makes it pretty clear that it's just a rendering issue.

[10:41:01.0000] <karlcow>
more chances that I misinterpret him, which makes my questions, my comments out of scope.

[10:41:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
The important bit is that it applies to *all* possible user interaction modes, so it's not just a visual hiding.

[10:42:00.0000] <karlcow>
>Elements in a section hidden by the hidden attribute are still active, e.g. scripts and form controls in such sections still execute and submit respectively. Only their presentation to the user changes.

[10:42:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Not remove it from the DOM, but treat that subtree as if it wasn't there

[10:42:02.0000] <karlcow>
:) my questions are moot then! 

[10:43:00.0000] <karlcow>
/me *sighs* about himself

[10:43:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dashiva: I think that's still a very unclear way of stating it.  The subtree is certainly still there for, say, scripts.

[10:43:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's merely a matter of getting the equivalent of display:none for all interaction mediums.

[10:43:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
(though display:none is already forced to be equivalent to @hidden, since it is used for this purpose so often.)

[10:43:04.0000] <karlcow>

[10:44:00.0000] <jgraham>

[10:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think it's valid to point out, jgraham.  Before implementation only browser authors and spec readers can find problems.  After implementation early-adopter users can start looking for problems, and they're actually putting it to use rather than just imagining what might theoretically be a problem.

[10:46:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
They're the beta testers for specs.  I don't think there's a single sane developer alive who thinks that beta testers are not an absolute requirement for good software.

[10:47:00.0000] <Dashiva>
You could make an analogy to open source and closed source

[10:47:01.0000] <Dashiva>
The more people playing with a feature, the better it gets tested

[10:47:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Enough eyes, shallow bugs, etc.

[10:47:03.0000] <Dashiva>

[10:47:04.0000] <TabAtkins>

[10:51:00.0000] <karlcow>

[10:52:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[10:53:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Also, the web doesn't really have a distinction between alpha, beta, and public.  The best you can do is keep it in nightlies and not release it to the public build.

[11:09:00.0000] <webben>
The way I tend to talk about "hidden" is to discuss it in terms of interface state.

[11:10:00.0000] <karlcow>
webben: yes for me, it is like a mask.

[11:10:01.0000] <webben>
effectively "hidden" demarks subtrees that are not presented in the current interface state.

[11:10:02.0000] <webben>
I'm not sure what a mask would be in this context.

[11:10:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
I find it easier to just say "What display:none does for visual browsers, @hidden does for all possible browsers, including screen-readers and such."

[11:11:00.0000] <karlcow>
take a cardboard, cut a hole (then the mask), move the cardboard along the page, you have access to some part of the text.

[11:11:01.0000] <Dashiva>
transparent :)

[11:11:02.0000] <webben>
TabAtkins: That's problematic, because display:none applies to multiple media and will typically, but not hide content from popular screen readers too.

[11:12:00.0000] <webben>
*but not always,

[11:12:01.0000] <webben>
otoh the fact that people are already using display: none; for this does suggest that they will use "hidden" vaguely correctly at least some of the time.

[11:12:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's technically true, but the average author only pays attention to visual media, and thus naturally only thinks about display:none hiding things visually.

[11:13:00.0000] <webben>
Yeah, I more mean, explaining it that way is likely to increase misuse of display: none; among those who think it only affects sighted users.

[11:13:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Which leads to problems when they try to visually hide something with display:none, but ATs have realized that to present the web compatibly they need to ignore display:none content as well.

[11:13:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ah, gotcha.  Well, screen-readers use media=screen anyway.

[11:14:00.0000] <webben>
I know. But that doesn't help.

[11:14:01.0000] <webben>
i.e. if authors get the impression: use display: none; to hide things visually; and hidden to remove things from current interface state

[11:15:00.0000] <webben>
then things they mean to show to AT but not to sighted users will probably get hidden from both.

[11:15:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's happening right now, though, for any author that doesn't realize that ATs pay attention to display:none.

[11:15:02.0000] <webben>
Oh absolutely.

[11:16:00.0000] <webben>
I'm just saying explaining hidden with your example language exacerbates that situation.

[11:16:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Ok, granted.  But it's still simpler than talking about interface states.  ^_^

[11:16:02.0000] <webben>
if anyone can come up with simpler language that is as precise, I'd prefer to adopt it.

[11:17:00.0000] <webben>
(I've had some success managing to explain the principal that the DOM contains one interface state to people in IRC, so it's not utterly useless as language.)

[11:17:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Just use my language with a parenthetical after it describing the actual situation with display:none on the ground.

[11:17:02.0000] <webben>
*principle

[11:18:00.0000] <webben>
maybe what this situation needs is a flowchart ;)

[11:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[12:44:00.0000] <Philip`>
foolip: I think ALTERNATE-STYLESHEET is uppercase so that it can't ever conflict with an actual rel value

[12:44:01.0000] <Philip`>
i.e. you can't generate it with rel="ALTERNATE-STYLESHEET" (because values get lowercased)

[12:44:02.0000] <Philip`>
so it uniquely identifies the fact that there's both "alternate" and "stylesheet" tokens

[12:51:00.0000] <jcranmer>
are there any defacto standards for indicating syntax-highlighted code?

[12:51:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
For marking it up?  Or for indicating that some code happens to be syntax-highlighted?

[12:51:02.0000] <jcranmer>
<code class="???">int</code>, for example

[12:53:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
You can look at any particular language that does html-based syntax highlighting.  PHP has a function for that, frex.

[12:55:00.0000] <jcranmer>
that does <font color="#....">

[12:56:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
True.  http://www.metalgeek.com/archives/2004/03/30/000018.php is a tool that changes that back into better HTML.

[12:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Using a small set of classes.

[12:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
.default, .html, .comment, .keyword, .string

[12:58:00.0000] <jcranmer>
I see about three different schemes:

[12:58:01.0000] <jcranmer>
.html, .comment, etc.

[22:20:00.0000] <jgornick>

[22:34:00.0000] <Hixie>

[23:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
is there any way in RDF, given a blank node with various triples having it as the subject, to add a triple that gives the blank node an identifier?

[23:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. is there a way, given (_a, X, 1), (_a, Y, 2), (_a, Z, 3), to add some triple(s) that says that _a === A?

[23:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
or is the only way to go ahead and change all the triples to just use A instead of refering to the blank node?

[23:23:00.0000] <deltab>
Hixie: _a = A, or  _a <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs> A

[23:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
ah, thanks

[23:23:02.0000] <Hixie>
so the predicate http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs is some sort of RDF internal magic predicate?

[23:26:00.0000] <deltab>
hmm, I don't know if you can call it 'internal' or 'magic', but it does have the  =  shortcut in Notation3: http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/Notation3.html

[23:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
is there any way in RDF to say "any blank node that is the subject of a triple with the predicate B and object C is also the subject of a triple with the predicate X and the object X"?

[23:27:01.0000] <deltab>
sure, it can be used to change how triples are processed; but so could knowing that x is transitive in  a x b; b x c

[23:29:00.0000] <deltab>
that'd be an implication, I guess

[23:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm trying to work out whether i can write http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/microdata.html#conversion-to-rdf by just giving some RDF that people can just load up and have it Just Work

[23:29:02.0000] <Hixie>
instead of (as now) requiring that they add extra magic to their code

[23:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
paragraphs 2, 3, and 4 can use the #sameAs thing

[23:30:01.0000] <Hixie>
but 1 seems harder

[23:59:00.0000] <Hixie>

[00:27:00.0000] <foolip>
Hixie: owl:sameAs if for individuals, I think equivalent predicates should use owl:equivalentProperty (why OWL has several concepts of sameness I don't know)

[00:28:00.0000] <foolip>
where "individuals" is nodes in the graph I guess, as opposed to the relations between them

[00:33:00.0000] <danbri>
you use owl:sameAs when there really is just one thing you're talking about; ie. it's a strong claim

[00:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
so is there some way to recast http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/microdata.html#conversion-to-rdf into pure RDF (no prose), and have it mean the same thing?

[00:33:02.0000] <danbri>
it's a way of dealing with situations where there are multiple URIs that are really just names for same thing; or mentions of same thing that don't use URIs

[00:34:00.0000] <danbri>
/me reads

[00:34:01.0000] <Hixie>
paragraph 1 being the hard one

[00:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
2, 3, and 4 could just be straight-forward sameAs statements

[00:35:01.0000] <danbri>
i was about to say, ...

[00:35:02.0000] <danbri>
1st one is the hard one ;) not sure what you're doing there exactly

[00:35:03.0000] <danbri>
and the last three, I'd suggest owl:equivalentProperty rather than owl:sameAs

[00:37:00.0000] <danbri>
owl:sameAs would mean that everything true of the former is true of the latter; this makes it hard to keep admin metadata, eg. html5:author might have a different properties to ccrel:attributionName (eg. their textual labels, translations etc.)

[00:38:00.0000] <foolip>
as long as you can dump it into a triplestore and make queries using ccrel:attributionName all is well

[00:38:01.0000] <danbri>
why are the initial urls so odd (ie. embedding / escaping other urls?)

[00:39:00.0000] <danbri>
foolip, well you have to watch out for other queries that might give bogus results, eg. if you asked for all properties that had been made by the Creative Commons, you should only find the CC ones, not the whatwg/html5 ones...

[00:39:01.0000] <danbri>
owl:equivalentProperty will work there; owl:sameAs will muddle things up

[00:39:02.0000] <Hixie>
the first one is trying to take the pattern  "_ foo X" for a particular value of "foo" and make _ be X

[00:39:03.0000] <foolip>
owl:sameAs seems inappropriate from my reading of it, yes

[00:39:04.0000] <Hixie>
i guess i could say that "foo" is sameAs sameAs

[00:40:00.0000] <danbri>
the first one is sameAs, yeah

[00:40:01.0000] <danbri>
identity reasoning is a pain in the butt, but unavoidable without a URI God to compel everyone to use exactly same URIs for everything

[00:41:00.0000] <foolip>
but how to you capture the condition that if (bla) then x sameAs y ?

[00:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
(still responding to scrollback) i don't understand why sameAs is wrong for the other three. I want to make them exactly identical, so that it's like nobody ever used the one in the spec, and the other one is used everywhere

[00:41:02.0000] <Hixie>
the URLs are odd because they're the result of converting the short names used in microdata to the URL form used in RDF

[00:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
oh, i understand the owl:equivalentProperty thing now

[00:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
ok

[00:42:02.0000] <foolip>
Hixie: is the appending of # and : inspired by some RDFy scheme?

[00:42:03.0000] <Hixie>
no

[00:42:04.0000] <foolip>
I'll just let you reply to that email so everyone can see the answer :)

[00:42:05.0000] <Hixie>

[00:42:06.0000] <Hixie>
(i forget the details)

[00:43:00.0000] <danbri>
hixie, if you make them exactly identical, then all properties of the latter become properties of the former; eg. re dc:title

[00:43:01.0000] <danbri>
<rdf:Property rdf:about="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/title">

[00:43:02.0000] <danbri>
<rdfs:label xml:lang="en-US">Title</rdfs:label>

[00:43:03.0000] <danbri>
<rdfs:comment xml:lang="en-US">A name given to the resource.</rdfs:comment>

[00:43:04.0000] <danbri>
<rdfs:isDefinedBy rdf:resource="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"/>

[00:43:05.0000] <danbri>
<dcterms:issued>1999-07-02</dcterms:issued>

[00:43:06.0000] <danbri>
<dcterms:modified>2008-01-14</dcterms:modified>

[00:43:07.0000] <danbri>
<rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#Property"/>

[00:43:08.0000] <danbri>
<dcterms:hasVersion rdf:resource="http://dublincore.org/usage/terms/history/#title-006"/>

[00:43:09.0000] <danbri>
<skos:note xml:lang="en-US">A second property with the same name as this property has been declared in the dcterms: namespace (http://purl.org/dc/terms/).  See the Introduction to the document "DCMI Metadata Terms" (http://dublincore.org/documents/dcmi-terms/) for an explanation.</skos:note>

[00:43:10.0000] <danbri>
</rdf:Property>

[00:44:00.0000] <danbri>
... all that from the dc namespace would also be asserted for http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml/microdata#http%3A%2F%2Fn.whatwg.org%2Fwork%23%3Atitle

[00:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
ah

[00:44:02.0000] <danbri>
... and people running queries like 'find me property URIs from Dublin Core issued before 2000' would find your URIs; while we could find wiggleroom to justify this, it would cause general confusion I'm sure

[00:44:03.0000] <Hixie>
so presumably i also want equivalentProperty sameAs for the other one, not sameAs sameAs?

[00:46:00.0000] <danbri>

[00:46:01.0000] <danbri>

[00:47:01.0000] <danbri>

[00:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
i think rdfa and microdata are different enough that readers would be better off not trying to learn both at once

[00:48:01.0000] <foolip>

[00:48:02.0000] <danbri>

[00:49:00.0000] <danbri>

[00:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
foolip: i'd rather just make it equivalent to an existing vCard RDF vocabulary, and let the RDF guys worry about how that matches FOAF

[00:49:02.0000] <danbri>

[00:49:03.0000] <foolip>

[00:50:00.0000] <danbri>
you could add both harmlessly enough

[00:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
danbri: fundamentally RDFa and microdata present the same underlying triple idea in very different ways

[00:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
danbri: e.g. in microdata the presentation is more about groups of name-value pairs, where values can be further groups, or strings, or urls (or dates/times)

[00:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
danbri: whereas in RDFa the presentation is more about graphs

[00:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
danbri: of URLs

[00:52:00.0000] <foolip>
"It provides a simplified version of the basic factual claims that a page makes, stripped of flashy colours, pretty pictures or seductive language." <- surely one can express lies just as well in RDF as in natural language?

[00:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
danbri: in particular, with itemref="" in microdata you can even declare a bunch of name-value pairs without saying what group they're part of, and multiple groups (itemscope="" items) can import in those name-value pairs

[00:53:00.0000] <danbri>
interesting, do you have an example of where that's useful?

[00:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's not really useful for multiple items to use the same properties per se, but the use case for it is the same as the use case in RDFa for having about="" listed in several places

[00:54:01.0000] <danbri>
sounds like a kind of inheritance mechanism (but scoped to a single document I guess?)

[00:54:02.0000] <Hixie>
with the same value

[00:54:03.0000] <foolip>
Hixie: that last part about sharing subtrees between several items seems dubious though, certainly it means the model isn't a tree any longer but a directed graph (I think)

[00:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. see http://damowmow.com/playground/microdata/004/review-annotated.html

[00:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
foolip: depends what you consider the nodes

[00:55:02.0000] <foolip>
if you can fix itemref loops without breaking that though, fine

[00:55:03.0000] <foolip>
I did break it in my solution

[00:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
danbri: (except, if you look at that solution, pretend that <itemref> is really an itemref="" attribute next to the itemscope="" attribute)

[00:57:00.0000] <danbri>
/me not quite seeing the difference

[00:57:01.0000] <Hixie>
as what?

[00:58:00.0000] <danbri>
ah maybe i misunderstood your 'can import in those name-value pairs'

[00:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
here's another way of showing the difference

[00:58:02.0000] <danbri>
they're linked by a named property/relationship, not copied directly in?

[00:58:03.0000] <Hixie>
in microdata, if you say <div itemscope itemtype=... itemid=X></div><div itemscope itemtype=... itemid=X></div>, there are two empty groups of name-value pairs with no properties

[00:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
in RDFa, if you say <div about="X"></div><div about="X"></div>, there is no data present.

[00:59:01.0000] <danbri>
(folip, yes, it's important to be able to lie ... I was trying to capture that these property/value language strip out a lot of the human richness from docs, to dumb them down to computer level)

[00:59:02.0000] <danbri>
/me nods

[01:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
now it happens that microdata has a (lossy) mapping to RDF, and RDF has a (lossy, implied) mapping to microdata, but it's not the point of the mechanism

[01:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
unlike RDFa where the conversion to RDF is lossless and is the point of the mechanism

[01:01:01.0000] <danbri>
what's lost when you go from microdata to rdf?

[01:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
you can't refer to something with no properties in a triple store

[01:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
there's no triple

[01:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
you also lose the untyped items

[01:03:01.0000] <Hixie>
and currently you lose some type information from <time> elements, though that could be fixed

[01:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
my three legged cat is climbing on top of my bike

[01:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
this could go very poorly

[01:04:02.0000] <danbri>
hmm, I could say that http://danbri.org/foaf.rdf#danbri is a foaf:Person ...

[01:04:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Yeah, he'll never reach the pedals

[01:04:04.0000] <Hixie>
she's now sitting on the seat

[01:04:05.0000] <danbri>
and that it has a http://example.com/fooprop of http://example.org/barvalue

[01:04:06.0000] <danbri>
and say nothing more about barvalue

[01:05:00.0000] <danbri>
is that what you mean by a thinkg with no properties? do you count "incoming" properties as its properties?

[01:05:01.0000] <danbri>
since often the naming/direction of a property is pretty arbitrary

[01:05:02.0000] <danbri>
'made' vs 'maker' etc

[01:06:00.0000] <danbri>
/me grins re cat

[01:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
ok, back. sorry, had to take a picture of the cat doing this or my girlfriend would never believe me.

[01:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
danbri: consider <div itemscope></div> -- it's an item, but it has no type, no properties, and no identifier.

[01:07:01.0000] <danbri>
/me looks for a numLegs property in http://hyperdata.org/xmlns/pets/hedwig.xml ... fails

[01:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
danbri: it can exist in microdata (the DOM API can reference it), but I can't see how it can exist in RDF.

[01:08:01.0000] <danbri>
ok, it's a placeholder piece of markup?

[01:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
could be, yeah

[01:08:03.0000] <danbri>
oh, got you

[01:09:00.0000] <danbri>
so i guess if we distinguish APIs to the markup, from APIs to 'what the markup tells us', we get both

[01:09:01.0000] <danbri>
RDF APIs won't tell you the grouping clusters that things came in, in their source graphs

[01:09:02.0000] <danbri>
they tend to take pride in protecting people from needing to care about that 

[01:09:03.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[01:09:04.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think this is a failure of either model

[01:09:05.0000] <danbri>
but markup APIs obviously need that too, eg. to make an editor

[01:09:06.0000] <danbri>
/me neither

[01:09:07.0000] <Hixie>
but it's a difference

[01:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
in most practical applications, these differences would likely not come up much -- you don't exactly need to express an empty item often

[01:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
anyway, this is one of the examples of the reason i think it's best not to try to explain microdata and RDFa models together

[01:11:00.0000] <danbri>
so this is more a difference between the packet of deliverables the RDFa project and the Microformats project give you; former gives you markup, triples model, and maybe eventually an API to the triples; latter gives you markup, triples model, and an API to the markup 

[01:11:01.0000] <Hixie>
i think it might confuse people more than help, as they might try to apply one model to the other, and get confused

[01:12:00.0000] <danbri>
so, in both models, we are saying ... that any bit of markup can be scoped to be 'about' some specific thing of interest; and we might or might not identify that thing specifically. but regardless, it is a grouping construct for a collection of properties/links that describe it.

[01:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
do you mean "microformats" there or "microdata"?

[01:12:02.0000] <danbri>
yeah sorry

[01:12:03.0000] <danbri>
s/microformats/microdata/

[01:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
ah ok

[01:13:01.0000] <danbri>
mini-info, tiny-factoids, etc :)

[01:13:02.0000] <Hixie>
i wouldn't really say microdata is a triples model

[01:13:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's more a nestable name-value pair list model

[01:13:04.0000] <danbri>
but it does (perhaps grudgingly) give you the triples

[01:13:05.0000] <Hixie>
it can be converted to triples, yeah

[01:13:06.0000] <danbri>
so is any rdf syntax

[01:13:07.0000] <Hixie>
like rdf can be converted to name-value lists

[01:13:08.0000] <Hixie>
but it's not a perfect translation

[01:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. you can't express an empty list as triples sanely

[01:14:01.0000] <danbri>
people didn't make RDF 'cos they loved triples; they made it cos they wanted to get a big pile of name-value metadata systems talking to each other

[01:14:02.0000] <danbri>
yup, that's the syntax / model distinction again

[01:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
also, re your "in both models" statement above, it's possible to make name-value pairs in microdata without scoping it to a subject (item):

[01:15:01.0000] <danbri>
in RDF too, kinda

[01:15:02.0000] <danbri>
I can write:

[01:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. <div itemscope itemtype=... itemid=A itemref="q r"></div> <div id=q itemprop=Q>...</div> <div id=r itemprop=R>...</div> -- q and r could be referenced from other items also

[01:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
so they're not scoped to A

[01:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
(actually that's the case even if they _are_ scoped to A)

[01:16:03.0000] <danbri>
<rdf:Description><owner><Person><name>Ian Hixon</name></Person></owner><numLegs>3</numLegs></rdf:Description> ....

[01:16:04.0000] <danbri>
... ie. 'there is something, ... owned by hixie, ... with 3 legs'

[01:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
in the microdata example above, id=q doesn't say "there is something with Q=...", it only says "Q=..."

[01:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
if nothing references it, then nothing has Q=...

[01:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
(and there's a conformance error, but that's another problem)

[01:17:03.0000] <danbri>
and you're finding that construct useful?

[01:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
it proved to be a less confusing way of allowing properties of a single item to be scattered across a document than having each one be scoped to an item and for all those items to share the said itemid

[01:19:00.0000] <danbri>
but in that case they are properties of some item?

[01:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[01:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
the one(s) that referenced them

[01:19:03.0000] <danbri>
(or item means the grouping construct, not the thing described?)

[01:19:04.0000] <Hixie>
item means the thing with itemscope=""

[01:19:05.0000] <Hixie>
the list of name-value pairs

[01:20:00.0000] <danbri>
beginning to think we need a testcase repository

[01:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. you can do <div itemscope itemref="a b"></div> ...blabla... <meta itemprop=a content="1"> ...blabla... <link itemprop=b href="2">

[01:20:02.0000] <danbri>
irc is a bit cramped for this sort of detailed comparison

[01:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
with the RDFa-style you would do just ..blabla... <meta about=X rel=a content="1"> ...blabla... <link about=X rel=b href="2">

[01:21:01.0000] <danbri>
for rdf/xml we used http://www.w3.org/2000/10/rdf-tests/rdfcore/ ... basically a collection of rdf/xml documents plus normalised triples extracted, and some working-group metadata

[01:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
(but when we did the usability tests we found people got far more confused by that than the itemref thing)

[01:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
(even though it seems simpler)

[01:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
(it is also harder to expose in the DOM, since there's no longer a single element that maps to an item)

[01:22:02.0000] <danbri>
i'm confused by both here! using real examples rather than 'a', 'q', 'foo' etc helps, esp as i don't know your syntax well

[01:23:00.0000] <danbri>
care to bash a full example into a wiki somewhere?

[01:23:01.0000] <Hixie>
both are intending to express the triples X,a,1 and X,b,2

[01:23:02.0000] <danbri>
...and the human prose wrapped around those two triples is in same bit of the doc, or different bits of the doc? 

[01:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
different

[01:24:01.0000] <danbri>
(how do i get an url to this conversation btw? there's a logger bot with #-offsets somehow?)

[07:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:33:00.0000] <Lachy>
awesome. I just got confirmation that Selectors API 2 will be published as FPWD tomorrow

[07:34:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Cool.

[07:37:00.0000] <Lachy>
after FPWD, I think I'm going to seriously consider dropping queryScopedSelector.

[07:37:01.0000] <Lachy>
Though, I'm still waiting for some additional feedback from some people

[07:59:00.0000] <foolip>
Lachy: what does queryScopedSelector do?

[07:59:01.0000] <foolip>
doesn't calling querySelector on an arbitrary element also scope the results?

[08:02:00.0000] <Lachy>
it implies the presence of :scope at the beginning of the selector, where :scope will match the element it's called on.

[08:03:00.0000] <Lachy>
but that pre-processing only works for selectors that begin with a simple selector, so the common shortcut in JS libraries like "+div" can't be used

[08:04:00.0000] <Lachy>
in most cases, it's functionally the same as calling document.querySelector(":scope+div", elm); where elm is some element you want to select relative to.

[08:04:01.0000] <foolip>
oh, so elm.querySelector doesn't work?

[08:05:00.0000] <foolip>
I remeber trying that many times, but can't remember if it worked or not

[08:07:00.0000] <Lachy>
elm.querySelector only allows you to select descendants, not siblings

[08:07:01.0000] <Lachy>
so while it works for the " " and ">" combinators, it doesn't work for "+" or "~"

[08:08:00.0000] <Lachy>
queryScopedSelector was supposed to solve that, bug since modifying the selector syntax to allow them to being with combinators is out of the question, as far as the CSSWG is concerned, it doesn't really help much

[08:09:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Argh, Lachy, quit saying that.  It's wrong.

[08:10:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
There was a specific thing that we didn't like, the ! at the beginning to indicate scoped-ness.

[08:10:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Anne didn't like starting with a combinator, but the rest of us did.

[08:10:02.0000] <Lachy>
yeah, I know Anne hates it. I'm sure there were others in the CSSWG who said I shouldn't be modifying the selector syntax to allow selectors to begin with combinators

[08:11:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Not in the thread, there weren't.  I reviewed it a week or two ago.

[08:11:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Parity with jQuery was an important point.

[08:17:00.0000] <Lachy>
there was some initially from fantasai, but looks like she might have somewhat changed her mind in her last mail in the thread

[08:26:00.0000] <Lachy>
anyway, TabAtkins, before I decide what to do about queryScopedSelector and whether or not to bring back support for selectors beginning with combinators, I want to get feedback from othermaciej and JS library devs like JohnResi1

[08:26:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
kk

[08:33:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It seems all the differences in expression ability between RDFa and microdata are either obscure edge cases, or things you shouldn't be doing in the first place

[08:34:00.0000] <Lachy>
isn't the only difference in the ability to specify the value's type in RDFa, whcih is something that should be defined by the vocabulary?

[08:34:01.0000] <Dashiva>
There's also stuff relating to unidentified items (only microdata), cyclical blank nodes (only RDFa) and some others

[12:42:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[12:45:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:45:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or, I should say: Wikipedia "consensus" does.

[12:46:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
A lot of groups seem to have independently realized that consensus-based decision-making is a great idea, and so adopted that, except without the consensus part.

[12:46:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Oh, right. Forgot about that.

[12:47:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Wikipedia consensus seems more like benevolent dictator, where the dictator happens to be whatever arbcom member is on duty

[12:47:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, ArbCom is totally different.  That's just plain votes, but they usually only accept cases where people have been misbehaving and won't stop.

[12:47:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
AFAIK, the ArbCom always votes in full on any given case, barring recusals.

[12:48:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
ArbCom members definitely don't have much of any privileges beyond voting on ArbCom cases, last I checked.

[12:48:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
enwiki has Jimbo Wales as a benevolent dictator.  Everyone else only has Wikimedia employees, who have been known to randomly do whatever they think is appropriate regardless of what anyone thinks.

[12:49:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
(although pretty rarely, and usually with good reason)

[12:49:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Hum, I thought arbcom handled first-line disputes

[12:50:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Like appeals of page deletion

[12:50:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, they typically only accept disputes that have been running for months with no resolution by other means, or sometimes one-off sysop misbehavior (since they're the only ones who can desysop).

[12:50:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
There are about ten ArbCom members.

[12:51:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You're probably thinking of the myriad other bureaucratic processes on Wikipedia, which are mostly managed by sysops, who number one or two thousand.  Yes, a request for page deletion/undeletion or such is decided by a single sysop arbitrarily.

[12:51:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And it can really depend on who closes the request.

[12:51:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Regardless of discussion.

[12:52:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Aha

[12:52:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
There are other procedures that have accreted over time.  Like Raul654 runs the front page unilaterally last I checked, just because he's been running it for years and nobody dislikes him much.

[12:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
And promotion to sysop is handled by bureaucrats, who usually do it by strict vote (75-80% support required) but have sometimes ignored the vote.

[12:53:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And of course anything that doesn't require privileges (like changes to policy pages) is decided by whoever has the most people to flood discussions and revert your edits without appearing tendentious.

[12:53:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
(changes to articles, too)

[12:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
All very chaotic.

[14:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
MediaWiki had a fun bug with X-Forwarded-For once.

[14:20:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It ignores XFF except from trusted IP addresses, of course, since anything else is totally broken.

[14:21:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Wikimedia routes everything through Squids, with the Apaches not on the public Internet, so the Squids' IP addresses are whitelisted.

[14:21:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And they always send an XFF header, of course.

[14:21:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The Squids also filter out evil X-Forwarded-For headers.

[14:21:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
But someone figured out that if you send an X_Forwarded_For header, Squid will ignore it, but PHP will treat it the same as X-Forwarded-For.

[14:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So they tried to frame someone on Wikipedia for vandalism.  But Tim Starling investigated and fixed the bug, and the guy was unbanned.

[14:22:01.0000] <Philip`>
That's quite evil

[14:22:02.0000] <zcorpan__>
what about X-Forwarded_For?

[14:22:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
zcorpan__, I assume the fix covers that too.

[14:22:04.0000] <Philip`>
(The header naming, not the framing)

[14:22:05.0000] <Philip`>
What about X#Forwarded#For?

[14:22:06.0000] <zcorpan__>
x-forwarded-for?

[14:23:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
forwarded-for?

[14:23:01.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, I guess it's because CGI conventionally does s/-/_/g and prefixes HTTP_ to pass headers as environment variables

[14:23:02.0000] <Philip`>
so only _ would suffer from that problem

[14:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
(I assume PHP follows the same silly interface as CGI despite not having any of the constraints that force it to do so)

[14:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, and it also uppercases.

[14:24:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's the format of keys for $_SERVER.

[14:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
Seems like an instance of the general problem of blacklisting

[14:26:01.0000] <Philip`>
It'd be securer for the Squids to only allow a specific set of headers through

[14:26:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
At least when used as reverse proxies, I guess, yeah.

[14:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't know what the fix was.

his first mistake is using HTML Tidy. That has never been a good tool to encourage developers to use for general development.

[15:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
so pretty much anything we do in text/html is going to give him issues

[15:07:03.0000] <zcorpan__>
i guess those authoring tools also mangle general web content since clearly they're not parsing html in a way compatible with browsers

[15:07:04.0000] <Hixie>
not much we can do about that given the constraints we're working with

[15:07:05.0000] <daedb>
Hasn't that guy given up yet? He should just stick to XHTML and be done with it.

[15:08:00.0000] <Lachy>
HTML Tidy has limited utility in cleaning up markup from some other source, which is a complete mess when obtained. In that case, running through tidy as an initial clean up step us acceptable

[15:08:01.0000] <foolip>
oh, new blog post?

[15:09:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
i wonder how the authoring tools handle perfectly valid xhtml

[15:09:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
i guess xstandard manages

[15:09:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Wikipedia uses Tidy.

[15:10:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
can't tidy be run with a set of parameters to make it aware of the new tags?

[15:10:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
If html5lib becomes more mature and adds a "kill invalid stuff through any means necessary" feature, it would be nice to switch to that, but that doesn't seem likely in the immediate future.

[15:10:02.0000] <zcorpan__>
not that it'll fix the doctype or <a><div> problems though

[15:10:03.0000] <zcorpan__>
or other general compat problems tidy has

[15:11:00.0000] <foolip>
haha, he put a lot of effort into that blog post anyway

[15:11:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
i wonder why he doesn't put the effort into making an html5 aware editor

[15:13:00.0000] <foolip>
perhaps he doesn't like HTML

[15:13:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
i wonder why he doesn't put the effort into making an xhtml5 aware editor

[15:13:02.0000] <Hixie>
foolip: neither do i, but i recognise a lost cause when i see one :-)

[15:14:00.0000] <foolip>
hehe

[15:15:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
where's annevk?

[15:16:00.0000] <foolip>
I think he's on vacation with arjan or something

[15:16:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
ok

[15:16:02.0000] <Lachy>
if there are any plans to add an HTML-Tidy-like feature to html5lib, or to base such a tool on it, then there are some things in the parsing algorithm that should be avoided, or at least be careful about them

[15:17:00.0000] <Lachy>
in particular, the adoption agency algorithm, that can end up creating unwanted duplicate elements just by the accidental omission of an end tag

[15:17:01.0000] <foolip>
hmmm, what should be done instead then?

[15:17:02.0000] <Lachy>
e.g. given a case like this:

[15:18:00.0000] <Lachy>
<p>Some paragraph containing <b>an unclosed b element.</p><p>Another paragraph...</p>

[15:19:00.0000] <Lachy>
The parsing algorithm says to insert a new b element into the second paragraph. But it's more likely that the actual intention is to have the b element closed somewhere before the first paragraph

[15:19:01.0000] <Lachy>
I've seen the problem occur many times in forums that allow markup, but which don't sanitise it well. An unclosed link or b element, or something, can screw up the rest of the page

[15:20:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
inducing intention and moving away from the parsing algorithm seems like moving into Tidy land of incompatibility

[15:20:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
<p>foo<b>bar<b>baz</p> - there the second b tag is probably intended to be an end tag

[15:21:00.0000] <foolip>
perhaps sanitize comments/posts one-by-one rather than sanitizing as the last step before output?

[15:21:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
and in <p>foo/p> there's probably a < missing

[15:22:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
the second example is even valid html

[15:22:01.0000] <Lachy>
zcorpan__, yeah, that's true too. That case might also be detectable, but I'm sure there are limits to what can reasonbly be done. But the goal of a tidy program should be to make a best effort at giving a reasonble result, and not give something that is wildly unexpected and/or require significant cleanup afterwards

[15:24:00.0000] <Lachy>
in the case of an unclosed inline element, choosing not to reopen it again is the least detrimental choice that won't require too much author intervention to clean up again. But inserting a bunch of new elements into subsequent paragraphs will take more time for the author to then go and strip them

[15:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Lachy, as long as the output is parsed by browsers the same as the input would have been, is it really the sanitizer's problem?

[15:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
AryehGregor, if the sanitizer is supposed to help developers, then it should give a better result than what browsers are forced to do for compatibility reasons

[15:25:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Lachy, not if it's being automatically run on every page save or whatever.  If you're planning on editing the output manually, that's different.

[15:25:02.0000] <Lachy>
huh? I think you might be considering a different use case from what I am.

[15:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Possibly.

[15:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Wikipedia runs Tidy on the user-submitted content in every page before serving it.

[15:26:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's run as part of the wikitext parsing, toward the end.

[15:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Basically just for the sake of validating.

[15:27:01.0000] <Lachy>
my use case is an author writing some content in a CMS, and submits it. The CMS then checks the input and finds unclosed elements. It could either point out the error and return the markup unchanged for the user to continue editing, or ...

[15:27:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or just silently fix it and publish.

[15:27:03.0000] <Lachy>
it could offer to clean it up in a sensible way

[15:27:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
"Offer" is bad UI, most authors don't care, just do it.

[15:28:00.0000] <Lachy>
yeah, whatever

[15:28:01.0000] <Lachy>
whether it does it automatically or as a user pref or whatever is irrelevant here.

[15:28:02.0000] <zcorpan__>
use wysiwyg and hide the markup from the user

[15:28:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If only wikitext were simple enough to do sane WYSIWYG.  :(

[15:29:00.0000] <Lachy>
not even HTML is simple enough in all cases to do sane wysiwig

[15:29:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
At least it's more likely to round-trip without massive changes throughout the source code.

[15:32:00.0000] <Lachy>
damn, wikipedia gets the clean up wrong :-( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Sandbox

[15:33:00.0000] <Lachy>
wow. It also leaves the source text unaltered, rather than fixing the error

[15:33:01.0000] <zcorpan__>
<p>Some paragraph containing <b>an unclosed b element.</b></p>

[15:33:02.0000] <zcorpan__>
<p><b>Another paragraph...</b></p>

[15:34:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
?

[15:34:01.0000] <Lachy>
yeah, that's the wrong way to clean it up. It should be nice to the author and not put the b in the second paragraph

[15:34:02.0000] <zcorpan__>
what if the author wanted the second paragraph to be bold?

[15:34:03.0000] <Lachy>
but I mean, click the edit link and see the source wiki text. I didn't mean in the generated page source

[15:35:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
it would be annoying to fix mistakes if the source was tampered with

[15:35:01.0000] <Lachy>
then they can put a b in the second paragraph manually. An accidentally unclosed element is more likeliy than an intentional mis-nested element

[15:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Lachy, users mostly use wikitext for bold, which behaves as you describe.

[15:36:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
'''Bold text\n\nNo longer bold

[15:36:02.0000] <Lachy>
yeah, that's the sensible approach

[15:36:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
becomes: <p><b>Bold text</b></p><p>No longer bold</p>

[15:36:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
We don't want to tamper with the source text.

[15:36:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
That way madness lies.

[15:37:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Because we'd have to parse it reliably, and wikitext is so complicated that we can't really parse it, we just apply a bunch of magical transformations that turn it into HTML.

[15:37:01.0000] <Lachy>
sure, with wikitext being as haphazardly designed as it is, I'm sure trying to automate cleaning of it would be a total nightmare

[15:38:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anything related to wikitext is a total nightmare.

[15:38:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It sounded like a great idea, but it was one of the worst mistakes wikis made.

[15:38:02.0000] <Lachy>
I hate wikitext. I wish it was never invented.

[15:38:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
The idea was reasonable in the era before WYSIWYG editors were reliably available for the web.

[15:38:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's a lot easier to edit than raw HTML.

[15:38:05.0000] <Lachy>
surely, there would be a way to migrate away from it

[15:38:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
But now it's become counterproductive.

[15:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Do you have any idea how many times this has been discussed?  :)

[15:39:01.0000] <Lachy>
probably many times :-)

[15:39:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It would require an enormous amount of work to migrate away.

[15:39:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
First of all, we'd need to invent some new language with all the same features, and be able to convert wikitext to that.

[15:39:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think very simple forms of wikitext, such as Markdown, are still a great idea.  Going beyond should just be normal HTML, though.

[15:39:05.0000] <Lachy>
but generating HTML markup from the wikitext is the easy part. That's already done. You would just need to have a system that spends a lot of time generating and storing the HTML markup

[15:40:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, because wikitext contains tons of info beyond the raw HTML.

[15:40:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Like template calls, for instance.

[15:40:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The templates are substituted into the wikitext before parsing.

[15:40:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
We'd have to make up our own syntax one way or another, it can't be pure HTML.

[15:40:04.0000] <Lachy>
yeah, those have to be dealt with in a special way

[15:40:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also other features like that, categories and such.

[15:41:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Which, by the way, can be added via template, so it's not enough to just edit them separately like most software does.

[15:41:01.0000] <Lachy>
but it could be based more on HTML markup, rather than crazy random wikitext syntax

[15:41:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, we'd probably have to do something HTML-ish.  Except that would probably mean using XML, which would be seriously painful to manually edit.

[15:42:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
And not everyone would want to use WYSIWYG

[15:42:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
.

[15:42:02.0000] <Lachy>
editing HTML in a browser is only a pain because it lacks any kind of useful editing features, like syntax highlighting, autocompletion, etc.

[15:43:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I said XML, not HTML.  :)

[15:43:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
SYNTAX ERROR!

[15:43:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:44:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[15:44:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[01:03:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: so I notice that a year or so ago George submitted a jing patch that improves reporting for missing-attribute and missing-element cases

[01:03:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://code.google.com/p/jing-trang/issues/detail?id=35

[01:04:00.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: yeah. I had hoped to see the patch on trunk by now

[01:05:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: James seemed to not want to land it until some revisions to PatternValidator get made

[01:06:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://code.google.com/p/jing-trang/issues/detail?id=35#c1

[01:06:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
(James' comment)

[01:07:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: but there are a couple of problems with that patch as implemented

[01:07:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
one is the format of the error messages it emits

[01:07:02.0000] <hsivonen>
ideally, the expection objects would carry enough data for formatting the message on the application side

[01:07:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
for example, for <link> it will give you: "[href, rel] required attributes missing from element link"

[01:08:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[01:09:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
so the other problem is that it does not provide enough information for at least one case I can think of

[01:09:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
which is the case of <object>

[01:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
where the requirement is basically an OR case

[01:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
a data attribute OR a type attribute

[01:11:00.0000] <hsivonen>
what does it provide in that case?

[01:12:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
same as for the link case -- it just emits, "[data, type] required attributes missing from element object"

[01:12:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
his implementation just adds the attributes to a Set

[01:12:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
on then it calls toString to dump that

[01:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, maybe I'm misunderstanding something, but your response here about nested vocabularies seems confusing http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jan/0905.html

[01:27:00.0000] <Lachy>
You wrote: "I think it's better to just use itemtype="" everywhere you want to start a new vocabulary" - but in the vCard example foolip gave, the nested adr stuff isn't a new vocabulary. I thought foolip's idea was that it should default to inhereting the itemtype

[01:27:01.0000] <Lachy>
But in the somewhat contrived example you gave, where they are different, it does make sense to require an explicit itemtype

[01:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
Lachy: adr is a "new vocabulary" for the purposes of that sentence

[01:40:01.0000] <Hixie>
sorry for being ambiguous

[01:40:02.0000] <Hixie>
i really meant a new set of name-value pair names

[01:41:00.0000] <Lachy>
well, it shouldn't be. That seems very unintuitive to require the author to repeat the same itemtype again, and I don't expect most authors using the vCard vocabulary will remember that

[01:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
Lachy: no what i'm saying is that md-vcard, if it wants to work with rdf, should require that the adr types have their own types

[01:43:01.0000] <Hixie>
different than the vcard type

[01:43:02.0000] <Hixie>
since they're not vcards but addresses

[01:44:00.0000] <Lachy>
but they're part of the same vcard vocabulary

[01:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
only to the same extent that the "reload()" method on the Location object is part of the Window object

[01:45:01.0000] <Lachy>
so, if an author doesn't care about the RDF conversion, can they get away without using an explicit itemtype, and still express the semantics they want?

[01:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
sure, that's what md-vcard does

[01:46:00.0000] <Lachy>
ok. It still seems weird that the semantics that are expressable through md-vcard, can't be mapped to RDF in a sane way by default

[01:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
they could, just not using the vocabulary-agnostic rdf conversion algorithm

[01:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
even the work vocabulary can't really be converted naively -- you have to apply extra rules to get it into its "proper" RDF form

[01:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
(those rules are actually provided, though)

[01:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
a lot of this is a result of RDF's complexity

[01:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. using URLs everywhere

[01:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
i suppose we _could_ automatically map the adr properties to URLs by concatenating the "path" to the property

[01:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
hm, no, that wouldn't work

[01:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
there'd be no way to guarantee uniqueness

[01:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
(if the above doesn't make much sense to people reading archives, it's because i wasn't very eloquent.)

[06:12:02.0000] <cyberix>

[06:13:00.0000] <cyberix>

[06:14:01.0000] <Lachy>

[06:15:00.0000] <Lachy>
