[06:15:01.0000] <cyberix>
Lachy: the functions return value would be sound

[06:15:02.0000] <cyberix>
Lachy: it is the opposite of limiting

[06:15:03.0000] <Philip`>
/me doesn't know if push or pull APIs would be better

[06:15:04.0000] <Philip`>
Pull seems harder for browsers to handle nicely, since they don't know how long the function is going to take or how much sound it's going to return, so they don't know how early to call it

[06:16:00.0000] <Lachy>
so then it would have to generate the entire sound all at once, and return it as a single value in some undefined format?

[06:16:01.0000] <cyberix>
Lachy: no, it would return a chunk of sound

[06:16:02.0000] <Philip`>
whereas the script running in the page should have a better idea of those things, and of how much latency is acceptable

[06:16:03.0000] <Lachy>
push seems like a much more reasonable approach, and is more in line with how canvas works

[06:16:04.0000] <hsivonen>
argh. the rang/lang stuff is in http://www.w3.org/TR/xml-entity-names/#diff-xhtml1

[06:16:05.0000] <cyberix>
Lachy: and the browser would call it again to retrieve more

[06:17:00.0000] <hsivonen>
changing rang/lang sucks for roundtripping

[06:17:01.0000] <Lachy>
ok, but what format would it be requried to return? Would script authors be required to generate binary PCM data or something?

[06:17:02.0000] <cyberix>
Lachy: PCM would probably be good

[06:17:03.0000] <hsivonen>
if you serialize to &LeftAngleBracket; &RightAngleBracket;, the result is round-trip-incompatible with old HTML parsers

[06:17:04.0000] <Lachy>
that would be very complicated. I wouldn't expect most authors to be able to write a script that can generate sound and output PCM data.

[06:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
If they can't write a script to generate sound then they're just not going to use this scripted-sound-generating feature

[06:18:01.0000] <hsivonen>
if you serialize the new characters to &rang; and &lang;, you are incompatible with old MathML stuff

[06:18:02.0000] <cyberix>
Lachy: Currently the authors create PCM, store it in some variable, set flash to read that variable and play the sound

[06:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
If they can, I don't know what alternatives to PCM data would be better

[06:19:01.0000] <Lachy>
cyberix, the pull approach you're suggesting also seems to be unable to handle cases where sonds are generated in response to user interaction. It would be much simpler if, say, a click handler could invoke some sound generating methods when they want the sound

[06:19:02.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: Serialise to &#x27e8; then?

[06:19:03.0000] <Lachy>
and then the browser can then asynchrounosly produce that sound

[06:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dammit, Philip`, beat me to it.

[06:21:00.0000] <cyberix>
Lachy: you would have a click handler mix the sound of click to the buffer that gets returned on next call to the sound generator

[06:22:00.0000] <cyberix>
But push might be easier, I agree

[06:22:01.0000] <Lachy>
cyberix, so would the browser be constantly polling the function to check for new sound?

[06:22:02.0000] <Lachy>
That seems very inefficient

[06:22:03.0000] <cyberix>
yes

[06:22:04.0000] <cyberix>
it is not inefficent

[06:22:05.0000] <cyberix>
because

[06:23:00.0000] <Lachy>
the browser is wasting many cycles checking for new sound, running that function over and over again. How is that not inefficient?

[06:23:01.0000] <cyberix>
it makes sure you are only polling one sound at all times

[06:23:02.0000] <cyberix>
with push you might end up pushing multiple sounds at the same time

[06:24:00.0000] <cyberix>
ofcourse you don't do polling when the function has not been defined

[06:24:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you're dynamically generating sound, you're probably making a game and it's doing setInterval(updateFrame, 0) so you're already using up as many CPU cycles as you can, and it doesn't matter if a few more are spent on sound

[06:24:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: well, this &rang;/&lang; stuff is going to take way more of my time than I'd like

[06:24:03.0000] <cyberix>
I guess Lachy is worried about generating silence eating up lots of resources

[06:25:00.0000] <cyberix>
however most of the time you would not be using this callback to generate silence

[06:25:01.0000] <cyberix>
you'd rather not use sound output at all

[06:25:02.0000] <Lachy>
why does it matter if multiple sounds are pushed to it? Depending on how the API is defined to work, they can either play sequentially, or be multiplexed and output together.

[06:26:00.0000] <cyberix>
anyway

[06:26:01.0000] <cyberix>
We have been looking at different APIs on desktop side

[06:27:00.0000] <cyberix>
it seems everyone uses push

[06:27:01.0000] <Lachy>
all I'm saying is that it makes much more sense for the API to be something like audio.synthesizeSound(...); and have it play immediately, rather than having the polling method just waiting for something to be returned

[06:27:02.0000] <cyberix>
except for JACK

[06:27:03.0000] <cyberix>
whose developers say push is not a good idea because at the bottom you always have the sound device that is pull

[06:28:00.0000] <cyberix>
and you can implement push on top of pull easier than the other way around

[06:28:01.0000] <cyberix>
however JACK is really realtime critical

[06:28:02.0000] <cyberix>
if some process doesn't return the sound to it in time, it will kick the process out

[06:28:03.0000] <cyberix>
"no more sound for you"

[06:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
JACK seems to have different requirements to most normal audio systems, where it doesn't matter so much if there's a glitch and you lose a few milliseconds

[06:29:01.0000] <hsivonen>
aaargh. the difference in length between lang and LeftAngleBracket changes line wrapping, too

[06:29:02.0000] <Philip`>
Doing anything real-time based on JavaScript seems like a futile idea :-)

[06:30:00.0000] <cyberix>
so push is probably the way to go then

[06:30:01.0000] <cyberix>
and there should probably be just one channel out

[06:30:02.0000] <cyberix>
stereo

[06:30:03.0000] <cyberix>
if you want mixing, do it yourself

[06:31:00.0000] <Lachy>
but stereo is 2 channels

[06:31:01.0000] <cyberix>
one stereo channel

[06:31:02.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose it'd be nice to be extensible so we can do surround-sound output in the far future

[06:31:03.0000] <cyberix>
We also looked at this

[06:31:04.0000] <cyberix>
the conclusion was

[06:31:05.0000] <Philip`>
(rather than hard-coding the stereo assumption)

[06:31:06.0000] <cyberix>
there is no way to extend stereo into being surround

[06:32:00.0000] <Lachy>
and we'd probably want to design the API to be flexible enough to handle multiple channels, even if the first version of the API only supports L and R

[06:32:01.0000] <cyberix>
surround is something completely different

[06:32:02.0000] <cyberix>
it doesn't need to be part of the same API

[06:32:03.0000] <cyberix>
if you do that in future, you may as well define a new API

[06:32:04.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose it'd be nice to support mono for e.g. iPhone applications where you don't care much about audio quality and do care about processing time

[06:32:05.0000] <cyberix>
We also thought about that

[06:33:00.0000] <cyberix>
a function returning sound returns a pair of channels

[06:33:01.0000] <cyberix>
so ([3,5,3,7],[3,7,3,1])

[06:33:02.0000] <cyberix>
(left,right)

[06:33:03.0000] <cyberix>
if you want to save cpu and do mono

[06:33:04.0000] <cyberix>
just have the same reference on both sides

[06:34:00.0000] <cyberix>
the API can still be stereo

[06:34:01.0000] <Lachy>
do the numbers in those arrays just represent frequencies or something?

[06:34:02.0000] <Philip`>
That sounds quite sensible

[06:34:03.0000] <cyberix>
Lachy: yes, in no particular format

[06:34:04.0000] <cyberix>
so that would be four frames of stereo sound

[06:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
though I expect it'd be hard for browsers to optimise that case, so they'd still treat it as two independent channels and decode each number twice

[06:35:01.0000] <cyberix>
the reason why we want to have only one stereo channel going out is

[06:35:02.0000] <cyberix>
that otherwise people will expect us to implement ways of synchronising mixing

[06:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
Perhaps you'd want something similar to the canvas ImageData / WebGL typed arrays so it's much faster to transfer lists of numbers from JS to native code

[06:37:00.0000] <cyberix>

[06:37:01.0000] <Philip`>
C++

[06:37:02.0000] <Philip`>
(or C or whatever)

[06:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
where the browser converts the JS data into a format suitable for the platform's audio API

[06:38:01.0000] <Lachy>

[06:38:02.0000] <cyberix>

[06:39:00.0000] <cyberix>

[06:39:01.0000] <Philip`>

[06:39:02.0000] <cyberix>
the api for reading sound is

[06:40:00.0000] <Philip`>

[12:44:00.0000] <cyberix>
Philip`: I don't think we need binary buffers for sound

[12:45:00.0000] <cyberix>
Philip`: I just ate lunch with the main Kunquat developer, and we discussed the matter

[12:45:01.0000] <cyberix>
Even while coding C it is just typical to use float arrays to represent sound

[12:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
cyberix: I think the problem is that in JS (in some (all?) implementations), a float is a garbage-collected heap-allocated object

[12:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
which is a lot of overhead, when you have a hundred thousand of them per second

[12:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
(compared to a specialised array with a 4-byte-per-element backing store)

[12:56:00.0000] <cyberix>
Philip`: It'd the be job for the js engine writers to improve it

[12:57:00.0000] <cyberix>
then

[12:57:01.0000] <cyberix>
I don't think it is going to block anything

[12:57:02.0000] <cyberix>
it is just going to consume lots of resources

[12:57:03.0000] <cyberix>
that is ok

[12:57:04.0000] <cyberix>
there is always two options for that kind of problem

[12:57:05.0000] <cyberix>
one is to buy a more expensive computer

[12:58:00.0000] <cyberix>
and the other is to improve js

[12:58:01.0000] <cyberix>
:-)

[12:58:02.0000] <cyberix>
I think canvas uses this funny type because it can then access graphics acceleration

[12:58:03.0000] <cyberix>
standards like opengl define operations on graphics

[12:59:00.0000] <cyberix>
it is then easy to take that set of operations and reveal it to the use

[12:59:01.0000] <cyberix>
user

[12:59:02.0000] <cyberix>
in sound such a standard set of operations has not been defined

[13:00:00.0000] <cyberix>
and trying to do it on demand would probably not lead to very good results

[13:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
cyberix: Yeah, this probably isn't an important point

[13:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
The best approach is likely to be to list and describe use cases, and come up with an initial design, and get interest from implementors, and then iterate on the design

[13:08:00.0000] <cyberix>
If a page has frames

[13:08:01.0000] <cyberix>
do those frames have a Windows object?

[13:08:02.0000] <cyberix>
-s

[13:09:00.0000] <Philip`>
Every browsing context has its own Window object, and every page and frame and <iframe> and <object> etc has its own browsing context, if I remember correctly

[13:09:01.0000] <cyberix>
ok

[13:11:00.0000] <cyberix>
in that case we are talking about a function  Window.outputSound([[float],[float]])

[13:11:01.0000] <Philip`>
I guess it'd be better to add new API onto a new object, rather than cluttering up the existing ones, like how HTML5 originally had no <audio> element (I think) and you did "new Audio()" then called methods on it

[13:11:02.0000] <Philip`>
since it's likely to end up with lots of methods and properties

[13:12:00.0000] <cyberix>
I couldn't come up with any other method, but I'm still a wee bit unsure about, if the amplitude should be fixed to 48KHz

[13:12:01.0000] <karlushi>

[13:31:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:33:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:35:00.0000] <jgraham>

[13:49:00.0000] <cyberix>

[14:03:00.0000] <jgraham>
cyberix: Arrays in javascript are just normal objects, more or less

[14:03:01.0000] <jgraham>
In particular they can be sparse; not every index need be defined

[14:04:00.0000] <jgraham>
So in the example I create an arry with length 100, populate the first few index properties with things-that-might-evaluate-to-floats

[14:04:01.0000] <jgraham>
Then leave a bunch of undefined properties ("holes") and populate the last index with a string

[14:09:00.0000] <cyberix>
okay

[14:09:01.0000] <cyberix>
I see now

[14:10:00.0000] <cyberix>

[14:10:01.0000] <cyberix>

[14:10:02.0000] <cyberix>
because there is no type signatures

[14:13:00.0000] <Philip`>

[14:13:01.0000] <cyberix>
oh

[14:13:02.0000] <Philip`>
s/browser/browsers/

[14:13:03.0000] <cyberix>

[14:13:04.0000] <cyberix>

[14:13:05.0000] <cyberix>
well

[14:13:06.0000] <cyberix>
then they do

[14:13:07.0000] <Philip`>

[14:14:00.0000] <cyberix>
sure

[14:14:01.0000] <cyberix>

[14:14:02.0000] <Philip`>

[14:14:03.0000] <cyberix>

[14:14:04.0000] <cyberix>

[14:14:05.0000] <cyberix>

2010-01-20
[17:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
anyone have any input on the name of the doc="" attribute?

[17:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
body="" was suggested

[17:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
seems about as reasonable

[17:36:00.0000] <nessy>
I quite like using body - it raises the right expectations IMHO

[17:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[17:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
was considering something like srcbody="" too

[17:45:00.0000] <nessy>
although … if it contains a full html file with header and all, body may be a bit too restrictive

[17:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
srcmarkup=""?

[17:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
srcdata=""?

[17:46:02.0000] <daedb>
contents="" ?

[17:46:03.0000] <Hixie>
hmm

[17:47:00.0000] <nessy>
it's either html or xhtml, right?

[17:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's likely to be whatever the document is

[17:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
so xml in xhtml, html in text/html

[17:48:00.0000] <nessy>
@webdoc ? @webpage ?

[17:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
question is, in xml, do we want to require the <html xmlns="..."><head><title/></head><body> ... </body></html> boilerplate?

[17:48:02.0000] <Hixie>
if we do, then it's going to be far less useful in xml

[17:48:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's already less useful because XML escaping rules are ridiculous

[17:48:04.0000] <Hixie>
(e.g. you must escape < in attribute values, iirc)

[17:49:00.0000] <daedb>
Could you theoretically put for instance SVG in there?

[17:49:01.0000] <Hixie>
(not to mention that a stray U+FFFF would kill the whole page, etc)

[17:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
i guess

[17:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
what would the use case be?

[17:49:04.0000] <daedb>
I don't know, I haven't really followed the discussion :)

[17:49:05.0000] <Hixie>
the main use case is for blog comments

[17:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
which would mostly expect text/html, possibly with embedded svg or mathml

[17:50:01.0000] <Hixie>
for text/html blogs anyway

[17:50:02.0000] <nessy>
so, if we allow the contents of a body element, only, would that be helpful in avoiding the xml/html choice?

[17:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
xml/html choice?

[17:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
it would affect what we call the attribute

[17:52:02.0000] <Hixie>
don't think it would affect any xml/html issue

[17:53:00.0000] <nessy>
I mean: if we can avoid the need to put the boilerplate in and thus deal with xhtml or html the same way - is that possible?

[17:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
xhtml and html are totally different

[17:54:00.0000] <Hixie>
you can't treat them the same way

[17:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
(however hard people insist on trying)

[17:54:02.0000] <Hixie>
so i don't think the boilerplate issue affects that per se

[17:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
what it affects is whether the attribute is really giving the contents of a document's <html:body>, or whether it's giving a full document

[17:55:01.0000] <nessy>
I see

[17:55:02.0000] <nessy>
so you would have a content-type attribute, too?

[17:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
no, it would just be html in text/html docs, and xml in xml docs

[17:56:01.0000] <nessy>
oh! now I get it.

[17:57:00.0000] <nessy>
in that case I would not expect to have to repeat the boilerplate

[17:57:01.0000] <Hixie>
(we don't want to require that non-web xhtml UAs have to include HTML parsers to be XHTML compliant)

[17:57:02.0000] <nessy>
just use @body , I'd say - it's an additional piece of body text to be displayed

[17:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah, body and srcbody are the main candidates i think

[17:58:01.0000] <nessy>
in fact, ppl might get the boilerplate wrong if they are required to repeat it - so that would avoid an additional source of errors IMO

[17:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
(having "src" at the front is useful from a language usability point of view)

[17:58:03.0000] <nessy>
yeah, makes sense

[17:58:04.0000] <Hixie>
makes it long, though, and people might think it's a URL

[17:58:05.0000] <Hixie>
language design is hard :-P

[17:59:00.0000] <nessy>
yeah, I was just wondering about that

[17:59:01.0000] <Hixie>
so much easier to reverse engineer mistakes other people have already made :-P

[17:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
instead of having to make one's own

[17:59:03.0000] <nessy>
I know! Tell me about it! I've experimented with so many names for the time-aligned text stuff!

[17:59:04.0000] <Hixie>
yeah! exactly

[18:00:00.0000] <nessy>
why not put an email out with your current state of mind and proposing @body and @srcbody and see what ppl say?

[18:00:01.0000] <nessy>
at the same time propose to avoid the header boilerplate repetition

[18:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
e-mail threads about names are rarely if ever useful

[18:01:01.0000] <Hixie>
they just become big bikeshedding threads

[18:01:02.0000] <nessy>
they will happen anyway, I fear

[18:01:03.0000] <nessy>
better to direct it than to come back as a flame war ;)

[18:01:04.0000] <Hixie>
yeah but the more feedback you get on a name, the more people's opinions you eventually have to reject

[18:01:05.0000] <Hixie>
:-)

[18:02:00.0000] <nessy>
let others make the arguments on why to reject them ;)

[18:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
anyway we already had that thread last week

[18:02:02.0000] <Hixie>
that's where body="" came from

[18:02:03.0000] <Hixie>
i think i might just go with body=""

[18:03:00.0000] <nessy>
yeah, though a summary of the reasons and state of thinking is probably good to get everyone on board

[18:03:01.0000] <nessy>

[23:42:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
hsivonen: so I've ported over George's jing issue-35 patch to the validator-nu branch, with some tweaks

[23:42:01.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmithX: awesome

[23:43:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
I think I will have something ready to send you for review later today

[23:44:00.0000] <hsivonen>
ok

[23:44:01.0000] <MikeSmithX>
what I added was a way for it to distinguish between the case where a there is a choice among the missing attributes/elements, and the case where there's not

[23:44:02.0000] <MikeSmithX>
for the case where there's not, it emits a separate error message for each missing attribute/element

[23:45:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
for the case where there's a choice, it emits, e.g., "Element object is missing one or more of the following attributes: data type."

[23:46:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
I realize that for the case where there's only two attributes/elements in the choice, that doesn't make so much sense.

[23:47:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
but I think there are other markup vocabs (DocBook, maybe) that have more complex choice cases than HTML does

[23:48:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
as-is, what George's patch does is that it dumps out a text representation of the required content model

[23:48:01.0000] <MikeSmithX>
basically RNC syntax

[23:48:02.0000] <MikeSmithX>
but I think for most users that's probably not all that helpful

[23:49:00.0000] <hsivonen>
indeed

[23:50:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
so I think the ambiguity of "missing one or more of" is an acceptable tradeoff vs. exposing end users to raw, potentially complex RNC content models

[23:50:01.0000] <hsivonen>
yeah

[23:50:02.0000] <MikeSmithX>
OK, anyway, I will try to get the patch wrapped up shortly

[23:51:00.0000] <MikeSmithX>
hsivonen: one thing I am not clear on is what the difference is in jing between the "required elements missing" case and what it calls the "unfinished element" case

[23:52:00.0000] <hsivonen>
IIRC, unfinished element is a special case of the former

[23:52:01.0000] <MikeSmithX>
but in the v.nu message-emitter, I can see that both cases basically cause the same message to be emitted

[23:52:02.0000] <MikeSmithX>
hsivonen: OK

[23:52:03.0000] <MikeSmithX>
for our purposes, it seems like the can be handled the same

[23:52:04.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmithX: I don't really know why Jing makes the distinction

[23:52:05.0000] <MikeSmithX>
OK

[23:55:00.0000] <hsivonen>
aaargh. Gecko's HTML serializer can wrap lines inside tags

[00:43:00.0000] <zcorpan>
should doc="" be parsed as xml in xhtml5?

[00:45:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I hope not

[00:45:01.0000] <hsivonen>
HTMLness bit-dependent behavior for the lose

[00:46:00.0000] <zcorpan>
if not, then doc makes html parsing support required

[00:47:00.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: theoretical purity or Real Problem? :-)

[00:47:01.0000] <zcorpan>
former

[00:47:02.0000] <zcorpan>
maybe the spec should require both html and xml support

[00:47:03.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: fixable by making doc not required for XHTML5-only UAs

[00:48:00.0000] <Lachy>
hsivonen, why is the HTMLness bit-dependent behaviour bad for this?

[00:48:01.0000] <othermaciej>
how does innerHTML work in XHTML5 documents? (does it?)

[00:48:02.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: depends on HTMLness bit

[00:48:03.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: per spec and per Gecko and IIRC WebKit

[00:48:04.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: Opera has nicer behavior but is in minority

[00:48:05.0000] <othermaciej>
I hate varying DOM APIs or markup meaning based on the HTMLness bit, but whether to use the text/html or XML syntax seems one of the cases where it is most justified

[00:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
what I hate even more is varying APIs based on quirks mode :-/

[00:49:01.0000] <zcorpan>
opera serializes innerHTML differently in xhtml

[00:49:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Lachy: the problem is that changing one layer of the software stack changes behavior elsewhere

[00:49:03.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: oh. 

[00:49:04.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: but still parses as HTML on setter?

[00:49:05.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: yes

[00:49:06.0000] <hsivonen>
not so nice, then

[00:49:07.0000] <zcorpan>
no, it's completely bogus

[00:50:00.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: varying doc is essentially varying a DOM API upon setAttribute()

[00:51:00.0000] <Lachy>
I suppose if we do make doc HTMLness bit-dependant, then it would mean that scripts interacting with the attribute may have to vary their behaviour based on whether the document is HTML or XHTML.

[00:51:01.0000] <hsivonen>
my thinking is that text/html vs. application/xhtml+xml choice should affect the hop from server to DOM

[00:52:00.0000] <hsivonen>
but making various other things change behavior, too, doesn't maintain clean layering in theory and in practice makes it harder to change the hop from server to DOM

[00:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: that is a plausible view - but there are DOM APIs that differ which we aren't really free to change, so it seems more valuable to me to keep markup syntax consistency within each serialization

[00:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: I wish there were separate APIs for interacting via HTML and XML serializations, so you could pick one explicitly instead of it being based on your MIME type

[00:53:01.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: IIRC, this was argued differently when I suggested cloning WebKit's HTMLness bit dependency in XMLSerializer into Gecko

[00:57:00.0000] <hsivonen>
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms533897%28VS.85%29.aspx 

[00:57:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Documentation mention defer in the context of innerHTML

[01:01:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: I think it would be rather confusing if parsing wasn't internally cnsistent within one document

[01:01:01.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: I think we should have html="..." and xml='...' and the author should use the one that matches the page in order to avoid self-confusion

[01:02:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: it sucks to change JS library behavior when changing how the DOM gets built

[01:02:01.0000] <hsivonen>
so JS libs could still use setAttribute("html", "...") on XHTML pages

[01:03:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: Apart from that being really ugly, I would expect people to cargo-cult @xml into html documents and get a world of pain out

[01:04:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It also seems to crash with being able to only support one of HTML and XHTML

[01:04:01.0000] <jgraham>
In general I don't think that XHTML is a significant enough use case that we should be designing more markup to make it work slightly better

[01:04:02.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: in that case, doc='' should parse as HTML also in XHTML docs

[01:05:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: if the party line is that XHTML isn't significant enough

[01:06:00.0000] <Dashiva>
XHTML should be done with proper serialization and stuff, so it seems very simple to use src="data:..." for that

[01:06:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: I believe I said at the time that I would prefer to have separate APIs for getting XML and HTML serializations, instead of yet another switchy one

[01:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: but I don't 100% recall

[01:07:01.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: right. so wouldn't it be consistent to want explicitly flagged HTML vs. XML here, too, instead of making doc='...' depend on the HTMLness bit?

[01:07:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think you wanted to add an explicit way to pick one serialization or the other that struck me as awkard to use and thus I suggested the alternative

[01:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: the direct analogy would be to have both xmlDoc and htmlDoc

[01:09:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:09:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:15:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:17:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:18:01.0000] <Lachy>

[01:18:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:18:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:18:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:19:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[01:19:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: Maybe the difference is that you think conformance is an abstract notion, whereas other people think conformance is what a conformance checker tells you by applying the mechanistic conformance rules that the specification specifies

[03:30:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Philip`: ITYM s/specification/DTD/

[03:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
and they don't accept a notion of conformance where you can't even tell whether a document conforms to HTML5 by looking at its bytes, never mind telling whether it conforms to a more complex set of specification documents

[03:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
hsivonen: I'm imagining those hypothetical people would accept any kind of schema language, not just DTD

[03:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
as long as it's one you can feed into a schema checker tool and get a boolean output

[03:32:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[03:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
They're not the same people who decided to hard-code DTDs into XML (or they're the same people but in the future, where they've realised other schema languages might be better)

[04:08:00.0000] <jre>
othermaciej, hixie: yes, RFC 2616 does allow wextension methods (http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/rfc2616.html#rfc.section.5.1.1)

[04:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
how about response codes?

[04:15:00.0000] <jre>
Hixie, same thing (http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/rfc2616.html#rfc.section.6.1.1)

[04:16:00.0000] <jre>
I mean, it's easy to check so I was confused about the confusion over here

[04:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
extension-code doesn't seem to have any semantic meaning defined anywhere

[04:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
or are you saying I could return HTTP/1.1 999 OK and it would be conforming?

[04:18:00.0000] <jre>
according to the ABNF yes

[04:18:01.0000] <jre>
according to the prose in 6.1.1 no

[04:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
so is it conforming or not?

[04:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
i can't see anything saying it isn't

[04:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
which seems suboptimal

[04:20:00.0000] <jre_>
"The first digit of the Status-Code defines the class of response. The last two digits do not have any categorization role. There are 5 values for the first digit:"

[04:21:00.0000] <jre_>
...

[04:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
so HTTP/1.1 199 OK is conforming?

[04:21:02.0000] <jre_>
yes

[04:21:03.0000] <Hixie>
that seems... bad?

[04:21:04.0000] <jre_>
why?

[04:21:05.0000] <Hixie>
what does it mean?

[04:21:06.0000] <jre_>
ask the status code registry

[04:22:00.0000] <jre_>
if the recipient doesn't understand it, treat it as 100

[04:22:01.0000] <jre_>
"However, applications MUST understand the class of any status code, as indicated by the first digit, and treat any unrecognized response as being equivalent to the x00 status code of that class, with the exception that an unrecognized response MUST NOT be cached."

[04:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
ah, ok, so http uses a registry-based centralised extensibility mechanism

[04:22:03.0000] <Hixie>
ok

[04:23:00.0000] <jre>
The question was: does HTTP allow extension methods or status codes, and the answer is "yes". How they are registered is orthogonal.

[04:23:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Does it allow new classes? E.g. 7xx codes

[04:23:02.0000] <Hixie>
i'm just trying to learn about the various extension mechanisms

[04:23:03.0000] <jre>
Dashiva, no

[04:23:04.0000] <Hixie>
maybe what html5 says is rarer than i thought

[04:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
(does anything actually require that extension-codes be registered before they are used?)

[04:24:01.0000] <jre>
not in RFC 2616, the status code registry was introduced later

[04:24:02.0000] <Hixie>
so what does 199 mean if it's not in the registry?

[04:25:00.0000] <jre>
http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/rfc2817.html#rfc.section.7.1

[04:25:01.0000] <jre>
it means the same thing as 100 for recipients that don't understand it

[04:25:02.0000] <jre>
so a definition of 199 would need to be consistent with the generic status code 100

[04:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
but no definition need exist before i start using it?

[04:26:01.0000] <Hixie>
per http?

[04:26:02.0000] <Lachy>
Leif's response seems confusing. She seems to be suggesting that putting extensions through the W3C process is good, while at the same time advocating methods for arbitrary extensions that bypass that.

[04:26:03.0000] <jre>
RFC 2817 updates RFC 2616 and requires you to register the code

[04:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
oh so the lack of requiring a registry was a bug?

[04:27:01.0000] <jre>
if you don't register you are on your own with respect to collisions, nothing new here

[04:27:02.0000] <Hixie>
(where does 2817 actually require that the codes be registered? i can't see that anywhere)

[04:28:00.0000] <jre>
there are extension points that don't even have a registry today, simply because nobody has asked for it yet 

[04:28:01.0000] <jre>
I think range extensions fall into the category

[04:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
seems weird to have extension points that allow arbitrary values without needing them to be defined

[04:28:03.0000] <jre>
you can always write a standards track RFC which updates RFC 2616, and then you're safe (as long as the IESG pays attention)

[06:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
Is it intentional that the discussion about "drawfocus()" seems to be talking about something quite different to the spec's drawFocusRing()?

[06:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
since the latter is meant to be something you call for every element that you draw, regardless of whether it's focused or not, and it will only draw if the element is focused

[06:38:01.0000] <Philip`>
but people seem to be talking about some kind of method that you only call on focused elements, or on elements that you want to become focused

[17:37:00.0000] <Lachy>

[17:37:01.0000] <Lachy>
<Lachy> Hixie, re: using HTTP URLs for Microdata itemtype, does it have to be a URL at all? http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-January/024770.html

[17:37:02.0000] <Lachy>
<Lachy> The problem I have with using URLs for this, and for namespaces in general, is that formats will most likely out-last the organisation that created them and assigned the namespace or itemtype URL 

[17:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
what should we use instead? people didn't like the reverse-dns identifiers

[17:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
and urls are what rdf uses already

[17:38:02.0000] <Hixie>
users didn't have any problems dealing with urls in the studies, fwiw

[17:38:03.0000] <Lachy>
I know that, and realise we're stuck with URLs, at least for RDF conversion.

[17:39:00.0000] <Lachy>
I just don't like the idea of tying widely used metadata formats to one particular organisation.

[17:39:01.0000] <Hixie>
*shrug*

[17:39:02.0000] <Lachy>
and one of the problems that has occured with namespaces is that there's no widely used convention for how the URLs should be structured, so we've ended up with a wide range of confusing, non-memorable URLs

[17:40:00.0000] <Lachy>
which often contain effectively meaningless stuff like the years in the older W3C namespaces

[17:42:00.0000] <Lachy>
e.g. compare http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml, http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom (note the unexpected capital A), http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace

[17:43:00.0000] <Lachy>
so I would prefer that we could come up with a simpler, predictable format for itemtype, which identify the format, without identifying the organisation that happened to define it

[17:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
this is not a battle i want to engage in, but if you can find a solution that i can adopt without having to spend effort defending, i'll happily do so

[17:46:00.0000] <Lachy>
I also assume that using a centralised registry won't go down well either, since one of the claimed benefits I've heard for using URLs, is that it piggy backs on top of the existing DNS registry

[17:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
long term i think we need to support URLs anyway, given the volume of vocabularies already using them, and if we have to support _two_ mechanisms, that may be worse than URLs, however good the alternative mechanism

[17:47:01.0000] <Hixie>
which may be an argument for not bothering

[17:47:02.0000] <Hixie>
(it was the argument against reverse-dns -- it just wasn't enough of a gain to be worth it)

[17:48:00.0000] <Lachy>
hmm, ok. That does suck that we have to continue to suffer from the mistakes of RDF and namespaces :-(

[17:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
just like we have to suffer from SVG's design mistakes

[17:49:01.0000] <Lachy>
btw, is there any plan to switch the itemtypes from using n.whatwg.org URLs to W3C URLs, or is the intention just to keep those permanently, regardless of whatever eventually happens with microdata?

[17:49:02.0000] <Hixie>
and just like people in the future will have to deal with ours

[17:49:03.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. the storage mutex

[17:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
i don't intend to change anything

[17:50:01.0000] <Lachy>
ok

[17:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
of course if the w3c can provide a better URL (-> shorter, memorable) before that one gains usage, then i don't see why we wouldn't use it

[17:52:00.0000] <Lachy>
it's going to be nice when spammers inevitably take over whatwg.org and start serving ads or even malicious content from those URLs

[17:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
i wish i could renew domains for more than 1 year at a time

[17:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'd just renew it for 100 years if i could

[17:53:02.0000] <Lachy>
that depends which provider you register it through

[17:53:03.0000] <Hixie>
dreamhost

[17:54:00.0000] <Lachy>
I thought the maximum permitted by the .com registry was about 10 years

[17:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's already pretty miserly

[17:54:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe DNS won't exist in 100 years, then you wasted your money.

[17:55:00.0000] <Lachy>
but I once saw one registrar use a loophole to allow 100 year registrations, where they would register it for 10 and promise to keep renewing it automatically

[17:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
AryehGregor: it's ok, by then the money would have been worthless anyway :-P

[22:32:00.0000] <beilabs>

[23:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
hmm

[23:59:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: ayt?

[23:59:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I guess you are since you just said something

[23:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
hey

[23:59:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I have a hopefully brief question relating to a WebKit bug

[00:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>
someone submitted a patch that would cache the actual NodeList objects returned by getElementsByTagName, getElementsByTagNameNS, getElementsByName, and getElementsByClassName

[00:00:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so if called on the same node with the same parameter twice, they would return the same value

[00:00:02.0000] <othermaciej>
DOM Level 3 Core seems to explicitly forbid this for gEBTN and gEBTNNS

[00:00:03.0000] <othermaciej>
but for the two specified in HTML5, it does not say one way or the other

[00:01:00.0000] <othermaciej>
here is the bug: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=33696

[00:01:01.0000] <othermaciej>
my comment links the relevant spec sections: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=33696#c17

[00:01:02.0000] <othermaciej>
my question to you is whether HTML5's silence on whether these methods return a new object is meant to intentionally diverge from DOM Core and allow caching, or if it's just an oversight and is actually supposed to match DOM Core

[00:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
the latter

[00:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>
ok

[00:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
can you file a bug for that?

[00:04:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I will

[00:04:03.0000] <Hixie>
thanks

[00:04:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it would be better if DOM 3 Core and HTML5 both allowed caching, but it certainly seems bad for them to differ

[00:04:05.0000] <othermaciej>
so probably the right thing to do is fix it in DOM Core first

[00:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
i would rather scripts always get reliably a new object

[00:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
so that they don't start getting non-interoperable behaviour if they're messing with properties on these objects

[00:05:02.0000] <Hixie>
either it should always return the same object or never, imho

[00:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that is indeed somewhat safer to always return a new object

[00:06:01.0000] <Hixie>
it seems like it'd be relatively easy to implement wrappers that make it seem like they're new objects while being mostly the same object internally

[00:06:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the only reason I was enthused about the caching is that I think setting custom properties on NodeLists is kinda rare, and the performance win seems really big

[00:06:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that is in fact what we do currently

[00:06:04.0000] <Hixie>
what's most of the win from?

[00:06:05.0000] <Hixie>
is creating JS objects that expensive?

[00:07:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I believe most of the win is from not allocating the JS-level wrapper, but it's not my patch and I did not do profiling so I can't say for sure

[00:07:01.0000] <Hixie>
ah

[00:07:02.0000] <Hixie>
maybe you can do copy-on-write magic or something

[00:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that's not really practical to do with JS objects

[00:08:01.0000] <othermaciej>
they can easily share all their innards but be different wrappers, and we do that already (essentially)

[00:08:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but you can't have two pointers to the same JS-level wrapper turn different later

[00:08:03.0000] <othermaciej>
so there's no way to avoid doing an allocation on every call with the current requirements

[00:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
seems like you should be able to add one level of indirection -- one pointer and one bit, in fact -- but i guess the code complexity would be disproportionate

[00:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
and i guess the cost could be prohibitive

[00:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
relative to the win

[00:10:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it's really the fixed overhead of allocating the JS wrapper that I believe is the expensive part, so adding a level of indirection would not help, since the indirect part would have to be allocated as a JS value itself

[00:10:03.0000] <othermaciej>
to work with the GC

[00:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
ah, yeah

[00:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
surely your JS wrappers are all fixed-size and can be arena allocated really cheaply

[00:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
seems odd that that would be the expensive bit

[00:13:01.0000] <Hixie>
allocating the actual NodeList, sure

[00:15:00.0000] <othermaciej>
GC allocation ain't cheap

[00:15:01.0000] <othermaciej>
allocating the C++-level NodeList might be a big part of the cost too, and in theory we can have distinct wrappers for the same C++-level NodeList

[00:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think our caching right now is of an object that's shared by multiple C++ NodeLists

[00:16:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I can suggest trying that to the contributor and see if returning the same actual JS-level NodeLists still looks like a big win after

[00:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
filed http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=8792

[00:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
with the caveat that i am talking out of my nether regions, it seems like getting GC structures to allocate fast would be a good win in general

[00:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
but i expect you have experts who are better positioned to work out this kind of thing :0)

[00:17:03.0000] <Hixie>
:-) even

[00:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
/me poured water on his macbook pro yesterday and has been relegated to an X41

[00:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
running Windows

[00:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
what a life

[00:18:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I am sure JSC and V8 have both put a good bit of work into tuning our respective GC allocators

[00:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there are some fundamental limits

[00:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[00:19:02.0000] <othermaciej>
in the case of this test it's not just the allocation, but the fact that you are creating lots of garbage

[00:19:03.0000] <othermaciej>
and every garbage JSNodeList needs to have a finalizer

[00:19:04.0000] <Hixie>
makes sense

[00:19:05.0000] <othermaciej>
that will strain any GC algorithm I know of

[00:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway I r-'d the patch for now

[00:21:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I am finding that a lot more WebKit contributors are submitting stuff lately that I have to r- because it directly violates a spec, without apparent compatibility need (or similarly good reason)

[00:21:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I am not sure what to do about this

[00:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
also I am far from the only reviewer so I wonder how much of that sorta thing is slipping through

[00:22:01.0000] <othermaciej>
not that it's your problem

[00:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
yeah i dunno what the solution is

[00:22:03.0000] <Hixie>
what other kind of stuff has there been?

[00:24:00.0000] <othermaciej>
one that I specifically recall is someone submitting a patch to implement HTML5 footer that tried to enforce the content model in the parser

[00:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
i.e. it would actually reparent on an attempt to nest <footer> elements

[00:24:02.0000] <Hixie>
oh yeah, i saw that one

[00:24:03.0000] <Hixie>
that seems like a pretty fundamental failure to read the spec

[00:24:04.0000] <Hixie>
some of the feedback on the mailing lists has been like that too

[00:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
standards are complex

[00:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and it can take a while to get up to speed on some of the basic concepts

[02:16:00.0000] <Lachy>
othermaciej, why are we going to do a new CfC for publishing Microdata?

[02:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Lachy: the new CfC will be for HTML5, Microdata, 2D Context, and HTML+RDFa to all get first or new Working Drafts

[02:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Lachy: reasons for a new CfC are threefold:

[02:18:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(a) some of the objections from the first one will be addressed by Hixie's changes

[02:18:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(b) the HTML5 proposed for publication originally will be materially changed by the further splitting of 2D Context

[02:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(c) may as well just have one CfC for everything we want to publish

[08:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
"User agents may wait for a suitable break in the user's interaction before queuing the task; for example, a user agent could wait for the user to have not hit a key for 100ms, so as to only fire the event when the user pauses, instead of continuously for each keystroke."

[08:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So I guess this means we need to use onkeypress or onkeyup instead of oninput?

[08:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
If we really want to have it be per key.

[08:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess there's no event that fires after the input has happened, so that it will reliably fire once each keystroke and event.target.value will be the current value?

[08:17:00.0000] <Philip`>
Why would you want such a thing?

[08:17:01.0000] <Philip`>
What do you expect it to do with input methods where you use multiple keystrokes to insert a single character?

[08:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Just give the current value after whatever the user just entered.  Really I want an event whenever the contents of the form field change, with the new value of the field.

[08:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
For using <datalist>.

[08:18:02.0000] <Philip`>
Why is 100ms latency unacceptable?

[08:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I want to dispatch the new contents to my backend to ask for suggestions.

[08:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Because the result has to be thrown out if the form value is no longer the same when the suggestion returns, and there already may be a significant round-trip delay.

[08:19:01.0000] <Philip`>
You'd have to implement some kind of buffering yourself anyway, because you don't want to send a request to the backend after every keystroke if the user's typing really really fast and has a dialup connection

[08:21:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me tries to figure out if MW already buffers

[08:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It looks like we usually wait 250 ms, except if the user hits the down arrow.

[08:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
We use keyup, keydown, keypress, blur, and focus, but of course we also use a <div> positioning hack right now to generate the results.

[08:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Probably we don't need to hook blur and focus with datalist.

[08:23:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Using datalists via JS is really ugly, by the way.

[08:23:03.0000] <Philip`>
Given that pages will have to implement some kind of buffering if some browsers don't buffer themselves, it seems silly for the spec to say "may" - it should require buffering for all browsers or none

[08:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'd really prefer just input.suggest = ['Foo', 'Bar'] instead of creating a datalist element, making up an id, giving it the id, setting the input's list attribute, and looping through the result list to add <option> children.

[08:24:01.0000] <Philip`>
(maybe)

[08:24:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, yeah, "may" is a pain.

[08:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
Author feedback from attempting to use the element is a good thing to have :-)

[08:26:00.0000] <Lachy>
AryehGregor, datalist is useful to have when the choices are a fixed list, so they can just be listed in the page and not have to worry about being modified by scripts

[08:26:01.0000] <Lachy>
but maybe we need an optimised API for the scripted use cases that dynamically change the list

[08:26:03.0000] <Lachy>

[08:26:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:27:01.0000] <Lachy>

[16:08:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[16:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[16:14:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm baffled by the number of people who don't want the spec to encourage user agents to try to make things better for AT users in the face of authoring mistakes

[16:14:01.0000] <Hixie>
why do people want to pubish users for authoring mistakes?

[16:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's like the whole draconican parsing thing all over again

[16:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I think people are either misreading the spec, or buying into a subtle argument about giving authors incorrect expectations

[16:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, I think they're mostly asking to rephrase to be vaguer at this point, aren't they?

[16:16:02.0000] <Lachy>
I don't think people are opposed to ATs providing a better user experience. They seem to be opposed to the spec setting seemingly unrealistic requirements and somehow giving authors unrealistic expectaions and choosing not to give alternative text

[16:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
+1 to Lachy.

[16:18:00.0000] <Lachy>
and since the purpose of the statement in the spec is to give implementations permission to use alternative techniques, it seems reasonable to say so without indicating what those techniques may be, especially when it could be misconstrued as referring to futuristic technologies

[16:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That is, I certainly don't want to punish users because authors were bad.  It totally makes sense that image-reading heuristics, when they exist and are practical, should be used in the absence of @alt.

[16:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
OCR is not a futuristic technology

[16:19:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it would probably fine to say that if alt is missing, UAs can present any other information they are able to get in lieu of a text alternative

[16:19:02.0000] <Lachy>
I don't think it's clear to everyone that "image analysis heuristics" refers to things like OCR.

[16:19:03.0000] <othermaciej>
and if specific examples are listed at all, they should be clearly realistic examples like using the filename or performing OCR

[16:20:00.0000] <Lachy>
people seem to be thinking it refers to some kind of futuristic AI, that can look at a picture and determine what it is and what it means in context

[16:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
there is shipping technology today that does painting recognition, OCR, landmark recognition, etc, on arbitrary images

[16:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
which would really help users who can't see images

[16:20:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
"User agents may also apply image analysis heuristics…" does seem to imply that such heuristics exist, when outside of OCR they don't reliably.

[16:21:00.0000] <Lachy>
yes, but those things, like Google Goggles, require large collections of sample images with which to compare the subject image with

[16:21:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there are in fact heuristics that can recognize all kinds of images other than images of text

[16:21:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Outside of images of text, though, you run into the intent problem.  A description of the image may not be valid alt text.

[16:21:03.0000] <Hixie>
sure

[16:21:04.0000] <othermaciej>
mostly either research projects, or somewhat experimental, and often requiring a huge corpus

[16:21:05.0000] <Hixie>
but it's better than nothing!

[16:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's not even that clear to me how I'd use the shipping Google Goggles to build an accessibility feature for a UA - uploading every image that lacks alt text seems like a bad idea for both bandwidth and privacy reasons

[16:23:00.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, I just think you should try to find a way that makes the intent of the statement clear, without making people think the spec is setting unrealistic expectations

[16:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that being said, it seems like a much more general statement would both be less objectionable, and more broadly applicable

[16:23:02.0000] <Hixie>
well i'd be happy to make the text even vaguer so long as we still explicitly allow such behaviour

[16:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
(no bug was ever filed for this as far as i know, btw)

[16:25:00.0000] <Lachy>
personally, I thought image analysis heuristics was a rather general statement already, and I don't agree with most of the rationale that was given in the change proposal

[16:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
yeah i'm not exactly sure how to make it vaguer

[16:25:02.0000] <Lachy>
maybe use less jargon

[16:28:00.0000] <Lachy>
Change it to "User agents may also utilise any other available techniques or technologies to help the user make sense of the image when the user is unable to make direct use of the image, ..."

[16:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
well it's not _any_ other

[16:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. iirc we explicitly discourage use of the filename

[16:29:02.0000] <Hixie>
since that has been shown to hurt more than help

[16:30:00.0000] <Lachy>
that's an implementation decision though. There's no reason to have the spec explicitly disallow it

[16:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think it might also help to say "get information about the image" instead of "make sense of the image"

[16:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
since the latter seems to be what makes people think the technology described is science-fictional

[16:31:02.0000] <Lachy>
also, the file name is not always useless. It is when it's a bunch of random letters or numbers, but if the AT recognises the file name as being readable words (e.g. by checking a dictionary), then why not use the file name as a last resort?

[16:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, many filenames are bad, but not all - the best thing would be for AT to use heuristics to determine if the file name is human-understandable

[16:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
i could live with that

[16:34:00.0000] <Lachy>
Here the suggested text again with some changes: "User agents may also utilise any other available techniques or technologies to help the user obtain information about the image when the user is unable to make direct use of the image, ..."

[16:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
sounds wishy washy

[16:35:01.0000] <Lachy>
yep

[16:35:02.0000] <Hixie>
we should just come out and say what we mean

[16:35:03.0000] <othermaciej>
if you can find text that people find satisfactory then I'd be happy to try to put this one through as an amicable resolution

[16:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: re the thread with the guy who wants to do concatenation with microdata

[16:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
TabAtkins: it's a bad idea for us to make <div itemscope itemtype="http://example.com/"><span itemprop="a/b"/></div> mean the same as <div itemscope itemtype="http://example.com/a/"><span itemprop="b"/></div>

[16:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
which is why microdata goes to such lengths to make sure that can't happen

[16:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
he should just use owl:equivalentProperty if he's using RDF, the same way the work vocabulary does

[17:04:00.0000] <Lachy>
does such concatenation work in RDFa? e.g. is <span xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/terms/" property="dc:title"> the same as <span xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/" property="dc:terms/title">?

[17:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
Lachy: That's just CURIEs, not anything specific to RDFa

[17:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
RDFa just gets full URIs from its CURIE processor, it doesn't care how they're split up

[17:11:01.0000] <Philip`>
(in theory)

[17:11:02.0000] <Lachy>
so, then both of those would be semantically identical for RDF?

[17:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
yes

[17:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
that's one of the biggest problems with RDFa, imho

[23:28:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: I don't have enough data right now to say if I want doc='' to be sync or async

[23:28:01.0000] <hsivonen>
currently, the HTML5 parser in Gecko has no way of parsing a full document from an UTF-16 string

[23:29:00.0000] <hsivonen>
it can only parse a full doc (in an async way) from a byte stream or a fragment (in a sync way) from an UTF-16 string

[23:30:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Does sync load include waiting for external stylesheets/scripts blocking?

[23:31:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Dashiva: well, if doc='' can load stylesheets, scripts or XBL, making it sync would be bad

[23:32:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I haven't yet examined the dependencies of doc='', hence not enough data

[01:15:05.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:15:06.0000] <workmad3>
MikeSmith: and clean slate is great from an academic and developer perspective, but the biggest driver (business) would resist it like the plague, for fairly good reasons

[01:16:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:16:01.0000] <workmad3>

[01:17:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[01:18:00.0000] <workmad3>
MikeSmith: you're pretty much spot on there :)

[01:19:00.0000] <workmad3>
TCP fails when a network that needs speed more than reliability, and performs atrociously over a low reliability network

[01:19:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hey, I got something right

[01:19:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
I think it's the first time this week

[01:19:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
/me pats himself on the back

[01:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me saw some people saying how TCP fails sometimes in data center networks because it has hundreds-of-milliseconds timeouts on packet loss even if the latency is far less than that

[01:20:01.0000] <workmad3>
but then, that's why networks that need speed implement their own reliability mechanisms (using a different model than TCP) on top of raw UDP packets :)

[01:21:00.0000] <workmad3>
e.g. game servers

[01:21:01.0000] <Philip`>
Games sometimes use UDP simply to get around NATs

[01:22:00.0000] <workmad3>
that said, TCP works, it works pretty well for what it does and is, and I don't think it's going anywhere anytime soon

[01:22:01.0000] <workmad3>
/me waits to be proven wrong

[01:25:03.0000] <Hixie>

[01:28:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: true, and there's big difference between a technology that was fundamentally sound of the use cases it was intended for and specced out for at time, and one for which the spec was inadequate/ambiguous to the point where implementers ended up implementing it in non-interoperable ways

[02:37:00.0000] <Lachy>
Hixie, othermaciej, I had another go at rewriting the image analsis heuristics text

[02:37:01.0000] <Lachy>
---

[02:37:02.0000] <Lachy>
When the user is unable to make direct use of the image, e.g. due to a visual disability or because they are using a text terminal with no graphics capabilities, user agents may also provide the user with the ability to obtain any other information about the image that may assist the user in understanding the content or purpose of the image, utilising any available repair technique.

[02:37:03.0000] <Lachy>
Such techniques may be based on information from any relevant source including, but not limited to, the following suggestions:

[02:37:04.0000] <Lachy>
* Obtaining the file name from the URL reference or HTTP headers supplied with the resource, such as the Content-Location or Content-Disposition header fields.

[02:37:05.0000] <Lachy>
* Extracting human readable metadata embedded within the resource. e.g. EXIF or RDF embedded within the resource.

[02:37:06.0000] <Lachy>
* Referring to alternative text associated with another instance of the same resource on the page,

[02:37:07.0000] <Lachy>
* Applying OCR techniques to recognise and extract textual content that is graphically represented on the image.

[02:37:08.0000] <Lachy>
For more information, refer to the User Agent Accessibility Guidelines techniques for repairing missing content ([UAAG10-TECHS], section 2.7).

[02:37:09.0000] <Lachy>
---

[02:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Lachy: post it to the list I guess and see if people like it

[02:38:01.0000] <Lachy>
ok. What do you think of it?

[02:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Lachy: should XMP metadata be mentioned?

[02:40:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Larry cited it

[02:40:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not sure if it actually consists of RDF or not

[02:40:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Lachy: looks good to me in general though

[02:43:00.0000] <Lachy>
I don't know either. But UAAG mentioned RDF embedded in the resource, so I figured that and EXIF would be enough for examples

[02:48:00.0000] <jgraham>
The file name is bad unless human readable.

[02:49:00.0000] <jgraham>
>So it should either say "the human readable part of the file name" or (perhaps better) we shouldn't bother enumerating all these techniques

[03:04:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[03:10:00.0000] <Lachy>

[03:15:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[03:15:01.0000] <hsivonen>
as is talking about human-readable data in EXIF

[03:16:00.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: Some EXIF has human readable data

[03:16:01.0000] <jgraham>
But it is typically not a replacement for an image in context

[03:17:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
alt -- as found on the web -- is typically not a replacement for an image in context

[03:17:01.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: e.g. http://www.flickr.com/photos/carpeicthus/4291505464/meta/

[03:17:02.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: I don't have numbers, but I'd expect human-readable data that isn't either the photographer name or keywords derived from coordinates using geonames to be exceedingly rare

[03:18:00.0000] <hsivonen>
jgraham: does any EXIF spec formalize the <a href> stuff seen there?

[03:18:01.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: I think that typical photo editing software allows you to add a description to the exif

[03:18:02.0000] <zcorpan__>
hmm, <input type=image> coordinates either changed in implementations since last i tested or my testing was bogus last time

[03:19:00.0000] <hsivonen>
also, that data seems something that anyone who'd write it in the first place would want to present as part of the HTML page to all readers

[03:19:01.0000] <jgraham>
hsivonen: I doubt it; that is for flickr's benefit

[03:19:02.0000] <jgraham>

[03:19:03.0000] <hsivonen>

[08:06:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Is JF saying that if we can't be sure about author intent, we should abandon all attempts at doing anything useful?

[08:35:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dashiva: It's strange, but that's the vibe I get too.

[08:37:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I'm guessing it's a particular manifestation of "perfect is the enemy of good".

[08:42:00.0000] <webben>
Dashiva: I don't think so.

[08:43:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I can't imagine he would, but I'm having trouble reading it any other way

[08:43:01.0000] <webben>
I think he's just saying the spec should not imply feasibility of "non-existent techniques".

[08:46:00.0000] <webben>
and taking the phrase "image analysis heuristics" to imply technology that can determine author intent.

[08:47:00.0000] <webben>
I think that's a stretch, but meh.

[08:47:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Yes, that

[08:47:02.0000] <Dashiva>
is reasonable, until someone tells you that's not what it means :)

[08:52:00.0000] <webben>
Dashiva: Yeah, but even from that point, you can still make assertions that the spec's language implies something different that what is meant (or is ambiguous).

[08:53:00.0000] <webben>
Dashiva: hence his citing of a dictionary definition of heuristics, I guess.

[08:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Protip: As soon as you're citing dictionary definitions, you've lost the argument.

[08:55:01.0000] <webben>
Not really sure that's true.

[08:56:00.0000] <webben>
Not when you're discussing what does a blob of text imply, anyhow.

[08:56:01.0000] <webben>
That is, there's a difference between an argument about essences and an argument about phrasing.

[08:56:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I find that even in that sort of dicussion, whipping out a dictionary means the argument is officially over and you're on the losing side.

[08:56:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's like godwining.

[08:57:00.0000] <webben>
A /better/ argument, I find is to point to examples of other readers reading it that way.

[08:57:01.0000] <webben>
But - that's more expensive.

[05:06:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:07:00.0000] <jcranmer>

[05:07:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:08:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:08:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:08:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:10:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:10:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:11:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:12:01.0000] <jcranmer>

[05:13:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:13:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:13:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[05:14:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:14:01.0000] <jcranmer>
the current theory on Bilski is that it will pretty much kill business method patents but keep software patents in limbo for another case

[05:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The Supreme Court likes ruling narrowly, yeah.

[05:15:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Except on letting businesses buy politicians :P

[05:15:01.0000] <jcranmer>
SCotUS is also a big fan of narrowing patentability

[05:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Dashiva, no, it ruled narrowly there too.  The opinion of the court said they only considered constitutionality because they had no other option, since the corporation was clearly in violation of the law as written.

[05:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I guess they could have artificially restricted themselves to not-for-profits or something.

[05:16:02.0000] <Dashiva>
But they ruled in the general case, much wider than the specific instance the case was about

[05:17:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, yeah.  They don't rule only for one specific case, but they decide only as much law as necessary to decide that case.

[05:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So if they can reasonably make a ruling on Bilski that only covers business-method patents, probably they'll do so.

[05:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
But one never knows.

[05:19:00.0000] <jcranmer>
basically, they'll probably kill the State Street test "useful, tangible result"

[05:20:00.0000] <jcranmer>
which puts software patents on shaky grounds (Diamond v. Diehr held that software per se was unpatentable)

[13:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
You need a URL encoding function that encodes characters like #

[13:56:01.0000] <Philip`>
and I imagine it's easy to pick a function that isn't quite right

[13:57:00.0000] <foolip>
and with srcdoc you only need to escale < and " ?

[13:57:01.0000] <foolip>
escape

[13:59:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Yes

[14:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
No

[14:00:01.0000] <Philip`>
& and "

[14:01:00.0000] <foolip>
so there's no browser that would be confused by e.g. <a href="</a>">?

[14:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
No, as far as I'm aware

[14:02:01.0000] <Philip`>
(It's not well-formed XML, though)

[14:02:02.0000] <foolip>
that's surprising, but good if it's true

[14:03:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Yeah, as long as you get the " right you're "safe"

[14:03:01.0000] <Dashiva>
And if you don't, then it'll most likely break visibly all over the place

[14:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
foolip: It's not just the escaping.  Legacy concerns exist too - legacy browsers that understand data: but not @sandbox will show your content without sandbox security measures.

[14:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think that using text/sandboxed-html in the data: url would fix that, though.

[14:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't think escaping is a really compelling reason here.  urlencode() should work fine here, no?

[14:16:01.0000] <Philip`>
What is urlencode?

[14:17:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I mean, it's more complicated if you're writing things from scratch, but I assume you're using a normal programming language that supports basic Internet-related escape functions.

[14:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
PHP's urlencode(), for instance.

[14:17:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or Python/Perl/Ruby/etc. equivalents.

[14:17:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
"Returns a string in which all non-alphanumeric characters except -_. have been replaced with a percent (%) sign followed by two hex digits and spaces encoded as plus (+) signs."

[14:17:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
http://us.php.net/manual/en/function.urlencode.php

[14:17:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
That would work fine, right?

[14:17:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
But it would look a lot uglier, and you'd have the extra data:text/sandboxed-html,<!doctype html> boilerplate.

[14:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
Encoding spaces as + won't work

[14:18:01.0000] <Philip`>
See e.g. data:text/html,a+b

[14:18:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The + isn't translated to a space there?

[14:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then I agree it's more of a pain.

[14:18:04.0000] <Philip`>
No

[14:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
What does urlencode do with Unicode?

[14:19:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
You have to escape it as %20

[14:19:02.0000] <Dashiva>
That's the point, isn't it? Encoding data: is too easy to do wrong

[14:19:03.0000] <Philip`>
by which I mean: I assume urlencode doesn't do anything with Unicode, since PHP is stupid

[14:19:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
It probably treats it as binary.

[14:19:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
So if the input string is UTF-8, it will encode as UTF-8.

[14:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
so I guess it's okay iff you store strings internally with UTF-8 encoding before passing to urlencode

[14:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, granted, this is more complicated than necessary.

[14:20:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
The result of urlencode("…") is %E2%80%A6.

[14:20:03.0000] <Philip`>
If you do a simple replace-"-and-& encoder then you don't have to worry about encodings (or at least no more than for any other user input displayed on your site), since the input and output encodings will be identical

[14:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
(whereas URL encoding requires UTF-8 output, which is a pain if the input isn't UTF-8)

[14:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, only if you save the file as UTF-8.  Save it as UTF-16 and try again.  (Probably PHP will barf because it's not ASCII-compatible, though.)

[14:22:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or try any other encoding.

[14:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
For literals, it just goes by the format of the file.

[14:23:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Well, I'm passing the character in through a GET param.

[14:24:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I don't know what the implications of that are wrt encodings.

[14:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then it probably decodes the GET param as binary.

[14:24:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
PHP just treats everything as binary.

[14:24:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's actually very simple.

[14:24:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Really, all I know is that when things occasionally save as Windows-1252 I get pissed.)

[14:25:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I certainly understand Unicode and it's encodings, but I don't understand why there has to be so many compat problems between various levels.  >_<

[14:34:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Can anyone go test Python and/or Ruby real quick to see what they do when you pass "a b" to their url escaping function?

[14:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, >>> import urllib

[14:58:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
>>> urllib.quote("a b")

[14:58:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
'a%20b'

[15:02:00.0000] <Dashiva>
See what happens with < and " too

[15:04:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
>>> import urllib

[15:04:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
>>> urllib.quote("a b")

[15:04:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
'a%20b'

[15:04:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
>>> urllib.quote("a/b")

[15:04:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
'a/b'

[15:04:05.0000] <mpilgrim>
>>> urllib.quote("a/b", safe="")

[15:04:06.0000] <mpilgrim>
'a%2Fb'

[15:04:07.0000] <mpilgrim>
>>> urllib.quote_plus("a b")

[15:04:08.0000] <mpilgrim>
'a+b'

[15:05:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
(that's python 2.6.1, for TabAtkins)

[15:05:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
mpilgrim, . . . were you, like, reading the logs and came on IRC specifically to say that?

[15:05:02.0000] <Dashiva>
mpilgrim: What about " and <?

[15:05:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
yes

[15:06:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
>>> urllib.quote('a"b')

[15:06:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
'a%22b'

[15:06:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
>>> urllib.quote('a<b')

[15:06:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
'a%3Cb'

[15:07:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Neat, Google Reader suggested an RSS feed that contained a personal attack on me.

[15:07:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Never had that happen before.

[15:07:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Woo!

[15:07:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Thanks, mpilgrim.

[15:07:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Is / safe in data urls?

[15:07:05.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:37:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
All right, so, data urls vs @srcdoc.  What are the problems again?  (I'll list the ones I know, see if I missed any before I send this email.)

[07:38:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
1) data urls will work in current UAs that don't understand sandbox, thus "failing open".  Will the sandboxed html mime type help with this?

[07:38:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
2) data urls have more difficult escaping requirements.  Possibly not.  PHP escapes things correctly with rawurlencode, python also has a built-in function that will do it properly.

[07:38:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
3) ?

[07:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
1) Yes, sandboxed HTML MIME type should solve that problem, I think.

[07:39:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Maybe something with origins?  data urls are automatically unique-origin, right?  Could @sandbox=allow-same-origin just special-case override that?

[07:39:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
3) You can save some annoying boilerplate with srcdoc="".

[07:39:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Just the "text/html;charset=utf8" bit, right?

[07:40:00.0000] <Dashiva>
And the doctype

[07:40:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:14:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:14:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:53:01.0000] <Philip`>

[08:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:54:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[08:55:00.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:55:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[08:55:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Once you've got one, you just multiply by roots of unity.

[08:56:01.0000] <workmad3>
gsnedders: √π is the square root of π

[08:56:02.0000] <workmad3>
it's a multi-valued function

[08:56:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you take the principal nth root of x, the other nth roots are just that times e^(2k*i*pi/n), k = 1, ..., n -1.

[08:56:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
The principal square root function is not multi-valued.

[08:57:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Indeed.

[08:57:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That only becomes a real problem with complex numbers.

[08:57:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Where you don't have a continuous single-valued square root function, and there's no obvious candidate for the canonical one.

[08:57:03.0000] <Philip`>
Hmph, that's what I get for copying from a newsgroup posting

[08:57:04.0000] <gsnedders>
/me can't remember e^(2k*i*pi/n), k = 1, ..., n -1 off the top of his head though

[08:57:05.0000] <gsnedders>
/me guesses he must've known it once… like, a year ago.

[08:57:06.0000] <workmad3>
it rings bells

[08:57:07.0000] <Philip`>
It's meant to be 1/10^5*sum(exp(-n^2/(10^10)),n=-infinity..infinity)

[08:58:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Yeah, it looks familiar.

[08:58:01.0000] <workmad3>
haven't done anything serious along those lines since 1st year uni though... so almost 6 years ago now :(

[08:58:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
e^(2k*i*pi/n), k = 0, ..., n - 1 are the nth roots of unity (i.e., the nth roots of 1).

[08:58:03.0000] <Philip`>
Anyway, that equation gives you at least the first 42 billion decimal digits of sqrt(pi)

[08:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[08:59:01.0000] <Philip`>
though it's not equal to sqrt(pi)

[08:59:02.0000] <Philip`>

[10:36:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
I've been talking with some people in #javascript about forms' submit events. Right now, if a user wants to perform validation on a form before submission, or to prevent submission and handle the form asynchronously, the user has to scrape the form to get the value of each element, perform tests for disabled inputs, and special-case inputs like checkboxes to try to replicate the information that the UA has about the form. It's imposs

[10:36:01.0000] <Sidnicious>
get information about, say, which button was pressed to submit the form. I'd be much nicer if all that information were provided in the event.

[10:37:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
Ack, wall of text. I'm mostly curious about where the right place is to introduce the idea: here, the WHATWG list, or some W3C list. I don't know the politics involved here.

[10:40:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
whatwg is fine, or the htmlwg list.  Subscribing to the whatwg list is substantially easier, though.

[10:41:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
What information are you wanting, exactly?  The value of all the form elements, and relevant attributes such as disabled, plus the origin of the submit event?

[11:07:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
TabAtkins: Sorry, was afk. I want access to the data goes into creating the query string or post body, including the button that triggered submit, coordinates on image inputs, the works.

[11:07:01.0000] <Sidnicious>
The simplest implementation that gets us most of the way there would be an array of nodes that were involved in submission — only enabled inputs, only checked checkboxes, only the clicked button. That does not get us information like image coordinates, but it makes form scraping much more reliable: if I want the value of the to-be-submitted form, I just get the name and value of every element in the array.

[11:08:00.0000] <Sidnicious>
There are plenty of other ways this could be implemented. I like the idea of supplying an array of objects, each of which has a key property, a value property, and an node property, so it'd be possible to ignore the elements entirely (and minimize DOM access) and just look at the keys and values from the array.

[11:10:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hmm, that's interesting.

[11:10:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
And your use-case is validation, right?

[07:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:03:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
What kind of useless STS header is that?  500 seconds?

[07:03:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I leave the tab open for ten minutes and MITM starts working again?

[07:04:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:11:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:11:01.0000] <hsivonen>
will users then be locked out of the real service for a long time?

[07:11:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:11:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:12:01.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:12:04.0000] <Rik|work>

[07:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
hsivonen, no, the whole point of STS is 1) attackers could intercept an HTTP request (e.g., from typing "paypal.com" into URL bar) before it gets promoted to HTTPS, 2) users can click through normal cert warnings, but not if STS is set.

[07:13:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Rik|work: yay for APIs that modify behavior depending on call stack

[07:13:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
hsivonen, well, popup windows already do that.

[07:13:03.0000] <Rik|work>
it throws Error: INVALID_STATE_ERR: DOM Exception 11 otherwise

[07:13:04.0000] <hsivonen>
AryehGregor: is the CA lock feature different from STS then?

[07:14:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:14:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2009Sep/att-0051/draft-hodges-strict-transport-sec-05.plain.html#strict-transport-security-http-response-header-field

[07:21:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:21:04.0000] <hsivonen>

[07:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Passwords are really stupid, we should be logging in using some kind of public-key infrastructure where the private key isn't actually exposed to a programmable computer at any point.

[07:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Like it's in a USB device that only provides an API to the computer to let it encode or decode things using the private key, but doesn't actually tell it what it is, so you need the physical device to use the key.

[07:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That could replace all passwords and make it impossible to steal someone's login remotely, whether with phishing or anything else.

[07:23:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
But it would require a whole bunch of infrastructure.

[07:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
Everyone would lose their devices

[07:25:01.0000] <Philip`>

[07:26:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:26:01.0000] <hsivonen>
AryehGregor: hardware dongles FAIL for compatibility reasons

[07:26:02.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, you can get around the "losing" part by entrusting a master copy to someone who won't lose it, like your bank vault.  And have some setup where you can reclaim your accounts even if you lose the device, just like you can reclaim accounts if you forget the password today.

[07:27:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, sharing login details is best accomplished by some form of explicit delegation, not just giving them your login.  But you could share private keys with someone too.

[07:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:28:02.0000] <Philip`>

[07:28:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:29:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[07:29:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[07:30:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

I always thought client and server were just running the same PRNG with the same seed, so it's basically a shared secret, which isn't as good as a public key.

[07:46:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[08:19:03.0000] <Philip`>

[08:20:00.0000] <Philip`>

[08:20:01.0000] <Philip`>

[08:20:02.0000] <Sidnicious>
