[12:12:00.0000] <john_fallows>
is websocket-protocol of empty string supported by draft-hixie-thewebsocketprotocol-68 ?

[12:13:00.0000] <john_fallows>
section 5.1 seems to indicate that server must send back empty string for /subprotocol/ when websocket-protocol header in client handshake is empty string (because it is non-null)

[12:15:00.0000] <Hixie>
how do you mean by "supported"?

[12:15:01.0000] <john_fallows>
i meant permitted by the specification

[12:15:02.0000] <john_fallows>
actually, as i'm trying to explain it, i found something relevant

[12:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
the API won't accept it

[12:16:01.0000] <john_fallows>
if there are any entries in the /headers/ list whose names are the empty string

[12:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
but if a (non-browser) client sends it, the server defines what should happen

[12:16:03.0000] <john_fallows>
this is for names, not values

[12:16:04.0000] <john_fallows>
yep, that's fine

[12:16:05.0000] <Hixie>
er, the protocol spec defines what should happen on the server, i mean

[12:17:00.0000] <john_fallows>
i think there might be a section further up that states the subprotocol value should be non-null and non-empty

[12:17:01.0000] <john_fallows>
yep, got it

[12:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
i guess i don't know what you mean by "permitted by the specification"

[12:17:03.0000] <Hixie>
which specification? there are two

[12:17:04.0000] <Hixie>
the API? the protocol?

[12:17:05.0000] <Hixie>
sent by the client? by the server?

[12:17:06.0000] <john_fallows>
sorry, i was discussing the wire protocol spec draft-hixie-thewebsocketprotocol-68

[12:17:07.0000] <Hixie>
client->server? server->client?

[12:19:00.0000] <john_fallows>
the description of section 5.1 "Sending the server's handshake" /subprotocol/  says...

[12:19:01.0000] <john_fallows>
"Either null, or a string representing the subprotocol the server is ready to use."

[12:19:02.0000] <john_fallows>
...

[12:19:03.0000] <john_fallows>
"The empty string is not the same as the null value for these purposes."

[12:19:04.0000] <john_fallows>
i read that to mean empty string was permitted, but it is not, as described elsewhere in the document

[12:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
there's no concept of what is permitted from the server in the subprotocol name

[12:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
the server just sends back what the client sends

[12:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
if the client sent the empty string, then the server will send the empty string

[12:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
(assuming it wants to accept the connection)

[12:22:01.0000] <john_fallows>
understood

[12:23:00.0000] <john_fallows>
so the constraint of non-empty protocol name is for client only, as described by section 4.1 Handshake (in section 4 Client-side requirements)

[12:23:01.0000] <john_fallows>
"The /resource name/ and /protocol/ strings must be non-empty strings of ASCII characters in the range U+0020 to U+007E."

[12:23:02.0000] <john_fallows>
?

[12:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
right

[12:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
and the API also restricts it

[12:24:02.0000] <john_fallows>
ok, now it makes sense

[12:25:00.0000] <john_fallows>
the difference in strictness between client and server caused my temporary confusion :-)

[12:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
in practice there's no reason for a server to support the subprotocol "", since compliant clients can't send it

[12:26:01.0000] <john_fallows>
yes, agreed.

[12:27:00.0000] <john_fallows>
btw, i have some feedback regarding delivery of binary WebSocket frame payloads to JavaScript

[12:27:01.0000] <john_fallows>
should i send an email to the mailing list?

[12:27:02.0000] <Hixie>
yes please

[12:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
for binary i'm basically waiting for the text stuff to be widely implemented first though

[12:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
baby steps

[12:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
(also waiting for JS to have binary support)

[12:29:00.0000] <john_fallows>
i suspect that waiting for JS to have binary support is unnecessary and will explain the proposal in the email

[12:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
i think it's likely that JS binary support will come long before websocket is widely supported

[00:39:03.0000] <foolip>

[00:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
tiglionabbit: if you have 1->5, 2->5, 3->4, 4->5, you would changeVersion 1 to 5 with the error handler trying 2 to 5 with that error handler doing 3 to 4 and its success _and_ error handlers doing 4 to 5, and then have the succcess handlers for all of those except 3->4 and the error handler for 4->5 all be the smae "ok we're ready" handler

[17:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[17:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[17:23:02.0000] <enigmus>
I'm afraid there might be some problem with patents, though. Apple seems to claim ownership of a few of these, more or less.

[17:24:00.0000] <enigmus>

[17:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, we have the W3C Patent Policy to handle the patents.

[17:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If they have any, they have to declare them when the feature gets to Working Draft, and say whether they'll license them royalty-free.

[17:26:00.0000] <enigmus>
Great. I'm not sure what is the situation: Android and Nokia n900 do not support things like "pinch" to zoom (even though the hardware is capable), but Windows 7 does.

[17:27:00.0000] <enigmus>
I've heard claims Apple says they feel they have a patent on that one. Would they license it to MS? Maybe.

[17:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If it's in a Working Draft, they have to say so, yes or no.

[17:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Royalty-free for all implementations of the standard, or not.

[17:28:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
And if not, they could be kicked out of the Working Group, as I understand it, if the patent covers "essential claims" (although I might misremember).

[17:28:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
(this is all W3C stuff, not WHATWG)

[21:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
/me ponders how to solve the microdata-to-rdf problem

[21:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it isn't solved already?

[21:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: issues were brought up

[21:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
sadness

[21:29:00.0000] <Hixie>
specifically, how to convert the following:

[21:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
    <div itemscope itemtype="http://example.com/a" itemref="x"></div>

[21:29:02.0000] <Hixie>
    <div itemscope itemtype="http://example.com/b" itemref="x"></div>

[21:29:03.0000] <Hixie>
    <div id="x"> <p itemprop="q" itemscope> <span itemprop="r">s</span> </p> </div>

[21:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't think I am clear enough on the semantics of Microdata to help

[21:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I imagine the problem is that the contents of div#x are being interpreted in two different ways?

[21:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[21:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
not a problem for microdata, but when converting to rdf it causes an issue

[21:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
because they need a URL for the properties

[22:43:00.0000] <Hixie>
any rdf people here? Is there any meaning to the concept of a triple being stated twice?

[22:44:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. if I write (in Turtle): <about:1> <about:2> <about:3> . <about:1> <about:2> <about:3> .

[22:44:01.0000] <Hixie>
is that any different than just saying it once?

[23:33:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Where do people get this idea that HTML5 needs to make conforming everything that has ever been conforming?

[23:33:01.0000] <hsivonen>
HTML 2.0 doctypes aren't conforming per 3.2

[23:33:02.0000] <hsivonen>
and 2.0 and 3.2 doctypes aren't conforming per 4.0

[23:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: HTML4 Transitional documents aren't conforming HTML4 Strict, even

[23:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think people are starting with an assumption that IETF mime type registration updates can never make previous content of that MIME type noncomforming, combined with the fact that HTML5 obsoletes the old registration and does not explicitly mention the old versions

[23:56:01.0000] <othermaciej>
to conclude that

[23:56:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(I do not know if there is really such an IETF rule or if it applies to the W3C's inline registrations)

[23:56:03.0000] <Hixie>
there's a whole section on older versions

[23:56:04.0000] <Hixie>
"History", in the introduction

[23:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
then it seems like the logic being applied is fallacious if it is along the lines I said

[23:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2854 explicitly says it's not compatible with HTML2, even

[23:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
and HTML3:

[23:58:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Wouldn't it be sufficient to say something along the lines of: "The text/html content type may be used to label documents that conform to previous levels of HTML."

[23:58:03.0000] <Hixie>
      Note that [HTML20] included an optional "level" parameter; in

[23:58:04.0000] <Hixie>
      practice, this parameter was never used and has been removed from

[23:58:05.0000] <Hixie>
      this specification.  [HTML30] also suggested a "version"

[23:58:06.0000] <Hixie>
      parameter; in practice, this parameter also was never used and has

[23:58:07.0000] <Hixie>
      been removed from this specification.

[23:59:00.0000] <hsivonen>
s/previous levels/a previous level/

[23:59:01.0000] <Hixie>
hsivonen: maybe. would that mean you can't write a validator unless you implement every version?

[23:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
i think the spec already allows you to bail if the doctype is some older version's, no?

[23:59:03.0000] <Hixie>
or did i remove that

[00:00:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: at least the spec allows validators to go into a legacy checking mode

[00:01:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: even if the MIME registration permitted HTML 2.0, I have no intention to support HTML 2.0 validation

[00:01:01.0000] <Hixie>
holy crap, this is a must in 2854:

[00:01:02.0000] <Hixie>
      Implementors of text/html interpreters must be prepared to be

[00:01:03.0000] <Hixie>
      "bug-compatible" with popular browsers in order to work with many

[00:01:04.0000] <Hixie>
      HTML documents available the Internet.

[00:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
you know, i really can't see anything in 2854 that is any different than what html5 does, really

[00:02:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: how did an anti-competitive statement like that get into an RFC edited by L. Masinter?

[00:02:02.0000] <Hixie>
so i don't understand the problem at all

[00:02:03.0000] <Hixie>
hopefully bugs have been filed explaining what parts of 2854 i need to include to make things better

[00:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
assuming 2854 is ok

[00:03:01.0000] <Hixie>
which it presumably is

[00:03:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: it would mean you couldn't write a validator for conformance to the text/html content type without implementing every version, but you could still write an HTML5 validator

[00:10:00.0000] <hsivonen>
hmm. the full screen controls in http://jilion.com/sublime/video are different from the full window controls

[00:10:01.0000] <hsivonen>
are the full screen controls Safari-native?

[00:14:00.0000] <boblet>
any webkit peeps here? tried on #webkit but no informative replies :)

[00:14:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think Larry has a point about overspecification being anti-competitive - it's true if you are more worried about protecting the 0.01% implementation from the 2% implementation than the 2% implementation from the 60% implementation

[00:17:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I can see the point, but it seems to me that in practice, having undocumented but de facto necessary behaviors is more anti-competitive

[00:17:01.0000] <hsivonen>
overspecifying the unnecessary could be anti-competitive

[00:18:00.0000] <hsivonen>
but the thing is that whenever top 4 or even top 3 UAs have converged on a behavior, someone somewhere starts relying on it

[00:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: actually, roc made a good point about that

[00:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: which is that over-specification is harmless in practice

[00:18:03.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: since if it's not required to compete, you can just ignore it

[00:18:04.0000] <othermaciej>
of course, US antitrust law (and probably European too) would be more worried about a 60% vs 2% situation than a 2% vs 0.01% situation

[00:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: and if it is, it helps the underdog

[00:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: so in fact, it's better to overspecify

[00:19:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: sometimes, it's really hard to tell which parts of HTML5 are known to be required to compete and which parts aren't

[00:19:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: my underlying model is that the far underdog (as opposed to the still-significant underdog) does not have the resources to independently determine what parts of the spec are required

[00:20:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: so one could argue you waste resources by implementing parts that aren't competitive requirements

[00:20:01.0000] <othermaciej>
nor the resources to just implement the whole spec

[00:20:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: and developing the knowledge of which parts are hard and which soft requirements for competitiveness partially comes back to the reverse engineering problem

[00:20:03.0000] <Hixie>
i view the spec as being like a high resolution image

[00:21:00.0000] <Hixie>
and an implementation as being like an approximation of that image

[00:21:01.0000] <hsivonen>
although it's still better than just reverse engineering, because the spec gives you a hypothesis

[00:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
now there are two ways to do this:

[00:21:03.0000] <Hixie>
fill in each pixel one by one, or fill in the broad brush strokes and slowly improve each bit

[00:21:04.0000] <Hixie>
if you do the former, then (a) you'll never be done and (b) over-specifying is a bad idea

[00:21:05.0000] <Hixie>
if you do the other one, then you'll ship soon, and you'll immediately get feedback about which parts to try to paint in more detail

[00:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think Larry's incorrect premise is that the level of benefit to #300 vs #4 is as important as the level of benefit to #4 vs #1

[00:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
and over time you approximate the spec in more and more detail

[00:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
so i stand by roc's premise

[00:22:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that's not how we tend to evaluate whether a market is competitive, at least in law, economics or common-sense understanding

[00:23:00.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: indeed, we'd be lucky (in terms of preserving freedom and choice) to have even a 5th major impl.

[00:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
well, we have a 4-and-a-halfth at least

[00:23:02.0000] <hsivonen>
the and a half part fools people into thinking there are actually 5

[00:24:00.0000] <hsivonen>
so that stuff that is WebKit only, gets promoted as Safari, Chrome and Chrome Frame and counted as 3

[00:24:01.0000] <hsivonen>
s/,//

[00:24:02.0000] <othermaciej>
-and-a-half probably overestimates the degree of difference actually

[00:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think citing Safari, Chrome and Chrome Frame is only relevant in terms of telling content authors the size of their potential deployment target; definitely is not 3 separate implementations for standards purposes

[00:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(nor do Safari on iPhone, Safari on iPad, Arora, Epiphany, OmniWeb, iCab, Sunrise Browser, etc all count as additional implementations)

[00:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
man, even the w3c wasn't this arrogant when we discussed the w3c and the whatwg working together on html5

[00:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
the ietf people are making me have renewed respect for the w3c

[00:32:02.0000] <Hixie>
how dare they!

[00:34:00.0000] <hsivonen>
If IETF doesn't offer patent protection, what's the upside of taking the Web Socket protocol to the IETF?

[00:34:01.0000] <Hixie>

[00:34:02.0000] <hsivonen>
does the W3C require the protocol to be an IETF spec in order to get the PP on the API?

[00:35:00.0000] <Hixie>
(in theory more review)

[00:35:01.0000] <Hixie>
the W3C does not require the protocol to be an IETF spec at all

[00:35:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's only not in the W3C spec because the IETF whined to the W3C than the W3C were overstepping their agreement on who would work on what

[00:35:03.0000] <othermaciej>
IETF requires patent disclosure at least (IIRC)

[00:35:04.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: as far as i can tell it requires patent disclosure of patents that the contributors know about

[00:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
and minimum RAND licensing, though a group can ask for RF commitments

[00:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
and i certainly don't know jack about google's patents

[00:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't remember the details that clearly

[00:36:03.0000] <hsivonen>
what's the IETF definition of RAND?

[00:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:39:01.0000] <Hixie>

[00:39:02.0000] <Hixie>

[00:41:00.0000] <Lachy>
The problem with RAND is that what is considered reasonable is left entirely up to the patent holder, and the definition of non-discriminitory is that the fee applies equally to everyone, despite discriminating against those who can't be expected to afford the "reasonable" fee

[00:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
the fee isn't the problem, when it comes to free software

[00:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
but yeah

[00:48:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:48:01.0000] <Hixie>

[00:54:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: you were right that making streamless about:blank fire onload is a pain

[00:54:01.0000] <Hixie>
heh

[00:55:00.0000] <hsivonen>
all this onload firing machinery wants to see a stream-bound request

[00:55:01.0000] <Hixie>
the problem in the spec would be making sure it doesn't fire twice

[00:55:02.0000] <Hixie>
not really sure how to do that

[00:55:03.0000] <Hixie>

[00:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
and when you don't load a page, well, you didn't load a page. There's nothing to hook onto to fire the load.

[00:56:01.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: I put the about:blank creation on the code path that with any other URL kicks off the first actual load

[00:57:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: and if the browser context hasn't had anything loaded to it and is about to load about:blank, I generate a document and return early

[00:57:01.0000] <Hixie>

[00:57:02.0000] <hsivonen>

[00:57:03.0000] <hsivonen>
but when I try to fake onload, I keep hitting assertions that want to see a network request

[00:58:00.0000] <hsivonen>
so I guess I'll end up faking one

[06:55:01.0000] <Philip`>
therefore we can't allow it

[06:55:02.0000] <Philip`>
Proof by contradiction

[06:57:00.0000] <Dashiva>
If it's not proof by axiom, it isn't valid

[06:57:01.0000] <annevk>
I think that statement follows from the imo misguided way media types are drafted to work

[06:58:00.0000] <annevk>
btw, I noticed data URLs were discussed at some point here

[06:58:01.0000] <annevk>
they do have fragment identifiers

[06:58:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Only in Opera, apparently

[06:58:03.0000] <annevk>
fragment identifiers depend on the media type, not URI scheme

[06:58:04.0000] <annevk>
well, Firefox is buggy

[06:58:05.0000] <jgraham>
And webkit

[06:58:06.0000] <annevk>
also buggy

[06:58:07.0000] <Philip`>
Maybe it's actually a (sensible) desire to guarantee backward compatibility within media types, but twisted by a (incorrect) notion that content conformance and interoperable operation are tied together

[06:59:00.0000] <annevk>
see RFC 3986

[06:59:01.0000] <Lachy_>
Dashiva, people who claim things like that need to realise that a new specification making things non-conformng with respect to that particular specification, doesn't make those things non-conforming with respect to other specifications.

[06:59:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Lachy: I think the complaint is partially that changing the registration would make all text/html be considered HTML5

[07:00:00.0000] <Dashiva>
So you wouldn't be able to serve HTML<5 at all

[07:01:00.0000] <Lachy_>
that's nonsense. You can serve it. It's just non-conforming HTML5. But it may still be conforming with the older specifications, despite those older specifications being obsolete

[07:02:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:02:01.0000] <Philip`>
(since the new registration information for text/html would supercede the old ones)

[08:17:00.0000] <Lachy>

[08:17:01.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: It's not so much that, it's just URLs beginning with javascript: and data: are special-cased

[08:17:02.0000] <Lachy>
that's unfortunate :-(

[08:18:00.0000] <gsnedders>
It's better than fucking up every URI scheme totally

[08:20:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
gsnedders, RFC 3986 explicitly says that URI schemes can't special-case fragment syntax, as annevk pointed out.

[08:21:00.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: Yes, but it isn't just fragment syntax that is special cased. It the whole URI-reference that is special cased.

[08:21:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Really?

[08:21:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me looks more closely

[08:22:00.0000] <gsnedders>
If the string starts with javascript: or data:, it isn't treated as a URI at all

[08:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It seems like RFC 3986 allows URIs like data: and javascript:, with the path component defined as path-rootless.

[08:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
In what way is it not treated as a URI at all?  It looks like a URI to me.

[08:24:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Indeed.

[08:24:01.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: It's not actually parsed as a URL. The leading string is stripped, and pct-encoding is decoded.

[08:25:00.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: <iframe src="javascript://foobar%0Adocument.write('a')"></iframe>

[08:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So how is that not parsing as a URL?  It's just a URL that doesn't use the hierarchy syntax.

[08:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
RFC 3986 allows those as URIs.

[08:26:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Basically just a leading "something:" following by anything you like, and then a fragment.

[08:26:03.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: Because we'd have to separate it up into segments, and would only apy attention to path

[08:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, you do.  The path is just one segment, namely, the whole URL other than the initial "data:" and the trailing fragment.

[08:28:01.0000] <Dashiva>
And query part

[08:28:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah, that too.

[08:28:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Was about to say.

[08:28:04.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: No, we don't.

[08:28:05.0000] <gsnedders>
Look at that example above

[08:28:06.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: The whole thing is in the host

[08:28:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
What about it?  The path is "//foobar\ndocument.write('a')".

[08:28:08.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, there's no host.

[08:29:00.0000] <gsnedders>
How not?

[08:29:01.0000] <gsnedders>
A path can't start with //

[08:29:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Because an authority starts with //

[08:29:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
URI         = scheme ":" hier-part [ "?" query ] [ "#" fragment ]

[08:29:04.0000] <gsnedders>
/me thinks AryehGregor has got his ABNF wrong

[08:29:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
hier-part   = "//" authority path-abempty

[08:29:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
                  / path-absolute

[08:29:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
                  / path-rootless

[08:29:08.0000] <AryehGregor>
                  / path-empty

[08:29:09.0000] <AryehGregor>
path-rootless = segment-nz *( "/" segment )

[08:29:10.0000] <gsnedders>
It doesn't match path-absolute, path-rootless, or path-empty

[08:29:11.0000] <AryehGregor>
segment-nz    = 1*pchar

[08:29:12.0000] <AryehGregor>
It matches path-rootless.

[08:29:13.0000] <gsnedders>
pchar doesn't contain /

[08:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hmm.

[08:30:01.0000] <gsnedders>
Otherwise that would be ambiguous for cases like //gsnedders.com

[08:30:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Touche.

[08:30:03.0000] <Dashiva>
javascript: URLs are just an abomination, we shouldn't try to treat them otherwise

[08:30:04.0000] <gsnedders>
The only alternation there that can start with // is "//" authority path-abempty

[08:30:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Okay, you win.

[08:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
data: and javascript: don't follow URI syntax at all, so no reason to quibble over the fragment or query parts.

[07:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me is befuddled by smart compilers rearranging his computations for efficiency.

[07:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I understand that moving the division into a non-critical path so it can be done at the computer's leisure is *theoretically* a good thing, but the fact that this actually translates into a 10% speedup is astonishing.

[07:17:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's more befuddling because CPUs rearrange computations too

[07:19:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I know!  It's crazy.

[07:19:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I would never have thought to swap my algorithm around to move where the division takes place.

[07:19:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think I'm spoiled by not ever coding in C?

[07:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
Was it moved out of a loop or something?

[07:20:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Or into a rare conditional branch?

[07:20:02.0000] <Philip`>
/me wouldn't expect simple shuffling to affect much

[07:21:00.0000] <annevk>
oh yes, <1300

[07:21:01.0000] <annevk>
only 800-900 to go to get back to the old level

[07:22:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I was doing an array walk, based on the value in the array.  Previously the division was required to find the next index and I simply collected the value, but I swapped it so I use the division to collect values, and use the array val itself as the next index.

[07:22:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(In more specific terms, I was factoring a number using a slightly modified Sieve of Eratosthenes.  Originally I stored the smallest factor of the index, now I store the largest factor.)

[07:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
You mean so it can now do the division and memory fetch in parallel, or something like that?

[07:26:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I presume that's what is happening, yes.

[07:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
Sounds plausible

[01:14:00.0000] <Hixie>

[01:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: you don't need anything in websocket to do the negotiation of what frame types are supported, because you simply wouldn't use the frame types with an unsupporting server

[01:18:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: you know who the server is when you connect to it -- it's the server you specified

[01:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: how does the server know what frame types the client supports?

[01:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: it's the same as when you write a <form>, you know what form fields it's expecting, because you know the server

[01:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: send a frame of that type and see if you get a reply from your script

[01:19:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: also: the knowledge of frame types may need to be in the UA, not the JS-level code, if you expect frame types to have special processing and the UA is supposed to send them transparently

[01:19:04.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: or have the script feature-test and inform the server

[01:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
can you give an example of such a type?

[01:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm having difficulty working out what that would look like

[01:21:00.0000] <othermaciej>
let's say there was a frame type that implies gzip compression by the sender and gzip decompression by the client

[01:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
(don't forget that this is intended to be as close to pure TCP as we can get)

[01:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
oh, that's easy

[01:21:03.0000] <othermaciej>
(so that your compression/decompression code could be C++ in the browser, instead of coded in JS)

[01:21:04.0000] <Hixie>
just include a Supports-Gzip: header in the handshake

[01:21:05.0000] <othermaciej>
is it ok to add arbitrary headers to the handshake?

[01:21:06.0000] <Hixie>
                                   yes

[01:21:07.0000] <Hixie>
er, yes

[01:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
then that seems to be all the negotiation mechanism needed

[01:22:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it might be useful to define a convention for known frame types, but that is not really needed until frame types exist beyond the 1.0 set

[01:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
indeed

[01:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
all I wanted to know is that there is a mechanism whereby the negotiation can be added compatibly, and without extra round trips

[01:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
using custom headers seems fine

[01:23:02.0000] <othermaciej>
especially if we can later define one with a standard meaning

[01:24:00.0000] <Hixie>

[06:40:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[06:40:01.0000] <Philip`>

[06:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
and popular codecs have more and better encoders, so you can get better videos even if the codec is technically no better than another

[06:41:01.0000] <Steve^>

[06:41:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[06:43:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[06:43:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[06:43:02.0000] <Philip`>

[06:43:03.0000] <Philip`>
and if you're a user of Youtube then the latency of encoding is important, because you want to point people at your video as quickly as possible

[06:43:04.0000] <Steve^>

[12:46:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
annevk: A better variant of that idea would be to allow @sandbox on <html>, but that's already been suggested to be possible on any element - it fails open in legacy clients, though.

[12:47:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
At least, though, the escaping situation is less dire if you don't do it right - worst case the page will end prematurely because an attacker emitted </html>.

[12:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
<plaintext sandbox>

[12:48:01.0000] <Philip`>
That'll have safe legacy behaviour

[12:49:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Once you do that, though, what's the point of @sandbox?

[12:49:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
<plaintext> prevents the <script> from running anyway.

[12:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
In supporting browsers it would parse the context as sandboxed HTML instead

[12:51:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
...that makes sense.  Hmm.

[12:52:00.0000] <Dashiva>
How about just serving text/html-sandboxed?

[12:52:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That doesn't let you specify which sandboxing behaviors you want.

[12:53:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Though, of course, if you then do <html sandbox>...

[12:53:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That is, if you do that and serve it with text/html-sandboxed.

[12:53:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That seems like a good idea.

[12:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
No point making it so complex that people won't bother using it

[12:57:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I've added a comment to the bug along those lines.

[12:57:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
No more complex than iframe sandboxing.

[12:57:03.0000] <Philip`>
Does <iframe sandbox src> require that the content is text/html-sandboxed?

[12:57:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, it doesn't require it.  It'll just fail open if you don't.  Same thing here.

[12:57:05.0000] <annevk>
it wouldn't fail for cross-origin

[12:58:00.0000] <annevk>
at some point we might need a global script language switch

[12:58:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Well, partially.  You'd get the different-origin protection, at least.

[12:58:02.0000] <Philip`>
I guess it'll be common for people to either forget to set the content-type at all, or to accidentally set it back to text/html later when they're not paying attention, which wouldn't be much fun

[12:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
(and they wouldn't notice until someone exploited it)

[12:59:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:00:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:00:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
